Text: What nerve supplies the anterior motor compartment of the thigh?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The anterior muscles of the thigh (i.e. the quadricep muscles, iliopsoas, pectineus and sartorius) are supplied by the femoral nerve, which is a major nerve that originates from the lumbar plexus. Source: TeachMeAnatomy - Muscles of the Anterior Thigh
IncorrectAnswers: Tibial;;Sciatic;;Obturator;;Gluteal

Text: Which of the following drugs acts by reducing dopamine re-uptake from the synaptic cleft?

Text: Which nerve innervates the posterior muscles of the thigh?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The muscles of the posterior thigh are supplied by the Sciatic Nerve. Reference: TeachMeAnatomy - Muscles of the Posterior Thigh
IncorrectAnswers: Gluteal;;Obturator;;Tibial;;Femoral

Text: The loss of which ion from injured spinal cord cells is thought to be linked to spinal shock?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The reason spinal shock occurs is that there is a sudden loss of conductivity of electrical signals in the spinal cord as potassium ions move from the intracellular to the extracellular spaces (i.e. from inside cells to outside cells). When this happens the body can no longer effectively send nerve signal impulses to control automatic reflexes below the site of the spinal cord injury. In some cases the area above the spinal cord injury may also be affected, depending on the level of trauma and subsequent inflammation.
IncorrectAnswers: Calcium;;Chloride;;Sodium;;Magnesium

Text: At which vertebral levels would we expect to find sympathetic fibres in the spinal nerves?
Which neurotransmitter receptor is targeted by many general anaesthetics?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
A number of drugs used in anaesthesia have a large association with the neurotransmitter GABA. Drugs such as benzodiazepines, alcohol and barbiturates act both directly and allosterically at the GABA receptor. Increasing the action of GABA leads to increased chloride flux across neuronal membranes, which hyperpolarises and thus reduces neuronal firing.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/BkCUL1-RM4U" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Acetylcholine;;Glutamate;;Dopamine;;Noradrenaline

Text: Which two cords of the brachial plexus contribute to the median nerve?
IncorrectAnswers: Posterior and anterior;;Anterior and medial;;Medial and posterior;;Lateral and posterior

Text: Which spinal nerves are responsible for the Knee Jerk reflex?
Which of the following analgesics has an unclear mechanism of action?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The mechanism of action of paracetamol is not completely understood. Unlike NSAIDs such as aspirin, paracetamol does not appear to inhibit the function of any cyclooxygenase (COX) enzyme outside the central nervous system, and this appears to be the reason why it is not useful as an anti-inflammatory. It does appear to selectively inhibit COX activities in the brain, which may contribute to its ability to treat fever and pain. This activity does not appear to be direct inhibition by blocking an active site, but rather by reducing COX, which must be oxidized in order to function.[
IncorrectAnswers: NSAIDs;;Ketamine;;Opioids;;COX-2 inhibitors

Text: What of the following nerves is not a branch of the brachial plexus?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The intercostal (AKA thoracoabdominal) nerves are direct branches of the spinal nerves at each spinal level, and do not branch from the brachial plexus.

Text: Damage to which of the following nerves would result in flexed little and ring fingers?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Injury to the ulnar nerve leads to paralysis of the interossei, so abduction and adduction of the fingers cannot occur. Movement of the little and ring fingers is greatly reduced, due to paralysis of the medial two lumbricals. Ulnar claw consists of: 1. Hyper-extension of the metacarpophalangeal joints of the little and ring fingers  this is because of the paralysis of the medial two lumbricals, and the now unopposed action of the extensor muscles 2. Flexion at the interphalangeal joints (if the lesion has occurred close to the elbow, this might not be evident, as the flexor digitorum profundus will be paralysed) Reference: TeachMeAnatomy
IncorrectAnswers: Musculocutaneous;;Radial;;Axillary;;Median

Text: Damage to which nerve would result in wrist drop?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The radial nerve supplies the extensors of the wrist: extensor carpi ulnaris and extensor carpi radialis longus/brevis. If these nerves do not function, the wrist 'drops'. Reference: TeachMeAnatomy - Radial Nerve
IncorrectAnswers: Ulnar;;Axillary;;Musculocutaneous;;Median

Text:
Q1. A 8-year-old boy presents to the Emergency Department with a left-sided limp since one day ago.
He is able to walk, albeit with pain. He is otherwise well. Upon further questioning, his caregivers report coryzal symptoms one week prior.
On examination, he is normal weight child and afebrile. His left hip is not warm, swollen or erythematous. Additionally, it is not externally rotated or shortened. No neurological symptoms are present.
What would be the most appropriate management?
CorrectAnswer: Discharge home to caregivers with appropriate return instructions
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The most likely diagnosis is transient synovitis (Irritable hip). 

As per RCH Guidelines for the limping child: "Unless suspecting a specific diagnosis, investigations are usually not required in children with limp <3 days duration."

https://www.rch.org.au/clinicalguide/guideline_index/Child_with_limp/
IncorrectAnswers: Urgent referral to orthopaedics for theatre and washout;;FBE, ESR, Blood cultures, left-hip X-ray and bone scan;;Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics;;Orthopaedics outpatients in 6 weeks for elective operative stabilisation

Text:
Q10. A 30-year-old male presents to his GP with increasing lower back pain during the night and morning stiffness. The pain and stiffness improves with exercise and does not improve with rest.
What investigation result would confirm your suspicions?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Ankylosing spondylitis
IncorrectAnswers:
Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reaction protein (CRP)
;;High bone-mineral density (BMD)
;;Microcytic, hypochromic anaemia
;;Positive rheumatoid factor (RF)

Text:
Q6. A 65-year-old female presents to her GP with acute onset headache, associated with scalp tenderness, jaw claudication and stiff shoulders.
She denies visual loss, visual aura, photophobia, nausea, vomiting, rhinorrhoea, tearing from her eyes and neck pain.
What would be the most appropriate acute management?

IncorrectAnswers: Referral to neurosurgery for craniotomy and relief of intracranial pressure;;Dark room, IV normal saline and prochlorperazine;;Paracetamol and NSAID;;100% oxygen via non-rebreathing mask and subcutaneous sumatriptan

Q9. A 37 year-old female presents to her General Practitioner with a new-onset, progressive history of dysphagia to solids and liquids. She also complains of burning pains in her fingers and toes, especially during the past Winter season.
On examination, she has white spots on her fingers and thread-like red lines on her skin around her lips.

Limited cutaneous scleroderma - CREST syndrome
Calcinosis
Raynaud phenomenon
(O)esophageal dysmotility
Sclerodactyly
Telangiectasia

Text:
Q4. A 25-year-old male involved in a motor vehicle accident sustained a left femur fracture among other injuries. He has been admitted to the orthopaedic ward for further management.
While on the ward, one day after his admission, while the nurses were taking their regular observations, they noticed he had become hypoxic. The intern was paged and upon further examination, the patient became dyspneic, tachypneic and acutely confused.
Which of these is INCORRECT?
CorrectAnswer: Early immobilisation of fractures should be avoided because it can precipitate fat embolism syndrome
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Early immobilisation is a preventative measure for fat embolism in long bone fractures. 
https://www.cicm.org.au/CICM_Media/CICMSite/CICM-Website/Resources/Publications/CCR%20Journal/Previous%20Editions/September%201999/08-Sept_1999_Fat-Embolism.pdf
IncorrectAnswers: The characteristic red-brown, petechial rash may only be present in one-third of cases;;Diagnosing fat embolism syndrome may include laboratory studies and chest imaging;;Fat embolism syndrome is a rare clinical syndrome, typically due to long bone and pelvic fractures;;Treatment of fat embolism syndrome is largely supportive while it resolves spontaneously

Text:
Q2. A 55-year-old overweight female presents to her GP with a three-month history of RUQ discomfort, fatigue and generalised pruritus. She denies pain after eating fatty meals and denies malodorous, floating stools. She does not take any medications. She denies being currently pregnant. She is a non-drinker and non-smoker. 
On examination, you notice mild conjunctival icterus and mild hepatosplenomegaly. No ascites is present. Murphy s sign is negative.
What would be the most appropriate investigation to confirm your suspected diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Primary Biliary Cholangitis
- Rare, autoimmune condition that primarily affects women between ages 30-65
- Up to 60% may be asymptomatic and are detected because of incidental abnormal LFTs
- Often associated with other autoimmune disorders e.g. Sjogren syndrome, autoimmune thyroid disease, arthropathies and myopathies

Liver function tests are appropriate but are not diagnostic
IncorrectAnswers: Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA);;Extractable Nuclear Antigen Antibodies (ENA);;Liver function tests;;Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR) and C-Reactive Protein (CRP)

Text:
During a fight a woman is stabbed in the lateral chest beneath the right arm. The wound does not enter the chest cavity. Physical examination reveals that the vertebral (medial) border of the patient's scapula projects posteriorly and is closer to the midline on the injured side. On return visit the patient complains that she cannot reach as far forward (such as to reach for a door knob) as she could before the injury. 

Which nerve was injured to cause these symptoms?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
An injury to the long thoracic nerve denervates serratus anterior, meaning that there will be no muscle protracting the scapula and counteracting trapezius and the rhomboids, powerful retractors of the scapula. The long thoracic nerve is derived from the nerve roots of C5-7; this nerve is particularly vulnerable to iatrogenic injury during surgical procedures because it is located on the superficial side of serratus anterior.

The axillary nerve innervates teres minor and deltoid. It wraps around the surgical neck of the humerus and is endangered by fractures of the surgical neck. If the axillary nerve was damaged and deltoid was denervated, the patient would be unable to abduct his upper limb beyond 15 to 20 degrees. The musculocutaneous nerve innervates biceps brachi, coracobrachialis, and brachialis. If this nerve was disrupted, the patient would be unable to flex her or his forearm, and have weakened arm flexion. The radial nerve innervates extensors of the forearm and triceps brachi--if this nerve was injured, the patient would no longer be able to extend forearm, but only have slightly weakened arm extension (latissimus is the powerful extensor of the arm). Finally, the suprascapular nerve innervates supraspinatus--the muscle that initiates abduction. Damage to this nerve would prevent the patient from starting to abduct her or his arm.
IncorrectAnswers: Musculocutaneous;;Axillary;;Suprascapular;;Radial

Text:
You are the ED nights intern in a rural emergency department. You attend a trauma call, where the patient is a 24 year old male who was ejected from the passenger seat of a car during a MVA (car v tree) at approximately 65km/h. He was not wearing a seatbelt. He is screaming in pain, tachycardic and has multiple lacerations that are actively bleeding on multiple limbs and his face, presumably from the glass windscreen. 

What is not a part of your initial management?
CorrectAnswer: Examine and palpate the C spine
CorrectAnswerExplanation: According to the ATLS primary survey protocol, receiving a handover, assessing vitals, attending to ABCs and securing the C-Spine are the priorities initially, as these are the most important actions to ensure survival of the patient. Palpating the C spine is part if the secondary survey.
IncorrectAnswers:
Apply a Cervical Spine Collar
;;Listen to ARV handover;;Perform airway manoeuvers ;;Assess vital signs

Text:
A 67 year old woman presents with palpitations. Her pulse rate is around 150/min. An ECG is ordered immediately, and shown below.

What does the ECG show?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The ECG shows atrial flutter with 2:1 block. It has the characteristic  sawtooth  appearance.

The QRS complexes are less than 3mm in width, therefore are narrow complex. This rules out broad-commplex tachycardia.

The ECG shows a regular rhythm, thus ruling out atrial fibrillation.

The classic delta wave and shortened PR interval are not present here, thus making Wolff-Parkinson White Syndrome unlikely.

Junctional Tachycardia would most likely show retrograde P waves and inverted P waves in the inferior leads.
IncorrectAnswers:
Broad-Complex Tachycardia;;Atrial Fibrillation
;;Junctional Tachycardia;;Wolff-Parkinson White Syndrome

Text:
Janice, a 78yo, who smokes like a chimney, presents to the ED with central chest pain. She has COPD, and was hospitalised last week for an infective exacerbation. The nurse has a ECG done, and it shows the following (see below).

What is the most likely cause of Janice  chest pain?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Pericarditis; Symptoms- Pleuritic chest pain, positional, usually anterior. 
Causes: infections (usually viral), metabolic, systemic/connective tissue disease, post injury. 
Diagnosis made on ECG: Concave ST elevation, PR depression, predominant T waves, widespread changes

Tamponade: US/echo (pericardiocentesis) - distended neck veins, faint heart sounds, hypotension
IncorrectAnswers: Anterior STEMI;;Pulmonary Embolism;;Pleural Effusion;;Haemophilus Influenzae Pneumonia

Text:
John is a 28 year old male that has recently been in a motorcycle accident and has sustained a spinal injury. As the intern on the Rehabiliation team you have been asked examine John and record his neurological level of injury using the ASIA tool. Your findings are as follows:
Motor: 3+ hip flexor and 5+ knee extensor bilaterally 
Sensory: normal light touch and pin prick sensation in L2 distribution billaterally, no sensation below this level

According to these findings, what is the neurological level of the patient's spinal cord injury?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswer: The neurological level is at L2 as this is the most caudal intact sensory and motor function
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The ASIA assessment method for spinal cord injuries defines the level of injury as the most caudal spinal level at which there is normal sensation (both light touch and pin prick) and at least 3/5 power with all above levels having 5/5 power. Reference: ASIA Assessment Protocol
IncorrectAnswers: The neurological level cannot be ascertained from one examination;;Cannot comment on the neurological level as we don t know if the lesion is sacral sparing;;The motor function dictates the neurological level therefore it is L2;;The neurological level is at L2 because this is where the sensory level is

Text:
A 74-year old man presents to his GP complaining of unsteadiness on his feet that has developed over many months, and is worsening. He also mentions he has noticed his hearing hasn't been great lately, and he mostly notices this in his right ear. The hearing loss is constant and has been deteriorating for 6 months or more. Neurological exam reveals no nystagmus or middle ear signs. Weber's test lateralises to the left ear, Rinne's test is normal bilaterally.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The stem indicates unsteadiness and a progressive right-sided sensorineural hearing loss. The cochlear and vestibular nerves are most commonly affected by acoustic neuroma. The unsteadiness in acoustic neuroma is unlikely to be true vertigo and develops over a long period of time. 

Acoustic neuromas/vestibular schwannoma cause ~90% of cerebellopontine angle tumours.

Meniere's disease doesn't cause constant hearing loss, and episodes only last a minute or two, rather than having progressively worsening symptoms over a number of weeks-months.
IncorrectAnswers: Bell's Palsy;;Meniere's Disease;;Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV);;Presbycusis

Text: Which of the following figures is an approximation of the amount of blood that is filtered at the glomerulus?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Roughly one fifth of the blood flowing through the glomerulus is filtered (i.e. moves into the lumen of the nephron). However, the vast majority of this filtered plasma is reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubule.

Text: What type of Salter-Harris fracture is this?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: See Radiopaedia
IncorrectAnswers: V;;IV;;III;;I

Text:
Gladys is a 32 year old G4P0, who is currently 8 weeks pregnant. She presents to the emergency department after experiencing light vaginal bleeding. On speculum examination the cervical os is open and no fetal heartbeat can be detected on ultrasound. This is her fourth miscarriage.  
 
Which of the following tests would be least useful in determining an underlying cause for Gladys recurrent miscarriages?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Etiology of recurrent pregnancy loss: 
1.	Mechanical: uterine abnormalities- congenital, polyps, intrauterine adhesions 
2.	Autoimmune: Antiphospholipid syndrome
3.	Karyotype: Aneuploidy, chromosomal rearrangements 
4.	Endocrine: Poorly controlled thyroid or diabetes, PCOS
5.	Maternal Infection: No infectious agent has been proven to cause recurrent pregnancy loss, though some cause sporadic loss: Listeria, toxoplasmosis, CMV, HSV. 
6.	Environment: Obesity, smoking, alcohol use 
7.	Pro-thrombotic conditions: thrombophilia 

Anti-SCL-70 is a serological test for scleroderma
IncorrectAnswers: Anti-dsDNA;;Thyroid function test;;Anti-cardiolipin;;Thrombophilia screen

Text:
Patient A is a 92 year old male undergoing conservative therapy for prostate cancer which was diagnosed 3 years ago. He has presented as he has a deep pain in his upper arm and ribs that is waking him up at night.

Patient B is a 73 year old female that underwent a right-hemicolectomy 4 years ago for bowel cancer. She has been referred to your team as she has been suffering from increasing RUQ pain over the last 2/52. The pain is described as more of a pressure or discomfort and a CT scan of the abdomen shows multiple nodules in the liver.

What is the best therapy for the pain these patients are experiencing.
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswer: Radiotherapy for Patient A; Corticosteroids for Patient B
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Radiotherapy is considered first line treatment for bony metastases in prostate cancer, as it shrinks the metastasis and provides good analgesia. If radiotherapy is not possible, bisphosphonates and denosumab may be used as second line medications.

Corticosteroids have a role in reducing the pain and inflammation associated with metastases to the liver, as seen in this patient (B) with metastatic bowel cancer.
IncorrectAnswers: Corticosteroids for Patient A; Radiotherapy for Patient B;;Corticosteroids for Patient A; Bisphosphonates for Patient B;;Bisphosphonates for Patient A; Corticosteroids for Patient B;;Corticosteroids for Patient A; Corticosteroids for Patient B

Text: Which of the following is the biggest cause of CKD in Australia?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: With a huge rise in incidence over the last several decades, diabetes and its associated nephropathy has become the most common cause of CKD in Australia.
IncorrectAnswers: Lithium toxicity;;Glomerulonephritis;;Hypertension/Ischaemic nephropathy;;Polycystic kidney disease

Text:
Physical examination of a 60 year old woman presenting with a lump on the neck reveals a 2cm mass on the right lobe of her thyroid. It is mobile when she swallows. There are 3 smaller masses on the right lobe. They are mobile, soft, and there is no associated lymphadenopathy.

What is the next most appropriate investigation?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: If the lump produces thyroid hormones it is unlikely to be cancer, and therefore may not need a biopsy.
IncorrectAnswers: Core biopsy;;Ultrasound;;Radioactive Iodine Uptake Scan ;;Fine needle aspiration

Text:
Lucy is a 61-year-old female who presents to her GP with worsening shortness of breath. She began experiencing dyspnoea several months ago, initially limiting her from normal exercise. Now, Lucy is finding that she is becoming short of breath walking on flat ground for only a few hundred metres. Lucy s past medical history is notable for a long history of atrial fibrillation which has been rhythm controlled with amiodarone, as well as rheumatoid arthritis which has been managed with methotrexate. Lucy denies ever having asthma, and has never smoked or worked in an environment with airborne pollutants.

On examination, you note a reduced oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Lucy has fine crepitations over the middle and lower zones of both lungs, but no wheeze.

If you were to conduct spirometry on Lucy, what would you expect the results to show?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The key to this question is understanding the underlying pathology that is affecting Lucy here. Given a history of worsening exertional dyspnoea, but no history obstructive lung disease (smoking and asthma), restrictive lung disease should be considered. In this case, a history of amiodarone and methotrexate use suggests that Lucy is affected by drug-induced interstitial lung disease (these two drugs are known causes of pulmonary fibrosis).

The spirometry findings of restrictive lung disease are normal (but sometimes raised) FEV1.0/FVC, and a reduced FVC. Obstructive lung diseases cause a reduced FEV1.0/FVC, and either a normal or increased FVC.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/yNDKD_xI684?ecver=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Reduced FEV1.0/FVC ratio, normal FVC;;Reduced FEV1.0/FVC ratio, increased FVC;;Normal FEV1.0/FVC ratio, normal FVC;;Increased FEV1.0/FVC ratio, increased FVC

Text: Which one of the following maternal infections has NOT been associated with microcephaly in the fetus?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
If Zika infection occurs during pregnancy it can cause severe microcephaly and other problems such as eye defects, hearing loss, and impaired growth. CMV is one of the TORCH infections. The risk of serious adverse neurological outcome increases if primary infection occurs in the first half of pregnancy. When maternal infection occurs before 8 weeks of pregnancy, 80 90% of infants will have symptoms. Because of high immunization rates, congenital rubella syndrome is now very rare. If maternal chickenpox develops before 20 weeks' gestation there is a 2 3% risk of the fetus developing congenital varicella syndrome. This consists of skin scarring, eye abnormalities (cataracts, chorioretinitis, microphthalmia), hypoplasia of limbs, cortical atrophy, microcephaly, intellectual impairment, neurogenic bladder, oesophageal dilatation and early death. The correct answer is Hepatitis B because infants may become chronic carriers of HBsAg and are at risk of developing carcinoma of the liver. Symptoms of liver disease in the neonatal period are rare in affected babies and microcephaly is unlikely.

Reference: Sinha S, Miall L, Jardine L. Essential neonatal medicine. John Wiley & Sons; 2017 Jun 23.
IncorrectAnswers: CMV infection;;Rubella;;Zika virus;;Varicella

Text:
A 59-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer (treated initially with wide local excision) is being treated with doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide every 3 weeks. Her first treatment began 8 days ago, and she now presents to ED with a temperature of 38.2°C. Her vitals are currently stable, with a heart rate of 76bpm and a blood pressure of 118/78. She has no physical signs or symptoms other than mouth sores. An FBE is promptly arranged, which shows a white blood cell count of 0.5 (RR 4-11) with a neutrophil count of 0.2 (RR 1.5-8).

What is the most important treatment for this patient?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This lady is presenting with febrile neutropenia, a serious oncological emergency. The most important treatment is rapid introduction of broad-spectrum antibiotics. Although there are several regimens used (all endorsed by therapeutic guidelines), each hospital will have its own relevant guidelines.

The most appropriate out of the list given here is piperacillin/tazobactam (Tazocin).
IncorrectAnswers: 1L 0.9% NaCl IV STAT, with a noradrenaline infusion if systolic blood pressure falls below 90mmHg;;IV dexamethasone;;Amoxicillin/Clavulanate 500 mg orally TDS;;Infusion of Granulocyte macrophage colony stimulating factor (GM-CSF)

Text:
Thelma, an 18 year old female presents to your general practice clinic with an irregular menstrual cycle. She also comments that she is keeping her local beautician in business with her requirements for regular waxing (including facial and chest).
 
Given the likely diagnosis what would you expect to find on her blood results?
CorrectAnswer: LH:FSH ratio increased, free testosterone increased, decreased SHBG
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The likely diagnosis is PCOS. Diagnostic Criteria: (2 of 3). 
1. Cystic appearance of ovaries on ultrasound (ring of pearls). 
2. Oligomenorrhea /Amenorrhea. 
3. Evidence of excess androgens (hirsutism/acne etc.)      
FSH stimulates granulosa cells to convert androgens to oestrogen.
LH stimulates thecal cells to convert DHEA to androgen. 
This mismatch between FSH and LH results in excess androgens. 
SHBG: glycoprotein that binds to oestrogen and testosterone. SHBG decreases the bioavailability of sex hormones.
IncorrectAnswers: LH:FSH ratio increased, free testosterone decreased, increased SHBG;;LH:FSH ratio increased, free testosterone increased, increased SHBG;;LH:FSH ratio decreased, free testosterone decreased, decreased SHBG;;LH: FSH ratio decreased, free testosterone increased, increased SHBG

Text:
A 42-year-old male is admitted to ICU for treatment of respiratory failure secondary to Guillain-Barre Syndrome. His ventilator is set to a tidal volume of 600ml and a respiratory rate of 15. The patient is in a deep induced coma, so is not ventilating spontaneously. After several days in ICU, the patient develops a fever, and is found to have a new bacteraemia on blood cultures.

What change would you expect as a result of the patient s new infection?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Arterial CO2 is determined by systemic CO2 production and alveolar ventilation. While alveolar ventilation is unchanged here (due to ventilator solely determining ventilation parameters), CO2 production will have increased due to system infection and fever. Because ventilation has remained constant, arterial CO2 will rise accordingly, and dead space volumes (anatomic and physiological) will remain constant.
IncorrectAnswers: Increase in volume of gas delivered to each alveolus with each breath;;Increase in ventilation to dependent regions of the lung;;Decrease in physiologic dead space;;Decrease in the anatomic dead space

Text:
Philip, a 46 year old recreational drinker, presents after a big night on the town. He has significant epigastric pain radiating to the back and an elevated lipase. 

Which of the following parameters will NOT assist you classifying the severity of his disease at admission?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Ransin criteria for classification of severity of pancreatitis 
At admission 
1.	WCC > 16 000
2.	Age > 55
3.	BSL > 11
4.	LDH > 350
5.	AST > 250
Within 48 hours
1.	Serum calcium <2.0
2.	Hematocrit fall >10%
3.	BUN increase by 1.8 or more 
4.	Base deficit >4 
5.	Sequestration of fluids >6L 
Lipase levels are not an indicator is severity of pancreatitis
IncorrectAnswers: Blood sugar level (BSL);;Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH);;White cell count (WCC);;Age

Text:
A 26-year-old woman has fallen on an outstretched hand during a game of netball. She presents to ED two days later with a persistent sore wrist. On examination, she is tender between the extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis longus. Resisted pronation also elicits pain. A fracture is clinically suspected. 

Which of the following statements regarding the most likely diagnosis is incorrect?
CorrectAnswer: The fracture may result in avascular necrosis of the distal half of the bone
CorrectAnswerExplanation: This a scaphoid fracture, where interruption of the retrograde blood supply to the proximal portion of the bone may lead to avascular necrosis. Scaphoid fractures often require special 'scaphoid' views to be seen on plain film X rays, and may not be apparent until 3 weeks after the injury. The fracture is often displaced, and may require internal fixation to prevent avascular necrosis.
IncorrectAnswers: The fracture is often undisplaced;;The fracture may require treatment by internal fixation;;The patient may require special xray views to demonstrate the fracture;;The fracture may not be seen on any xray film before three weeks

Text: The following radiological features are matched with the correct diagnosis EXCEPT?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The silhouette sign refers to the loss of normal borders between thoracic structures. It is usually caused by an intrathoracic radiopaque mass that touches the border of the heart or aorta. It is often seen in right middle or lower lobe pneumonia. See Radiopaedia for more information
IncorrectAnswers: Bat s wing shadowing and cardiogenic pulmonary oedema;;Pleural capping and dissecting thoracic aorta;;Air bronchogram and consolidation;;Wedge-shaped shadow and pulmonary embolism

Text:
Mrs. W is a 68 year old female who has been admitted to the Rehabilitation ward following a large cortical stroke. You are the intern on the unit and your consultant asks you to chart the patient up for DVT prophylaxis. Recent blood results for the patient show the following:

FBE: Hb 140, WBC 4.2 x 10^9 (<11 x10^9) 
UEC: Urea 3.4 (2.0-7), Creatinine 72 (<120)

What medication, and what dose should you use as appropriate prophylaxis?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Hospital inpatients are anti coagulated with low-molecular weight heparin medications such as enoxaparin (AKA Clexane). The standard dose for patients with normal renal function (i.e. normal creatinine on UEC) is 40mg daily. If renal function is impaired (i.e. raised creatinine on UEC), the dose is 20mg daily.
IncorrectAnswers: Warfarin with target INR of 2.0 - 3.0 ;;Aspirin 75 mg;;Enoxaparin 20 mg ;;Enoxaparin 30 mg

Text:
You are an intern in Hamilton, where Clementine, a 35 year old herbalist presents to the emergency department, having just given birth to her first child with the help of a dola. 

Clementine is alert and talking to you, however has had significant vaginal bleeding (estimated 1000mL). On inspection there is no obvious tear.  Bloods are sent for cross match and a crystalloid infusion commenced. A urine catheter is inserted, and the midwife performs bimanual compression. You administer 5IU of Oxytocin IM, followed by 40IU via infusion. She continues to bleed. 

What is the most appropriate next step?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Primary PPH: loss of >500mL (vaginal delivery), or loss of >1000mL (C/S), within the first 24h following delivery.  

Management of Primary PPH (RANZCOG) 
1.	DRS ABC
2.	Insertion of wide bore cannula, begin fluids, consider o-neg  
3.	FBE/Coags/Cross Match 
4.	 Treat underlying cause (tone/tissue/trauma/thrombin) 

TONE
-Mechanical (Bimanual uterine compression, empty bladder) 
-Pharmacological (Oxytocin, Ergometrine, Misoprostol, Prostaglandin F2alpha) 
TRAUMA
-Thorough assessment of the entire genital tract is required 
-Pressure should be applied to bleeding areas and repair attempted 

TISSUE
-Through examination 
-Empty bladder
-transfer to theatre

THROMBIN 
-if you re in hamilton, alone, you re screwed  

THEATRE 
-balloon tampanade
-Haemostatic brace suturing 
-bilateral ligation of uterine arteries
-bilateral ligation of internal iliac arteries 
-selective arterial embolisaiton
-hysterectomy

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/SEQPKTceWp4" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Transfer to theatre for uterine artery embolization;;Transfer to theatre for insertion of Bakri Balloon;;Tranexamic acid 1g IV;;Transfer to theatre for examination under anaesthetic

Text:
A 39-week-gestation baby girl, who weighs 3.4 kg, is due for her baby check. She is lying supine. The examiner s left hand is stabilizing the pelvis and his right hand is grasping the left leg, flexed at the hip and knee, with his thumb over the lesser trochanter and the tip of his middle finger over the greater trochanter. He wants first to check whether the right hip is dislocatable with Barlow s manoeuvre. 

Which is the single most accurate description of how the examination should be performed?
CorrectAnswer: Adduct thigh to the midline while applying gentle downward pressure
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Barlow s test and Ortolani s test are used to check for developmental dysplasia of the hip. Barlow s test should be performed first (Barlow s = Back). Hold the thigh in one hand while stabilizing the pelvis with the other. With the leg in the midline, push back gently. If the hip is dislocatable, the femoral head will pop out of the acetabulum. Then perform Ortolani s test (Ortolani s = Out). Holding the leg in the same way, gently and steadily abduct the leg as far as you can, pushing up gently with your fingers on the greater trochanter. If the hip is dislocated, you will feel the femoral head pop back into the acetabulum, or the hip will simply not abduct fully.
IncorrectAnswers: Partially abduct the leg and apply gentle anterior pressure over the greater trochanter;;Fully abduct the leg and apply gentle posterior pressure over the lesser trochanter;;Fully abduct the leg and apply gentle anterior pressure over the greater trochanter;;Adduct the leg to the midline and apply gentle anterior pressure over the greater trochanter

Text:
A 45-year-old doctor presents to their ED with (correctly) self-diagnosed pulmonary oedema. The physician orders an echocardiogram among other tests, and the echo finds that there is hypertrophy of the left atrium, while ejection fraction from the left ventricle into the aorta is relatively normal. 

If this patient has suffered from multiple throat infections with joint pains and fevers as a child, what differential diagnosis may be most likely for them?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: A history of recurrent throat infections with fevers and joint pains suggests rheumatic fever, which often translates into rheumatic heart disease. The most common valve affected by rheumatic heart disease is the mitral valve, followed by the aortic valve. With time, the mitral valve becomes stenosed due to inflammatory changes causing narrowing of the valve opening. This leads to a hypertrophied left atrium (to increase pressure driving blood into the left ventricle), which then leads to a back pressure causing pulmonary oedema. In pure mitral stenosis, ejection fraction will be maintained.
IncorrectAnswers: Mitral regurgitation;;Pneumonia;;Myocardial infarction of the left atrium;;Aortic stenosis

Text:
A 68-year-old male is admitted to Warrnambool Base Hospital for emergency treatment of an incarcerated inguinal hernia. In theatre, he is induced via rapid sequence induction with propofol and suxamethonium. Maintenance anaesthesia is provided by sevoflurane. Soon after the operation begins, the patient is noted to be tachycardic and hypertensive with very high end-tidal CO2. The cardiac monitor shows evidence of frequent ventricular ectopic beats. 

What is the most important treatment intervention that must be initiated for this patient?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The scenario described above details a typical presentation of malignant hyperthermia (MH) - a rare but serious condition caused by a number of drugs used by anaesthetists (e.g. suxamethonium, inhalational anaesthetics such as sevoflurane). The mechanism of MH is thought to be related to uncontrolled calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in skeletal muscle tissue.

Patients with MH typically present first with prolonged muscle spasms, raised end-tidal CO2, tachycardia and arrhythmias. As the condition progresses, hyperthermia, hyperkalaemia, haemodynamic instability and skin mottling can lead to DIC, myoglobinuria, grossly raised CK levels and eventually cardiac arrest. 

Treatment guidelines are complex for malignant hyperthermia, however, dantrolene (an antagonist of the calcium releasing channel/receptor on the sarcoplasmic reticulum) is considered the most important life-saving intervention. While it is important to cease inhalational anaesthetics, give fluid resuscitation, hyperventilate with 100% O2 and initiate TIVA with propofol, dantrolene will ultimately save the patient's life. Insulin, exposure with ice and amiodarone can be utilised to manage the consequences of MH (e.g. hyperkalaemia, hyperthermia and arrhythmia), however these are secondary measures compared to dantrolene.

Malignant Hyperthermia in Australia and New Zealand (MHANZ) guidelines 2012
IncorrectAnswers: Amiodarone;;Full body exposure, cover with ice;;Insulin infusion;;1L bolus Hartmann s solution

Text:
You are counselling a patient who is new to the palliative care program. They are about to be commenced on opioid medication and are concerned about the side effects of these medications. You explain to the patient about the possible side effects and note that all of these side effects decrease with chronic use except one. 

Which one of the following side effects does not abate with chronic opioid use?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Of all the side effects that opioid medications are associated with, constipation is the classic symptom that does not abate with ongoing use. Reference
IncorrectAnswers:
Myoclonus 
;;Respiratory depression ;;Nausea and vomiting;;Hallucinations

Text:
Jimmy, a 12 year old with known epileptic presents to the ED after having several seizures. His dad states that in between seizures he has not fully recovered. Paramedics administered 5mg of Midazolam IM. He continues seizing after arrival. 

What is the initial treatment of choice on arrival to the ED?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Management of status epilepticus: 

IM midazolam (paramedics) 
1.	IV Midazolam on arrival at ED
2.	Check blood sugar, give dextrose if necessay 
3.	Repeat IV midazolam  
4.	IV Phenytoin 
5.	Repeat IV midazolam 
6.	Rapid sequence intubation
IncorrectAnswers: IV Phenytoin with 5% dextrose ;;Rapid sequence intubation  ;;Repeat IM Midazolam;;Oral Phenytoin

Text:
A 78-year-old male with a past history of ischemic heart disease presents to ED complaining of worsening shortness of breath over the last 48 hours. On further questioning, the patient has been utilising several pillows in bed each night, and occasionally wakes up gasping for air. The patient also admits to experiencing periods of palpitations that have been increasing in frequency lately.

You examine the patient, and detect crepitations to the mid-zone of the lungs bilaterally. Based on your clinical findings, you send the patient for a chest x-ray. 

What would the most likely findings on CXR be in this patient?
CorrectAnswer: Diffuse airspace opacification in a  bat-wing  distribution, with an increased cardio-thoracic ratio and horizontal lines arising from the lateral lung margins
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This patient most likely is presenting with acute pulmonary oedema. Chest x-ray findings for pulmonary oedema include:
- Diffuse airspace opacification
- Widening of the cardio-thoracic ratio (i.e. larger heart size)
- Kerley B lines

Blunting of the costophrenic angles bilaterally suggests bilateral pleural effusions, which may also be seen in significant pulmonary oedema. Hyperinflated lungs with flattened diaphragms and reduced lung markings suggests COPD. Opacification confined to the right upper zone, with a sharp border delineating between opaque and lucent at the horizontal fissure is suggestive of right upper lobe pneumonia. Midline shift of the mediastinum towards the right, with a clear region of absent lung markings between the chest wall and lung parenchyma on the left is suggestive of pneumothorax (potentially tension pneumothorax).
IncorrectAnswers: Hyperinflated lungs with flattened diaphragms and reduced lung markings;;Blunting of the costophrenic angles bilaterally;;Midline shift of the mediastinum towards the right, with a clear region of absent lung markings between the chest wall and lung parenchyma on the left;;Opacification confined to the right upper zone, with a sharp border delineating between opaque and lucent at the horizontal fissure

Text:
Jaxon, a 3 week old boy, was born at 38+2 via normal vaginal delivery. His mother has brought him in for review because she is sick of the other mothers in her mother s group saying that Jaxon looks too yellow. 

Which of the following investigations would be LEAST useful in assessing Jaxon?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Breast milk jaundice is common cause of prolonged jaundice. 
Test FBE, TFT and conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin. 

If conjugated bilirubin is high - refer to surgeon for obstructive causes 
TFT - hypothyroidism causes prolonged jaundice 
FBE - look for low grade haemolysis due to ABO incompatibility
IncorrectAnswers: Conjugated bilirubin;;Unconjugated bilirubin;;Full blood examination;;Thyroid function tests

Text:
You are an intern in Portland, on your first night shift when Fabrice, a 92 year old, who is recovering from decompression of a sigmoid volvulus, becomes unresponsive.

Fabrice s airway is patent however he does not appear to be breathing. After 2min of chest compressions a nurse arrives and attaches a defibrillator. Fabrice is in Ventricular Fibrillation, so you shock the patient. He remains in Ventricular Fibrillation.   

What should you do next?
CorrectAnswer: Continue CPR for 2 minutes, re-shock, and then administer 1mg of Adrenaline IV
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
VT: shockable rhythm
Adrenaline 1mg should be administered after second shock and then every second loop.
Amiodarone can be administered after adrenaline- 300mg  

In non-shockable rhythm: Give 1mg of adrenaline immediately then every second loop
IncorrectAnswers: Administer 1mg of Adrenaline IV now ;;Continue CPR for 2 minutes, re-shock, and then administer 300mg of Adrenaline IV ;;Continue CPR for 2 minutes, re-shock, and then administer 1mg of Amiodarone IV;;Administer 300mg of Amiodarone IV now

Text:
Phyllis is woman who is 38 weeks pregnant when she presents to the ED after having had a grand mal seizure. Records indicate she has failed to attend scheduled antenatal care visits. She has a relevant past history of epilepsy for which she currently takes lamotrigine. Prior to her pregnancy her epilepsy was well controlled using sodium valproate.

Her vitals are as follows:
HR: 110bpm regular 
BP: 180/90mmHg 
RR: 20bpm
O2: 99% RA 
Temperature: 37.0 

Following DRSABC  and fluid resuscitation what is the most appropriate initial management?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
There are four main aspects to care of the woman who sustains eclampsia.

1. Resuscitation These seizures are usually self-limiting. Resuscitation requires assuring a patent airway, oxygen by mask and institution of intravenous access. Intravenous diazepam (2mg/min to maximum of 10mg) or clonazepam (1-2mg over 2-5 mins) may be given whilst the magnesium sulphate is being prepared if the seizure is prolonged. 

2. Prevention of further seizures Following appropriate resuscitation, treatment should be commenced with magnesium sulphate given as a 4g loading dose (diluted in normal saline over 15-20 minutes) followed by an infusion of (1-2g/hr, diluted in normal saline). Monitoring should include blood pressure, respiratory rate, urine output, oxygen saturation and deep tendon reflexes. Magnesium sulphate by infusion should continue for 24 hours after the last fit. 

3. Control of hypertension Control of severe hypertension to levels below 160/100 mmHg is essential as the threshold for further seizures is lowered after eclampsia, likely in association with vasogenic brain edema. In addition, the danger of cerebral haemorrhage is real. 

4. Delivery Arrangements for delivery should be decided once the woman s condition is stable. In the meantime, close fetal monitoring should be maintained.
IncorrectAnswers: Immediate delivery via caesarean section ;;Recommence sodium valproate ;;Increase dose of lamotrigine ;;Admission for blood pressure control using labetalol

Text:
Charles, a 28 year old male was found confused and vomiting, and brought into the ED by a good samaritan. Blood tests reveal a Creatinine Kinase of 2000, and urine dipstick is positive for blood and protein. All other results are normal. 

What is the most likely cause?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Rhabdomyolysis; Elevated creatinine kinase- release through breakdown of muscle 
Myoglobin has a half-life of only two to three hours, much shorter than that of CK. Because of its rapid excretion and metabolism to bilirubin, serum levels may return to normal within six to eight hours.
Thus, it is not unusual for CK levels to remain elevated in the absence of myoglobinuria
Both haemoglobin and myoglobin can be detected in the urine as blood- however microscopic evaluation generally shows few red blood cells.
IncorrectAnswers: Pancreatitis;;Pylonephritis;;Urolethiasis;;Severe Dehydration

Text:
A 19-year-old female is brought into ED by her family, she appears confused and drowsy. Her family say that she has been unwell for nearly two weeks, with nausea and vomiting along with insatiable thirst despite frequent urination. Clinically, she appears to have an altered conscious state and is clearly dehydrated with sunken eyes and delayed capillary refill. She is hypotensive, tachycardic, and displaying a pattern of deep and laboured breathing. You suspect this woman is suffering from acute diabetic ketoacidosis, which is confirmed be a finger-prick blood glucose level of 26.1mmol/L, as well as elevated ketones. An arterial blood gas reveals a metabolic acidosis, with a pH of 7.12.

What is the first treatment you should initiate for this woman?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: With an acute presentation of diabetic ketoacidosis, the first considerations for management must always be ABCs. In this case, the woman is displaying signs of haemodynamic instability, with hypotension, tachycardia and dehydration. To avoid hypovolemic shock, a rapid bolus infusion of crystalloid (normal saline) should be given. While fast-acting insulin, potassium (as insulin will drive potassium into cells) and glucose (to prevent reflex hypoglycaemia) will almost certainly be given at some point in the management of this woman, the most important initial step is to resuscitate her with IV fluids. References: BMJ Best Practice, LITFL and NSW Guidelines
IncorrectAnswers: Fast-acting insulin with potassium;;Fast-acting insulin with glucose;;Fast-acting insulin;;2L Normal Saline with added potassium, to be infused over the next 4 hours

Text:
You are asked to perform a mental state examination on Joan who is a new patient to your clinic. Joan has been getting confused lately and has continued to topple over at home. Her past history is long and includes osteoarthritis, ischaemic heart disease and familial essential tremor. You notice when performing the examination that Joan has the tendency to repeat the same phrase over and over again, particularly out of context. 

What is this an example of?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Perseveration is the repetition of a particular response (such as a word, phrase, or gesture) despite the absence or cessation of a stimulus. It is usually caused by a brain injury or other organic disorder. Flight of ideas is a rapid flow of thought, manifested by accelerated speech with abrupt changes from topic to topic, and a symptom of some mental illnesses, especially manic disorder. Derailment is characterised by conversation consisting of a sequence of unrelated or only remotely related ideas. The frame of reference often changes from one sentence to the next. Knights move thinking is a complete loosening of associations where there is no logical link between one idea and the next. Concrete thinking is literal thinking that is focused on the physical world. It is the opposite of abstract thinking. People engaged in concrete thinking are focused on facts in the here and now, physical objects, and literal definitions. Reference: Thought Disorders - Wikipedia
IncorrectAnswers: Concrete thinking;;Knights move thinking;;Derailment;;Flight of ideas

Text:
A 25-year old man presents to his GP with a widespread rash present all over his body. You describe the multiple erythematous lesions as teardrop papules that are smaller than 1cm in diameter, with some covered by a fine scale. He reports that approximately 2 weeks ago he suffered exudative tonsilitis. Apart from mild asthma, he is otherwise fit and well.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Key things to remember for this are:
- 'teardrop papules' = guttate psoriasis
- 2-4 weeks after a strep throat infection = guttate psoriasis

Most cases resolve spontaneously within 2-3 months, and there is no evidence to support the use of antibiotics. However, tonsillectomy may be needed for recurrent episodes, and typical psoriasis treatments can be trialled.

Pityriasis rosea is described as a 'herald patch' - a round red patch with raised borders. This herald patch comes on 1-20 days before the onset of the generalised rash, which are smaller, scaly oval red patches mostly on the back and trunk. This can also follow a sore throat, however it usually comes on a few days following (rather than 2-4 weeks), and it can be a viral URTI rather than a streptococcal infection.

Reference: DermNet
IncorrectAnswers: Chicken pox;;Syphilis;;Discoid Eczema;;Pityriasis rosea

Text: The kidneys are an important regulator of acid-base balance. Which of the following is NOT one of their major functions in regulating acid-base balance?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
On average, the human body produces an excess of acids through metabolic processes each day. The kidneys are the organs responsible for the excretion of these metabolic acids, which is carried out by secretion of H+ ions, as well as employing processes to increase the blood pH using bicarbonate (reabsorption and production of new bicarbonate ions). In states of alkalaemia, the blood pH can be corrected by secretion of bicarbonate, but not by reabsorption of H+.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/FgQiN049jS0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Secretion of H+;;Production of  new  HCO3;;Secretion of HCO3;;Reabsorption of HCO3

Text:
A 59-year-old male presents to ED complaining of a 2-day history of a productive cough with yellow sputum, chest tightness, and fever. His medical history includes diabetes, hypertension and ischemic heart disease, as well as a 30 pack year smoking history. 

On examination, he has a temperature of 38.4°C, BP of 152/94 mmHg, heart rate of 88 bpm, and a respiratory rate of 20. His O2 saturation is 95%. Lung auscultation reveals distant but clear breath sounds, with coarse crackles at the right base. CXR shows a right lower lobe infiltrate.

What is the most likely organism to have caused this condition?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This man is presenting with symptoms of pneumonia (fever, cough, dyspnoea), with a supporting clinical examination and CXR. Given the context of the presentation, this man has community-acquired pneumonia (CAP).

The most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia is Streptococcus pneumoniae.
IncorrectAnswers: Haemophilus influenzae;;Chlamydophila pneumophila;;Klebsiella pneumoniae;;Mycoplasma pneumonia

Text: A baby is born with a congenital condition that causes bicuspid valve (the aortic valve to have 2 cusps). Which is the most immediate consequence this baby is likely to have?
CorrectAnswer: A drop in aortic blood pressure
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Bicuspid aortic valve may occur in several congenital conditions. The condition reduces the aortic valve opening area, thus reducing the amount of blood that can be effectively pumped into the aorta by the left ventricle. As a result, aortic pressure drops. 

This would then go onto stimulate baroreceptors to increase blood pressure via sympathetic stimulation of the heart.
IncorrectAnswers: Increased sympathetic innervation to the heart;;Syncope;;Pulmonary oedema;;Cyanosis

Text:
John is a 20 year old man on the rehab ward who suffered a T1 spinal injury 3 months ago. The nurse on the ward has come over to perform intermittent catheterisation on John and notices that he is sweating profusely and has a red face. 

What other sign is most likely to be associated with this presentation?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This is a presentation of autonomic dysreflexia, an emergency condition that affects patients with spinal cord injuries at or above the level of T6 (the splanchnic outflow). An ascending sensory stimulus triggers widespread reflex activity of the sympathetic nervous system which is uncontrolled due to the isolation of the spinal cord below the level of the injury from the regulatory centres in the brainstem. 

This sympathetic activity results in a sudden increase in blood pressure (acute hypertension, hence A incorrect), with a compensatory vagal bradycardia (B correct answer) occurring due to parasympathetic activation following detection of the hypertension by the baroreceptors in the aorta and carotid bodies. 

Other signs and symptoms associated include a throbbing headache, nasal congestion, blurred vision and piloerection (goosebumps).
IncorrectAnswers: Acute hypotension;;Petechial bleeding;;Atrial fibrillation;;Constricted pupils

Text: Which of the following will occur following a slight constriction of healthy afferent arterioles of the glomeruli of the kidney?
CorrectAnswer: A decrease in renal blood flow resulting in a decrease in glomerular filtration rate
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The afferent arteriole "arrives" at the glomerulus. As a result, constricting this blood vessel will lead to a decrease in blood flow. The rate of filtration at the glomerulus is dependent on the pressure and flow of blood through the glomerular capillaries. As such, reducing the flow of blood reduces glomerular pressure, thus reducing GFR.
IncorrectAnswers:
A decrease in glomerular filtration rate with a stable renal blood flow;;A transient increase in renal flow resulting in an increase in glomerular filtration rate;;A transient increase in renal blood flow resulting in a decrease in glomerular filtration
rate;;A transient increase in glomerular filtration rate despite a decrease in renal blood flow

Text:
You are the intern on the Rehabilitation ward and you are about to clerk a patient that has recently had a below knee amputation on their left side. Before you go and see the patient you are trying to revise your knowledge about amputations, in particular in relation to their aetiology. 

In regards to lower limb amputations, what is the most common aetiology and recent trend in the prevalence of this aetiology?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswer: Dysvascular disease, with increased in prevalence over the last 30 years
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Diseases such as diabetes and atherosclerotic peripheral vascular disease are rising in prevalence with increasing metabolic syndrome rates, leading to more amputations. At the same time, traumatic loss of limb is decreasing.
IncorrectAnswers: Traumatic, with decreased prevalence over the last 30 years;;Dysvascular disease, with stable prevalence over the last 30 years;;Traumatic, with increased prevalence over the last 30 years;;Dysvascular disease, with decrease in prevalence over the last 30 years

Text:
A 25 year old acrobat presents to ED with an unusual feeling in her left arm, 1 week after falling from height with an outstretched left hand and lacerating her arm on some equipment.

On examination, she has healed lacerations over the left forearm, with good vascular perfusion of limb. There is visible extension at MCP joints and marked flexion at the interphalangeal joints of the ring and little finger. Abduction and adduction is weaker in the left hand compared to the right hand. There is no radial of ulnar deviation, and the patient is well systemically. 

Which of the following mechanisms of injury most likely to have caused the presentation?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This lady is presenting with an ulnar nerve lesion as a result of laceration of the nerve at the wrist. This causes the 'ulnar paradox', where the nerve lesion gives a greater deficit in function with injury at the wrist compared to injury at the elbow.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/jsE_pFlGdME" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Supracondylar fracture of the humerus;;Blunt trauma to the forearm;;Delayed compartment syndrome;;Laceration near the elbow

Text:
A 62-year-old lady was admitted for abdominal hysterectomy. The anaesthetist used propofol for induction, sevoflurane for maintenance and suxamethonium for muscle paralysis. Once the procedure was complete, the anaesthetic gases and ventilator were stopped. Her pulse rate began to rise to 100 beats per minute and her blood pressure rose from 90/60 to 160/100. She was visibly sweating. She had made no effort to breathe spontaneously. Nerve function was tested using a peripheral nerve stimulator. There were no twitches. It was concluded that she was still paralysed and she was re-anaesthetised and put back on a ventilator. She was taken to recovery where she was monitored closely. She began to breathe spontaneously and was taken off the ventilator 2 hours later.

Which of the following best explains the mechanism underlying this complication?
CorrectAnswer: Slowed suxamethonium breakdown due to reduced plasma cholinesterase activity as a result of genetic variability or acquired condition, which leads to significant prolongation of the drug's effect
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The case above describes suxamethonium apnoea, a condition where a genetic predisposition or acquired condition leads to impaired metabolism of the drug. As a result, patient's take significantly longer to clear the medication, thus leading to signifiant increases in duration of muscle paralysis.

The other responses describe:
- Malignant hyperthermia (Abnormal response to sevoflurane and/or suxamethonium where the ryanodine receptor on sarcoplasmic reticulum membranes releases excessive calcium)
- Anaphylaxis (Massive mast-cell degranulation in response to previously encountered antigen leads to widespread release of histamine and other inflammatory products of hypersensitivity)
- Local anaesthetic toxicity (Inadvertent blockade of sodium-channels leads to arrhythmias and neurotoxicity)
- Respiratory depression as a side effect of spinal opioid injection (Anaesthetic agent travels too high, leading to inadvertent blockage of autonomic neurons, leading to respiratory depression)
IncorrectAnswers: Anaesthetic agent travels too high, leading to inadvertent blockage of autonomic neurons, leading to respiratory depression;;Abnormal response to sevoflurane and/or suxamethonium where the ryanodine receptor on sarcoplasmic reticulum membranes releases excessive calcium;;Massive mast-cell degranulation in response to previously encountered antigen leads to widespread release of histamine and other inflammatory products of hypersensitivity;;Inadvertent blockade of sodium-channels leads to arrhythmias and neurotoxicity

Text:
John is a 72-year-old smoker with a diagnosis of COPD who complains of worsening shortness of breath over the last several months. Previously, he was only breathless on moderate-intensity exercise, but now he feels out of breath even when walking normally on flat ground.

His current COPD management is salbutamol MDI as reliever medication.

Which of the following interventions would be most beneficial in improving John s function?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Smoking cessation is by far the most important strategy for improving function and mortality in patients with COPD. While other measures such as introducing combination inhaled medications, the most important measure will always be smoking cessation.
IncorrectAnswers: Provide John with roxithromycin and prednisolone for use in infective exacerbations;;Pneumococcal vaccine and influenza vaccine to prevent infective exacerbations;;Pulmonary rehabilitation;;Introduce Symbicort (budesonide/eformoterol) as a regular inhaled medication

Text: Which of the following is true of papillary muscles of the heart?
CorrectAnswer: Their primary purpose is to help prevent retrograde flow of blood
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The papillary muscles are attached to the ventricular myocardium and chordae tendinae. Their primary function is the prevent the atrioventricular valves (i.e. mitral and tricuspid valves) from everting and thus leading to regurgitation through the valve.

There are no papillary muscles associated with the semilunar valves (i.e. aortic and pulmonary valves).

The papillary muscles are only found in the left and right ventricles, NOT the atria. They are comprised of cardiac muscle tissue.
IncorrectAnswers: They are not true muscles in that they are comprised of connective tissue;;They are features of the inside wall of the atria;;They are attached to the myocardium of only the left ventricle;;They are attached to chordae tendinae of the aortic and pulmonary valves

Text:
Jannet, a 55yo janitor presents to the gynaecology outpatients clinic complaining of vaginal itch. On examination you notice a single small ulcer on the labia majora. Biopsy reveals invasive carcinoma. 

What is the most likely underlying pathology of the lesion?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of cancer seen on the labia majora.
IncorrectAnswers: Bartholin s gland carcinoma ;;Melanoma;;Paget s Disease  ;;Basal cell carcinoma

Text:
An 18 month old boy is bought into ED by ambulance following a witnessed  convulsion  at home which self-terminated. On examination, the patient is noted to be febrile at 38.9.

Which of the following findings, if present, would suggest this patient did NOT suffer a simple febrile convulsion?
CorrectAnswer: The patient had a past history of afebrile seizures
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Febrile Convulsions
=convulsions in child b/w 6mth and 6yrs of age in setting of acute febrile illness WITHOUT
ð  previous afebrile seizures
ð  significant prior neurological abnormality
ð  CNS infection

Complex needs one or more of the following:
- focal features at onset or during the seizure 
- Duration of more than 15 minutes 
- Recurrence within the same febrile illness 
- Incomplete recovery within 1 hour.

Risk of recurrence   depends on age of child   the younger the greater the risk
ð  1yr=50%
ð  2yr=30%
ð  Overall about 1/3rd will experience another
Risk of epilepsy
ð  Determined by risk factors (e.g. Fhx of epilepsy, any neurodevelopmental
problem, atypical/complex febrile convulsion)
ð  1 risk factor = 2%; >1 risk factor = 10%
IncorrectAnswers: There was no developmental delay noted before or after seizure;;There was no recurrence of the seizure within the same febrile illness;;Patient had generalised tonic-clonic seizure lasting 12 mins;;The patient was lethargic, had decreased consciousness and neurological symptoms for 20 minutes following the seizure

Text: Which anatomical structure is superior to the pituitary gland?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The diaphragm sellae is composed of dura mater and separates the pituitary gland from the optic chiasm. There is an opening in the middle to allow the infundibulum to pass through.
IncorrectAnswers: Sphenoid sinus;;Intercavernous dural sinus;;Sella turcica;;Cavernous dural sinus

Text: Which of the following characteristics are true of Purkinje fibres in the heart?
CorrectAnswer: Purkinje fibres  depolarisation involves opening of fast Na+ channels that are not present in pacemaker cardiomyocytes
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The Purkinje fibres branch from the bundle branches that run in the interventricular septum. The Purkinje fibres are unique in that they depolarise using Na+ channels that are not seen in other pacemaker cells in the heart.
IncorrectAnswers: The membrane potential slowly drifts towards the threshold of -40mV at which an action potential occurs;;The opening of long acting Ca2+ channels results in efflux of calcium;;Purkinje fibres have no pacemaker activity in any cardiovascular pathology;;Purkinje fibres have a relatively slow depolarisation upstroke when compared to that of pacemaker cardiomyocytes

Text:
Doris, a 86yo presents to your clinic complaining of a heavy, dragging sensation in her  nether regions . You take a brief history in which Doris tells you that she occasionally experiences urinary incontinence when she coughs or laughs. She has had 7 uncomplicated vaginal deliveries. 
 
What is the most likely cause of Doris  issues?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Cystocele occurs when the front of the vaginal wall weakens, allowing the bladder to herniate into the vagina. This condition changes the angle of the urethra (tube that carries urine from the body) and often results in stress incontinence. When a cystocele occurs, the urethra also may prolapse into the vagina (called urethrocele). When prolapse of both the bladder and the urethra occurs, the condition is called cystourethrocele.

Enterocele is a condition that occurs when the front and back vaginal walls separate, allowing the small bowel to press against or herniate into the vagina. This condition is more common following removal of the uterus (hysterectomy).

Rectocele, which also may be called proctocele, occurs when the back of the vaginal wall weakens and the rectum presses against or prolapses into the vagina. This condition may create a bulge that is more noticeable during a bowel movement.

Uterine prolapse: Weakening of the ligaments that support the top of the vagina (uterosacral ligaments) may cause the front and back of the vaginal walls to weaken as well, resulting in prolapse of the uterus
IncorrectAnswers: Enterocele;;Uterine prolapse;;Vault prolapse;;Rectocele

Text: The anatomy of the cubital fossa does not involve which of the following structures?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The triangle-shaped cubital fossa is bordered inferiorly by the brachioradialis (laterally) and the pronator teres (medially). Passing through the cubital fossa is the brachial artery and median nerve. The ulnar nerve passes medially in the elbow, around the medial epicondyle of the humerus. Reference: Teach Me Anatomy - Cubital Fossa
IncorrectAnswers: Brachioradialis;;Brachial artery;;Median nerve;;Pronator teres

Text:
A 63 year old gentleman with metastatic prostate cancer presents with worsening pain. He currently takes MR morphine 60 mg BD orally. Due to his recent vomiting it is decided to change how this medication should be administered. 

What would be the most appropriate way to administer this medication?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswer: Subcutaneous through a syringe driver 40 mg
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Syringe drivers (continuous subcutaneous infusions) are preferred in palliative care as second line to the oral route as they offer reliable pharmacokinetics and ease of medication delivery. In comparison, IM injections and PR suppositories are less reliable, and not as well tolerated in patients.
IncorrectAnswers: PR 40 mg QID;;Subcutaneous through a syringe driver 60 mg ;;Continue 60 mg BD PO and provide him with an appropriate antiemetic medication ;;Intramuscular injections into the deltoid 60 mg BD

Text: Which of the following is not a scapulo-humeral muscle (fibres from scapula to humerus)?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The pectoralis minor muscle originates from the 2nd, 3rd and 4th ribs, and inserts onto the coracoid process of the scapula. It has no attachment to the humerus (unlike pectoralis major). Reference: TeachMeAnatomy - Pectoral Muscles
IncorrectAnswers: Teres minor;;Deltoid;;Subscapularis;;Teres major

Text:
A 22 year old woman presents to ED with an acutely painful and red right eye with associated blurred vision and photophobia. You examine the patient s eye using a slit lamp with fluorescein and topical anaesthetic drops (see image). 

What is the diagnosis and initial management?
CorrectAnswer: Dendritic Ulcer (HSV) = Swab for PCR + oral acyclovir
CorrectAnswerExplanation: This is a dendritic ulcer (branching pattern of ulcer is suggestive) that requires anti-viral treatment (acyclovir). Reference: Medscape
IncorrectAnswers: Dendritic Ulcer (HSV) = Irrigation + oral antibiotics + referral;;Chalazion = conservative Mx with heat pack + reassurance;;Foreign Body = lid retraction + irrigation + referral to ophthalmology;;Viral Conjunctivitis = analgesic eye drops + reassurance

Text:
Jenny is a 44-year-old female with a history of migraines. She presents requesting stronger medications to treat migraines, as they are becoming so unbearable and uncontrolled on her current medications. She uses naproxen and paracetamol as relief for migraines currently. 

Despite occasional symptoms of asthma in the colder months (relieved by salbutamol), Jenny has no other medical conditions or documented allergies.

What would the most appropriate medication to treat migraine headaches in Jenny?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
First line treatment for migraines is with paracetamol or an NSAID. If these medications fail to adequately treat the symptoms of migraine, then the next option is a 'triptan' medication, such as sumatriptan.

Medications may also be prescribed for prevention of migraines in individuals with a high frequency, including propranolol, topiramate and amitriptyline. Metoclopramide may be used for anti-nausea during a migraine.
IncorrectAnswers: Amitriptyline;;Metoclopramide;;Pregabalin;;Propranolol

Text:
A 25-year old man presents to his GP with a 2-week history of a pruritic skin rash. This has not improved with emolient cream, and is now disturbing his sleep. On examination you notice a combination of papules and vesicles on the extensor aspects of his knees and elbows, as well as on his buttocks.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Dermatitis herpetiformis is an autoimmune condition associated with coeliac disease. It is caused by deposition of IgA in the dermis layer.

Characteristically, it causes a blistering, vesicular, itchy skin rash on the extensor surfaces of the upper and lower limbs.

Treatment is with Dapsone (an antibiotic) and a gluten-free diet.
IncorrectAnswers: Eczema;;Scabies;;Lichen planus;;Acne

Text:
Freida, a 15 year old female, skips her geology class to visit you at your GP clinic to ask for contraceptive advice. After discussing the importance of geology, you take a detailed history and give advice regarding safe sex. Her only relevant medical history includes a diagnosis of epilepsy, which is treated with sodium valproate. Additionally, she occasionally suffers from migraines which are preceded by a tingling sensation. She has no family history of thromboembolic conditions. She takes no other medications or herbal supplements. Her BHCG is negative. 
 
Which of the following methods of contraception is contraindicated?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Contraindications of Various Contraceptives

Combined hormonal contraceptives (CHC):
Acute flare of hepatitis   do not start CHC.
Breastfeeding d 6 weeks post-partum.

Text: A patient is treated at the ED for a superficial laceration to the chest sustained 15 minutes ago, but not before losing a moderate amount of blood. Which of the following mechanisms is likely to have occurred at the point of treatment?
CorrectAnswer: The arterial baroreceptors have decreased firing in response to a decreased stretch in the aortic arch and carotid artery, resulting in increased sympathetic stimulation to the heart to increase heart rate and contractility to maintain blood pressure
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Blood pressure is a parameter controlled very carefully by the body, utilising both short term and long term systems to maintain a homeostatic pressure level. The short term (i.e. seconds to minutes) regulation of blood pressure is carried out by the autonomic nervous system. In this scenario, a loss of blood would decrease MAP, which decreases the stretch in baroreceptors located in the carotid bodies and aortic arch. This feeds back a signal to increase sympathetic stimulation to the heart and systemic vasculature to increase contractility, heart rate and vascular resistance, all of which leads to increase in MAP.
IncorrectAnswers: The kidneys have detected a decrease in renal perfusion and have subsequently increased renin production, significantly increasing sodium reabsorption;;Peripheral chemoreceptors in the aortic arch and carotid body increase firing as blood pressure decreases, increasing sympathetic innervation to the heart to increase heart rate and contractility;;Endothelin released from the damage VSMC has caused systemic vasoconstriction to maintain blood pressure;;The heart has sensed a decrease in ventricular pressure and has decreased production of ANP and BNP to promote water retention

Text:
A 23 year old women presents to ED feeling light headed. She reports having crampy abdominal pain that started yesterday and has recently gotten worse with associated with shoulder tip pain and diaphoresis. She states she has just got her period, and had a normal amount of p/v bleeding for day 1. Her LMP was 7 weeks ago, her periods are usually irregular, she is sexually active in a long term heterosexual relationship and is not on any hormonal contraceptive. Her last meal was yesterday lunch time. She has no allergies. 

On examination she is afebrile 36.8!, HR= 115, BP= 105/65mmHg, RR = 15, O2 Sats 99% on room air. She is tender in the RIF, with some guarding but there is no rebound tenderness. 

What investigation(s) will most likely lead to the definitive diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This patient presents with a potential ectopic pregnancy. 

Whilst this patients period s are usually irregular, you cannot assume the p/v bleeding and crampy abdominal pain is a normal period. 

Her vital signs indicate she is hemodynamically compromised, and the shoulder tip pain indicates there is blood in the abdominal cavity causing irritation and peritonism. 

While a urine beta HCG would be an appropriate initial investigation, it will always be followed up by serum beta HCG and ultrasound in a case of suspected ectopic pregnancy. Laparotomy would be a treatment option, not an investigation.
IncorrectAnswers: Urine beta HCG +  ultrasound;;Urine beta HCG;;Laparotomy;;Serum beta HCG

Text:
A 13-month old child is brought into ED by her mother, who has noticed a 24-hour history of increased work of breathing, lethargy, and coryzal symptoms. On examination you discover subcostal recession and fine inspiratory crackles. Her oxygen saturations are 92% on room air. 

What is the next most appropriate course of action?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: This child most likely has bronchiolitis - which is a common LRTI caused by RSV. It is a self-limiting condition, however it is important to know that some children can deteriorate in the first 72 hours. This is why admission for observations is appropriate. Admission is usually recommended if: - Apnoea - Persistent O2 sats of <92% - <50% of usual oral intake - Persisting severe respiratory distress (grunting, recession, RR >70) Humidified oxygen may be used if necessary. Fluids may need to be given via an NGT or IV line if child isn't feeding properly. Steroids and antibiotics are NOT helpful. Reference: RCH Clinical Practice Guidelines
IncorrectAnswers: Admit to hospital for a full septic screen;;Admit to hospital for IV antibiotics;;Call a MET call;;Discharge home as this is a self-limiting process

Text:
Steve is brought in to the emergency department by his disgruntled wife who states that her husband  looks more carrot than human , referring to the orange discolouration of his skin. With a thorough history and examination you discover that unfortunately, Steve has obstructive jaundice. 

What are you likely to find upon examination of a stool sample and urine dipstick?
CorrectAnswer: Urine: Urobilinogen not present. Stools: pale
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Bilirubin is produced through the breakdown of haemoglobin. It circulates as unconjugated bilirubin until it reaches the liver where it is conjugated and excreted through the common bile duct into the small intestine. In the small intestine it is converted to urobilinogen and stercobilinogen. Urobilinogen is then reabsorbed into the bloodstream and transported to the kidney for renal excretion. Stercobilinogen is what gives feces their brown colour.
IncorrectAnswers: Urine: Urobilinogen present. Stools: pale ;;Urine: Urobilinogen not present. Stools: normal ;;Urine: Urobilinogen present. Stools: normal;;Steve is, in fact, a carrot

Text:
A 56-year-old man is admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of sepsis on a background of pneumonia. He is treated with oxygen, IV antibiotics and fluid challenges to a total volume of 4.5L normal saline. Currently, his pulse is 124 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 75/45mmHg (mean arterial pressure 55mmHg) and his respiratory rate is 26 breaths per minute. Oxygen saturation measured via pulse oximetry is 91% on 50% oxygen via non-rebreather mask. His CVP is 12mmHg (normal is 3-8mmHg). His arterial blood gas shows a mild metabolic acidosis with a chloride of 112mmol/L (normal is 95-105), and a haemoglobin concentration of 83g/L.

What is the next step in optimising his cardiovascular function?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: This patient can be clinically diagnosed with septic shock given a history of infection and very low blood pressure. Although his volume status has been resuscitated to an adequate level (given raised CVP), his MAP has not reached a satisfactory level (generally accepted to be 65mmHg). According to the 2016 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines, the next step for management of septic shock in this patient would be commencement of a vasopressor infusion, for which noradrenaline is the first line drug of choice. While the surviving sepsis guidelines support use of packed red cells in anaemic patients, this should occur only once patients are haemodynamically stable.
