Dobutamine is a beta-adrenoceptor agonist (primarily beta-1, but has some beta-2 activity) used more in cases of cardiogenic shock, and is not recommended as initial therapy in septic shock. Similarly, albumin can be used in patients with hypoalbuminaemia, but is not considered standard protocol for initial resuscitation. The patient in this question has developed a hyperchloraemic metabolic acidosis, likely due to significant resuscitation with normal saline. While it would be prudent to alternate to a balanced salt solution such as Hartmann's, this will not directly address optimisation of cardiovascular function. Surviving Sepsis Campaign: International Guidelines for Management of Sepsis and Septic Shock: 2016 See also: Initial Sepsis Management
IncorrectAnswers: Transfuse packed red cells to a haematocrit of >30%;;Switch to a balanced salt solution (e.g. Hartmann's) and continue fluid resuscitation;;Dobutamine infusion;;Albumin bolus

Text:
A 38-year-old female requires an emergency C-section. She is brought to the anaesthetic bay, and the decision is made that a spinal block would be the most appropriate form of anaesthesia for this patient. The anaesthetist draws up the relevant medications (bupivacaine + fentanyl), and injects local anaesthetic to numb the site of spinal injection. 

The anaesthetist locates the L3/L4 interspace, and is able to confirm placement of the needle in the intrathecal space by visualisation of CSF flow. The spinal block is administered, and level of anaesthesia is checked with an ice block.

Which of the following is NOT a contraindication to spinal anaesthesia?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Spinal anaesthesia has a number of absolute contraindications. Infection over the injection site (e.g. cellulitis) may lead to introduction of pathogens into the CSF/CNS, while bleeding disorders (e.g. low platelets, use of warfarin) may lead to the formation of an epidural haematoma and compression of the caudal equina (leading to cauda equina syndrome and potentially paraplegia). Injection into the intrathecal space with raised ICP may lead to herniation of cerebral contents through the foramen magnum.
IncorrectAnswers: Cellulitis over site of injection;;Raised intracranial pressure;;Therapeutic use of warfarin;;Thrombocytopenia

Text: The macula densa is located in which portion of the nephron?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The macula densa is an area of closely packed specialized cells lining the wall of the nephron at the transition to the distal convoluted tubule.

The cells of the macula densa are sensitive to the concentration of sodium chloride in the distal convoluted tubule. A decrease in sodium chloride concentration initiates a signal from the macula densa that has two effects: 
(1) it decreases resistance to blood flow in the afferent arterioles, which raises glomerular hydrostatic pressure and helps return GFR toward normal, and 
(2) it increases renin release from the juxtaglomerular cells of the afferent and efferent arterioles, which are the major storage sites for renin.
IncorrectAnswers: Collecting duct;;Thin ascending Loop of Henle;;Thick ascending Loop of Henle;;Proximal convoluted tubule

Text:
A 60-year old man presents to his doctor with a new left varicocele, visible haematuria and general malaise for the past 3 weeks. He has an ache-like pain in his left loin, but otherwise examination only reveals a left-sided varicocele.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC) presents (in MCQs) with a classic triad: haematuria, loin pain, abdominal mass. An acute LEFT varicocele is a common presentation, and this happens when the RCC grows and occludes where the left testicular vein drains into the left renal vein. This causes engorgement of the left pampiniform plexus.

Be aware of other potential presentations of RCC, which can be due to endocrine effects (secretion of EPO leading to polycythaemia, secretion of PTH leading to hypercalcaemia, and secretion of renin and ACTH).
IncorrectAnswers: Pyelonephritis;;Urinary Tract Infection (UTI);;Nephrolithiasis;;Vesico-ureteric reflux (VUR)

Text: Which of the following is FALSE regarding Na+ handling along the nephron?
CorrectAnswer: Sodium is predominantly reabsorbed by the Na+/K+/Cl- symporter in the early proximal convoluted tubule
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Most (~65%) of the sodium reabsorption in the kidney occurs in the proximal tubule. In the latter part it is favoured by an electrochemical driving force, but initially it needs the cotransporter SGLT and the Na-H antiporter.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/19p97ju1xLw?ecver=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Not a lot of sodium is reabsorbed in the descending LOH as it is required to help set up the counter-current exchange model;;Over 99% of the Na+ filtered in the nephron is reabsorbed;;Sodium reabsorption is increased in the presence of aldosterone;;The majority of sodium is reabsorbed at the proximal tubule

Text:
A 55-year old man with a history of gallstone disease presents to Colac Hospital with a 2-day history of pain in the right upper quadrant. He feels like he 'has the flu' and his wife reports that he has had a fever for the past day. On examination his temperature os 38.1, BP 100/60, HR 102/min, and he is tender in the RUQ. His sclera have a yellow tinge. 

What is the most likely diagnosis.
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Charcot's Triad = RUQ pain + fever + jaundice = ascending cholangitis. 

Bacterial infection secondary to biliary obstruction (usually a stone but also CBD stenosis and malignancy).

Biliary Colic = contraction of gallbladder against a stone pressing against GB outlet (RUQ pain +/- fever).

Cholecystitis = inflammation of GB (RUQ pain + fever + increased WCC).
IncorrectAnswers: Biliary colic;;Acute viral hepatitis;;Pancreatic cancer;;Acute cholecystitis

Text: Which of the following is true of the elbow joint?
CorrectAnswer: The capitulum of the humerus articulates with the head of the radius
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
In the elbow joint, there are a number of articulating surfaces between the humerus with the radius and ulna. The circular head of the radius articulates with the capitulum of the humerus.

The trochlea is the articulating surface of the humerus (not the ulna) that articulates with the ulna. The humerus accommodates the olecranon in the olecranon fossa during full extension. The annular ligament holds the head of the radius (not the ulna) against the ulna to allow for pronation and supination at the proximal radio-ulnar joint. The carrying angle (the angle formed between the arm and forearm) is normally greater in women, not men.
IncorrectAnswers: The carrying angle is normally greater in men than in women;;The humerus has the olecranon fossa which accommodates the olecranon during full flexion;;The trochlea of the ulna articulates with the humerus;;The annular ligament holds the head of the ulna to allow for pronation and supination

Text:
A 9 year old boy has been brought to the emergency department with redness and swelling around his right eye that has been present for 1 day. He had visited his general practitioner 3 days ago complaining of a frontal headache which was thought to be viral sinusitis. His right eyelid is now red, tender and swollen. It will not open fully and there is evidence of proptosis. Assessing eye movement is difficult due to pain but there is evidence of ophthalmoplegia. His temperature is 37.8.

Which of the following is the best next step in management?
CorrectAnswer: Take blood cultures, perform a CT scan of the sinuses and orbits and commence empirical IV flucloxacillin and cefotaxime
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Orbital Cellulitis (infection involving orbital tissue) = surgical emergency. Urgent consult with opthamology

Key symptoms to differentiate from periorbital cellulitis (infection soft tissue layer of superficial eyelid):
1. Pain with eye movement Ophthalmoplegia
2. Proptosis (may be subtle)
3. +/- vision impairment , chemosis
IncorrectAnswers: Perform thyroid function tests and consult an endocrinologist;;Take blood cultures and commence oral Amoxycillin/Clavulanate (Augmentin);;Take blood cultures, perform a lumbar puncture and commence empirical IV flucloxacillin and cefotaxime;;Give IM adrenaline and attempt to identify a cause of anaphylaxis

Text: Arteries, veins and capillaries differ in a variety of ways. Which of the following is characteristic of veins?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Veins are the only vasculature system in the body (other than lymphatics) with one-way valves. Their function is to prevent blood from pooling in the peripheries, which would otherwise be more likely to occur due to the low pressure driving blood forward in the venous circulation.

Arteries have the thicker media, and contain supplying blood vessels to larger arteries (vasa vasorum). Arteries also have significant stretch-capacity, making them the 'pressure reservoir' of the circulatory system.
IncorrectAnswers: Vaso vasorum;;Highly branching, large surface area;;A thicker media (particularly elastin) than most arteries;;Function as the  pressure reservoir

Text: Which of the following cranial nerve has no involvement with the eye?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The eye is a complex structure that requires input from multiple different cranial nerves to function. Cranial nerves III, IV and VI are all involved with the movements of the eyeball, while cranial nerve II (the optic nerve) is responsible for vision. Cranial nerve V is the trigeminal nerve, which innervates the sensory aspects of the eye, while cranial nerve VII (facial nerve) is involved with movements of the eyelids. 

Cranial nerve I is the olfactory nerve, and is involved with smell only.
IncorrectAnswers: CN IV;;CN V;;CN II;;CN III

Text:
A 40 year old women presents to the ED with a 4-hour history of right upper abdominal pain and fever. She tells you that she has previously been investigated for abdominal pain and was found to have gallstones. She says that she has never felt this unwell with the pain before. On examination, she is markedly jaundiced with a temperature of 39 and pulse rate of 130/min. There is localised peritonism in the right upper abdomen 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The differential diagnosis for RUQ pain includes a number of biliary pathologies, especially in the context of previously diagnosed gallstone disease. This patient appears to have been diagnosed with gallstones in the past, which predisposes her to a greater risk of biliary disease in the future. The presence of fever and jaundice indicate there is both infection and obstruction of bile flow. The condition in this context that causes this problem is ascending cholangitis, where infection begins after a stone from the gallbladder becomes lodged in the common bile duct.

( Biliary colic is the pain associated with ingestion of fatty foods, and is likely related to temporary obstruction of the cystic duct. When there is inflammation of the gallbladder (generally due to obstruction by a stone lodged in the cystic duct), this is termed cholecystitis. Because there is no obstruction to the common bile duct, there will be no jaundice. ( Gallstone ileum occurs with chronic inflammation of the gallbladder, leading to a fistula forming between the small bowel and the gallbladder. Large stones can then pass into the bowel, causing an obstruction.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/TuHskzj25X0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Gallstone ileus ;;Biliary colic;;Carcinoma of the gallbladder;;Acute cholecystitis

Text:
You are the intern on the Rehabilitation ward currently looking after a patient admitted with Traumatic Brain Injury following a motor vehicle accident. After the incident they were in a coma for 3 weeks and they have unfortunately developed a complication which your consultant tells you leads to restricted movement and often pain. 

According to the clinical information, and the accompanying X Ray, what is the most likely diagnosis?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Heterotrophic ossification (HO) is seen in patients post-TBI and SCI, as well as musculoskeletal injury. It is defined as the presence of bone in soft tissue where bone normally does not exist. In the X ray, HO can be seen posterior to the elbow joint. Patients suffering from HO give a history of swelling and stiffness. Reference: Radiopaedia.
IncorrectAnswers: Septic arthritis;;Osteochondritis dissecans;;Myositis ossification;;Traumatic fracture of the radial head

Text:
Henrietta is a 68 year old who presents to the gynaecology outpatients reporting irregular vaginal bleeding. Her last normal menstrual period was 18 years ago. All previous pap smear results have been normal.

Which of the following comprises the most appropriate investigations?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Investigation of post menopausal bleeding:
Need to rule out endometrial cancer- best way to do this is assess endometrial thickness with trans-vaginal ultrasound followed by hysteroscopy.
IncorrectAnswers: Pap Smear + Trans Vaginal Ultrasound;;Pap smear + HPV testing;;Exploratory Laparoscopy;;Pap Smear + Colposcopy

Text:
A 62-year old female is being evaluated after she had an episode of syncope. She complained of having progressive exertional dyspnoea over the last 2 months, with an occasional dry cough. Cardiac auscultation finds a holosystolic murmur. 

Which of the following best described the physical findings in this patient?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The combination of holosystolic murmur + exertional dyspnoea + dry cough should make you think of mitral regurgitation. A combination of decreased cardiac output and increased LA pressure contributes to symptoms. The dry cough may relate to pulmonary congestion and oedema, which is an indicator of more severe disease that has resulted in left ventricular dysfunction. The classical holosystolic murmur is best heart over the apex with radiation to the axilla. 

Ascending aortic aneurysm can be associated with aortic regurgitation, which would cause a diastolic murmur.

Although patients with constrictive pericarditis often present with exertional dyspnoea, physical findings such as elevated JVP, pulsatile hepatomegaly and signs of fluid overload are often present as well. 

Tricuspid stenosis would cause a diastolic murmur. The most common cause is rheumatic heart disease.

Mitral stenosis is associated with a diastolic murmur, not a systolic murmur.
IncorrectAnswers: Aortic stenosis;;Ascending aortic aneurysm;;Tricuspid stenosis;;Constrictive pericarditis

Text:
Frederic, a 77 year old male presents to the ED complaining of terrible abdominal pain. His past medical history is unremarkable. On examination he has generalised abdominal tenderness.
 
His vitals are as follows: 
HR: 130bpm
RR: 22bpm
BP: 80/50mmHg
T: 37.5
O2: 98% on room air 

What is the most appropriate initial management?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: This man is clearly hypotensive (with tachycardia), which could be due to a number of causes such as sepsis and dehydration. Before investigating the cause of the hypotension, the patient's haemodynamic state must be addressed. In this case, rapid infusion of large quantities of crystalloid fluid would be the most appropriate first step in treating the patient.
IncorrectAnswers: Immediate transfer to theatre;;Administration of appropriate analgesia;;Urgent CT abdomen;;Abdominal Xray

Text:
A 48 year old man is BIBA with acute back pain following an accident at work. He has central back pain in the L4-5 area with shooting pain down both legs. His pain is excruciating an preventing him from walking. He has no history of back pain, is on no regular medications and is fit and well. You conduct an examination, noting his pants are wet. 

What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: This scenario depicts cauda equina syndrome. The mnemonic SPINE (saddle anaesthesia, pain, incontinence, numbness, emergency) is worthwhile knowing. This requires urgent neurosurgery consultation, as paralysis and ongoing neuraxial impairment may result if not treated rapidly. Reference: MedScape
IncorrectAnswers: Oxybutynin for urinary incontinence;;Non-urgent MRI and referral to physiotherapist;;Naproxen;;IV hydrocortisone

Text:
A 78-year-old male with chronic kidney disease presents to ED with muscle weakness. The intern in ED suspects this may be a case of hyperkalaemia secondary to poor renal function, so she orders an urgent UEC and ECG. The potassium comes back as 7.2 (N = 3.5   5), and the ECG confirms the diagnosis of hyperkalaemia.  

Which of the following features is not suggestive of hyperkalaemia on ECG?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The signs of hyperkalaemia (excessive potassium) on ECG are: - Peaked T waves (usually the earliest sign of hyperkalaemia) - P wave widens and flattens, and eventually disappears - PR segment lengthens - Prolonged QRS interval with bizarre QRS morphology - AV block and bundle branch block - Sinus bradycardia or slow AF - Development of a sine wave appearance (a pre-terminal rhythm) Terminal hyperkalaemia will result in PEA, VF and asystole. Reference: LITFL - Hyperkalaemia
IncorrectAnswers: Bundle branch block;;Peaked T waves;;P wave flattening;;Prolonged PR interval

Text:
Janet, a 47yo librarian presents to the ED with chest pain, palpitations, and a sensation of tingling in her hands. An ECG reveals the following (see below ECG).

What is the most likely underlying cause of her presentation?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
ECG shows hyperkalemia: peaked T waves, shortened QT interval, ST segment depression.
Two most common causes of hyperkalemia are AKI and CKD. 
Other causes include addisonian crisis, rhabdomyolysis, ACE inhibitors, destruction of red blood cells due to severe injury or burns.
IncorrectAnswers: Pulmonary embolism;;Pericarditis;;Diabetic ketoacidosis;;Acute coronary syndrome

Text:
Cecilia, a 68 year old female who has recently begun dating after her fourth divorce, presents to your GP clinic complaining of a cottage cheese like vaginal discharge. She has had three previous normal vaginal deliveries and her pap smears are up to date. She has had no previous STIs. She also has Crohns disease, for which she takes oral steroids.
  
Given the most likely diagnosis, what is the most appropriate treatment?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Most likely diagnosis candida albicans (cottage cheese like discharge)- not an STI. 
Risk factors for candida include immunosuppression (steroid use), recent antibiotic use, or increased oestrogen levels (pregnancy/OCP).
Tx: Fluconazole 150mg PO single dose 

Other answers:
Bacterial vagniosis: metronidazole 
Chlamydia: Azithromycin 
HSV: Aciclovir 
Syph: Ben Pen
IncorrectAnswers: Metronidazole 500mg PO DB (7 days);;Acyclovir 200mg PO five times daily (5 days);;Benzathine penicillin G 2.4 million units IM single dose;;Azithromycin 1g PO single dose

Text:
A 5-year-old boy presents to his GP with a 3-day history of puffy eyes. He has been unwell with a coryzal illness for the last week. His mother states he has had no new medications and no hayfever, allergies or asthma. On further examination he has generalized oedema and scrotal oedema. He is tachycardiac and has cool peripheries, no skin rashes or erythema. 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Nephrotic syndrome (triad of proteinuria, hypoalbuminaemia and generalized oedema) 

The examination findings of generalized oedema make periorbital cellulitis (in the absence of a fever) and allergic reaction (in the absence of skin rash, wheals, flares) unlikely. 

Additionally has hypovolaemia, due to increased interstitial fluid collection due to reduced oncotic pressure. 

Rarely, C1 esterase deficiency can present with generalized oedema following an intercurrent illness. However it is not the most likely in this case.

IgA nephropathy = haematuria. Usually presents days after infection which fits in this case. As appose to Post-strep glomerulonephritis which occurs weeks after illness.
IncorrectAnswers: Allergic reaction;;Periorbital cellulitis with hypovolaemia;;C1 esterase deficiency;;IgA nephropathy with hypovolaemia

Text:
Jeff, a 57-year-old man with a long history of hepatitis C, presents with a complaint of a bloated and tender abdomen, fever, vomiting, and blood in his stool. He has presented numerous times previously with abdominal distention and has undergone drainage of ascitic fluid, which have improved the symptoms.

A set of vitals is taken, which show that Jeff is haemodynamically stable but slightly febrile. The nurse notes that Jeff also appears generally confused.

What is the most likely cause of Jeff s symptoms?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) occurs when patients with cirrhosis and portal hypertension develop bacterial infection of ascites fluid. This occurs due to several reasons:
1. Overgrowth of gut flora due to PPI use and altered small bowel motility in those with liver cirrhosis
2. Increased bowel permeability, which leads to bacterial translocation into the lymphatic system of those with cirrhotic livers
3. Acquired immune deficiency as a result of reduced PMN function and reduced serum complement, secondary to liver cirrhosis

SBP presents with fever, abdominal tenderness and distension, vomiting, altered mental status and occasionally GI bleed (secondary to poor liver synthesis of coagulation factors). It is treated with antibiotics and albumin infusion to prevent hepatorenal syndrome.

Malignant ascites is seen in patients with peritoneal malignancies that leads to the formation of ascites via increased production of peritoneal fluid and decreased reabsorption. Secondary peritonitis is a condition that occurs when an individual develops infection of the peritoneum secondary to another infection, e.g. appendicitis. A bowel perforation would likely be caused by an underlying surgical condition, or would be a complication of bowel surgery. Intraperitoneal haemorrhage is a rare phenomenon that would be expected to cause harm-dynamic instability.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/M502Byuiskw?ecver=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Intraperitoneal haemorrhage;;Bowel perforation;;Malignant ascites;;Secondary peritonitis

Text:
An 18-year old woman has presented to her GP because she has noticed a supraclavicular neck lump. It is firm and rubbery, but not tender. She also reports experiencing flu-like symptoms, as well as night sweats, for a few weeks now.

A biopsy is taken and sent for pathology testing. The results come back and show Reed-Sternberg cells are present.

What is the diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
BUZZWORD: Reed-Sternberg cells (mirror image nuclei) = Hodgkin's lymphoma. 
Other features of Hodgkin's lymphoma:
- Lymphadenopathy - usually painless, asymmetrical. 
- Systemic B symptoms in some
- Normocytic anaemia
- Raised LDH

Non-Hodgkins lymphoma is much more common than Hodgkin's lymphoma, but they both present in a similar way. Diagnosis is made on microscopy of biopsied tissue.
NHL is usually much more likely in elderly patients, with the average age of diagnosis being in the patient's 60s. Hodgkin's has a bimodal incidence, more common in patients' 30s and 70s.

Hodgkin's is also more likely to begin in lymph nodes of the upper body, as seen in this case.
IncorrectAnswers: Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma;;Thyroid adenoma;;Benign cyst;;Tuberculosis

Text:
Rebecca is a 31-year-old female who presents to her GP complaining of irritability, palpitations and fatigue. On examination, Rebecca has a subtle mass in her neck that is non-tender and smooth. Rebecca has a resting heart rate of 104bpm, but her remaining vital signs are otherwise normal. The rest of the examination is unremarkable, with no lid lag or proptosis.

You order several blood tests which show:
TSH - 0.3 (0.5 - 4.0)
T4 - 28 (10 - 20)
Anti-TPO - Positive
Anti-TSH Receptor - Negative

What is the most likely diagnosis for Rebecca?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The blood tests here reveal a clear picture of primary hyperthyroidism (low TSH with high T4). Although the most common diagnosis for primary hyperthyroidism in this context would be Grave's disease, the lack of Anti-TSH receptor antibodies suggests this is not the diagnosis. 

Sub-clinical hyperthyroidism does not usually present with symptoms, while De Quervain's thyroiditis typically has a painful goitre associated. A toxic multi nodular goitre will generally be an irregular mass, not smooth.

Although most Hashimoto's thyroiditis is diagnosed when the patient is hypothyroid ('burnt out thyroiditis'), the early stage of the disease often involves a period of hyperthyroidism. The presence of anti-TPO antibodies is suggestive of Hashimoto's.
IncorrectAnswers: Sub-clinical hyperthyroidism;;Toxic multinodular goitre;;De Quervain s thyroiditis;;Grave s disease

Text:
Delilah is an 87 year old who presents from her nursing home after blood tests following a diarrhoeal illness showed a serum creatinine of 200umol/L (RR: 55-120umol/L). She does not appear to be fluid overloaded. Her current medications include Atorvastatin, Frusemide, Perindopril, Digoxin, Vitamin D and Alendronate.   

As she is being transferred to short stay, you are asked to chart her regular medications. Which of the following alterations is appropriate?
CorrectAnswer: Stop Frusemide and Perindopril, reduce dose of Digoxin
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Adjustment of medications during AKI
Need to stop al nephrotoxic medications:
-	NSAIDs
-	ACE inhibitors 
-	Diuretics 
-	Contrast 
Adjustment of doses of medications that are renally excreted 
-Digoxin (need to monitor levels for digoxin toxicity)
-Some antibiotics (penacillins, gentamicin)  
-Lithium
IncorrectAnswers: Stop Perindopril, reduce dose of Frusemide and Alendronate;;Stop Furosemide and Perindopril, reduce dose of Alendronate ;;Continue all current medications;;Stop Frusemide, reduce dose of Perindopril and Digoxin

Text:
A 53 year old gent, presents to the emergency department with a superficial forehead laceration. He is disheveled, cachectic and smells of alcohol. Despite this, he is lucid and orientated.  His history reveals numerous (>15) admissions for alcohol intoxication and related injuries in the last year. He is vitally stable, and the laceration requires a few stitches. The ED is very busy, so you place the patient in a quiet room and plan to see him as soon as more urgent cases are stabilised. 

You return hours later and find the patient to have florid delirium with hallucinations with associated confusion and irritability. He is unsteady on his feet. 

What is the most appropriate next step in management, given the likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswer: Establish I/V access and give Vitamin B1 (thiamine) urgently, followed later by a small meal and fluids
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This patient has Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) Deficiency. It is caused by the acute deficiency of thiamine in a susceptible host (Risk Factors: Chronic alcoholics & Hx of bowel surgery). It is under-diagnosed in clinical practice.

The spectrum of patients affected continues to increase with changing medical practice. The neuropsychiatric manifestations are varied but typically include alterations of consciousness, eye movement abnormalities, and gait and balance disorders.

Unless treated as an emergency with thiamine replacement parenterally, permanent neurological injury may occur as Korsakoff's psychosis.
IncorrectAnswers: Septic Screen;;Give Vit. B1 I/M STAT;;Sandwiches;;Lorazepam and supportive I/V fluid replacement for alcohol withdrawal

Text:
A 76-year-old woman with a history of atrial fibrillation presents with severe abdominal pain and bloody diarrhoea. On examination her temperature is 37.8, HR 102 and RR 30. Her abdomen is tender with generalised guarding. Blood tests reveal a markedly raised white cell count and low bicarbonate. 

The most likely diagnosis is?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Mesenteric ischemia is a condition caused by obstruction of blood supply to a vascular territory of the gut. It is commonly seen in vasculopaths, as well as those with AF (especially if not therapeutically anticoagulated). Blockage of a mesenteric vessel due to thrombus or embolus leads to ischemic necrosis of the gut, which causes the symptoms of severe pain and bloody diarrhoea (due to breakdown of mucosal blood vessels). With time, the patients may develop systemic inflammatory response due to the degree of injury to the gut, with or without an infective infiltration. The dying gut also leaks lactate, which may lead to a lactic acidosis (seen here with low bicardbonate).

A ruptured AAA would not be expected to cause bloody diarrhoea, while diverticulitis would not be expected to cause such significant pain and systemic illness. A small bowel obstruction does not generally cause bloody diarrhoea.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/NTE1caA3sxk" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Diverticulitis;;Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  ;;Campylobacter infection;;Small Bowel Obstruction

Text:
A 47-year old woman loses consciousness for 2 minutes while shopping in a supermarket. In the ED, she recounts feeling nausea and warmth spreading over her body immediately before passing out. She has never had this happen before. She has not seen a doctor for several years and does not take any medications, nor does she smoke or drink alcohol. Her family history is unremarkable. 

Which of the following is the most likely cause of her episode?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Neurocardiogenic syncope is also known as vasovagal syncope, and is a common cause of fainting. It occurs due to excessive vagal tone and is characterized by nausea, diaphoresis, tachycardia, and pallor immediately prior to the syncopal episode. If often happens in response to stress, pain, and certain bodily actions. It is particularly common in young women. It can be diagnosed with the tilt table test.

In arrhythmia, generally there are no preceding signs or symptoms except for palpitations in some. Patients usually have underlying cardiac disease. 

The patient does not have clear signs of seizure (e.g. tongue biting), a history of seizures, or a post-ictal state, making this less likely. 

Syncope due to aortic stenosis (valvular disease) usually occurs with activity. Dyspnoea, chest pain and fatigue on exertion are symptoms of aortic stenosis that generaly occur earlier in the disease course.

Orthostatic hypotension is a drop in systolic BP greater than 20 mmHg after the patient rises to a standing position. It is most common in the elderly, diabetics, those with autonomic neuropathy, those with hypovolaemia, and those taking diuretics.
IncorrectAnswers: Cardiac arrhythmia;;Valvular heart disease;;Orthostatic hypotension;;Seizure

Text: Which of the following would NOT result in a change in the anion gap?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Alterations in the anion gap (AG = Na - (Cl + HCO3)) are caused by production of anions that would be present normally, e.g. diabetic ketoacidosis creates ketoacids which dissociate into various anions and H+. The added anions raises the cation balance (i.e. increased Na+), thus increasing the anion gap. The other way of getting an increased anion gap is via kidney dysfunction, as this leads to impaired electrolyte handling.

Diarrhoea involves the iso-osmotic loss of water and electrolytes, thus there is no change in the anion gap.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/sQnEFVNrY74" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Kidney disease;;Aspirin overdose;;Diabetic ketoacidosis;;Lactic acidosis

Text:
A 76-year-old male with metastatic bowel cancer is admitted to the palliative care ward complaining of abdominal pain, nausea and recurrent dark-brown vomits. On questioning, he reports not having passed bowel motion in several days. Examination shows an unwell looking gentleman, with a diffusely tender and distended abdomen. Auscultation of the abdomen reveals absent bowel sounds. The admitting doctor promptly diagnosed the patient with an acute bowel obstruction likely secondary to the mass effect of his cancer which was confirmed with abdominal X ray.
 
What anti-enetic medication is contraindicated to treat this patients nausea?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Metoclopramide is contraindicated in this situation as it is a pro-kinetic agent, which would worsen the symptoms of bowel obstruction by allowing more digested content to reach the point of obstruction.

The other anti-emetic agents are less likely to worsen the symptoms of nausea associated with bowel obstruction, thus making them safe to use in this context.
IncorrectAnswers: Cyclizine ;;Ondansetron ;;Droperidol;;Dexamethasone

Text: What is the function of corrugator supercili?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The corrugator supercilii is a small, narrow, pyramidal muscle close to the eye. It is located at the medial end of the eyebrow, beneath the frontalis and just above orbicularis oculi muscle. It arises from the medial end of the superciliary arch; and its fibers pass upward and laterally, between the palpebral and orbital portions of the orbicularis oculi muscle, and are inserted into the deep surface of the skin, above the middle of the orbital arch. The name corrugator supercilii is Latin, meaning wrinkler of the eyebrows. Reference: TeachMeAnatomy - Muscles of Facial Expression
IncorrectAnswers: Draws the upper lip upwards;;Assists in abduction of the hip;;Assists in elevation of the scapulae;;Elevation of the upper eyelid

Text:
A mother brings her 1-month old son into the GP clinic because she is concerned about a rash he has developed over the past 3 days. You notice the child is lethargic, floppy, and appears very unwell. Vital signs are: HR 180bpm, SBP 60, T 38.7. You suspect sepsis. 

What is the most likely causative agent in this child?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Group B streptococcus (GBS) one of the most common causes of sepsis in children under 3 months old, along with E. coli and, less commonly, Listeria. This child therefore most likely has an infection caused by GBS.

Staph aureus infection is a more likely cause in children older than 3 months of age. Community acquired MRSA, Group A streptococci and Neisseria meningitidis are all more common causes of sepsis in children older than 3 months of age.
IncorrectAnswers: Group A streptococci;;Neisseria meningitidis;;Community-acquired MRSA;;Staphylococcus aureus

Text: A sample of urine from a patient is found to contain blood (haematuria). Which of the following would best help determine if the blood was glomerular in origin or not?
CorrectAnswer: Monomorphic vs dysmorphic red blood cells on microscopy
CorrectAnswerExplanation: When red blood cells are forced through the glomerular filtration membrane, the narrow slits formed by the podocytes cause structural damage to the red cells. As a result, microscopy of the urine from a patient with haematuria of glomerular origin will show dysmorphic red blood cells.
IncorrectAnswers: Proteinuria;;Microscopic vs macroscopic haematuria;;ALT levels;;Iron studies

Text:
Dennis is a 64-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, on a background of a 40 pack-year smoking history. On examination, Dennis has a pulse oximetry reading of 93%, and appears to have an enlarged thorax with blue-tinged lips and hands. You notice distended neck veins on Dennis, as well as peripheral oedema. He is currently managed with regular inhaled beta-agonists and muscarinic antagonists. 

What would you expect Dennis  arterial blood gas to show?
CorrectAnswer: pH <7.35, PaCO2 increased, HCO3 increased, PaO2 reduced
CorrectAnswerExplanation: In COPD, CO2 retention is a common feature of late stage disease (especially in those with a picture suggestive of more chronic bronchitis). CO2 retention leads to an increase PaCO2 on ABG, which will be compensated by an increase in HCO3. True compensation will never return the pH to normal values, so the pH in this patient will reduced due to the acidic nature of CO2.
IncorrectAnswers: pH >7.45, PaCO2 decreased, HCO3 normal, PaO2 normal;;pH >7.45, PaCO2 normal, HCO3 increased, PaO2 normal;;pH <7.35, PaCO2 decreased, HCO3 increased, PaO2 reduced;;pH normal, PaCO2 increased, HCO3 increased, PaO2 reduced

Text:
A 49-year-old male undergoes an iodide-131 thyroid scan following a 6-month history of slight weight gain and cold intolerance. The scan shows a large  cold nodule  in the left lobe of the thyroid. 

Without taking a biopsy at this stage, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Papillary carcinoma is the most common type of cancer of the thyroid in this demographic. Medullary carcinomas are associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia syndromes.
IncorrectAnswers: Medullary thyroid carcinoma;;Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma;;Follicular thyroid carcinoma;;Metastatic cancer

Text: The majority of cardiac muscle in the heart is found in which component of its anatomy?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The myocardium layer (middle layer) of the heart contains the most cardiac muscle.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/bm65xCS5ivo" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Mitral valve;;Endocardium;;Epicardium;;Pericardium

Text: Occlusion of which coronary artery leads to an infarct involving the anterior wall of the left ventricle?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The LAD supplies most of the blood feeding the anterior wall of the left ventricle, apex, most of the conduction system below the AV node, and the anterior two-thirds of the septum. An occlusion of the LAD results primarily in injury to the anterior wall of the left ventricle. Left circumflex is wrong because occlusion of this artery would lead to a lateral wall infarct. Right coronary artery is wrong because occlusion would lead to an inferior/posterior infarct. Obtuse marginal artery is wrong because occlusion of this vessel would lead to a high lateral infarct. Posterior descending artery is wrong because occlusion of this artery would lead to a posterior infarct.
IncorrectAnswers: Right coronary artery;;Left circumflex;;Obtuse marginal artery;;Posterior descending artery (PDA)

Text:
A 30-year old man is brought into ED. He is bradycardic, sweating and salivating profusely,  and has generalised muscle weakness. The consultant on call suspects organophosphate poisoning. 

Given this likely diagnosis, what is the most appropriate treatment?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Organophosphate-containing insecticides work by inhibiting cholinesterase activity, thereby prolonging the effects of acetylcholine. Common features include:
- Anxiety
- Bradycardia
- Restlesness
- Nausea and vomiting 
- Hypersalivation
- Abdominal colic
- Diarrhoea
- Eventually ,muscle weakness and fasciculation can develop, which may progress to a flaccid paralysis. 
Atropine reverses the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine and is given regularly until the skin becomes flush and dry, the pupils dilate, and tachycardia develops.

Adrenaline is the management for anaphylaxis.
Flumanzeil is for treatment of benzodiazepine overdose.
IncorrectAnswers: Neostigine;;Fluid support;;Adrenaline;;Flumazenil

Text: What is the best description of the physiological mechanism by which the aortic valve opens during the cardiac cycle?
CorrectAnswer: During cardiac systole, depolarisation of contractile cardiomyocytes causes contraction of the muscle as a  syncytium, increasing intraventricular pressure to the point at which aortic pressure is succeeded, causing the valves to open
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The aortic valve opens when the pressure in the left ventricle exceeds the pressure in the aorta. The physiological mechanism is underpinned by contraction of cardiac muscle causing changes in LV pressure and aortic pressure.
IncorrectAnswers: Blood flowing from the right atria to the right ventricle during cardiac diastole results in an increase in ventricular pressure, resulting in a closure of the tricuspid valve and opening of the aortic valve in a transition to cardiac systole;;The aortic valve opens when aortic pressure exceeds intraventricular pressure;;The aortic valve opening occurs when conduction via the cardiac pathway reaches the Bundle of His, causing blood to be pumped into the aorta;;After a period of isovolumetric contraction, the increased volume in the left ventricle results in an opening of the aortic valve and blood flows out of the ventricle

Text:
A 5-month old boy is brought into Warrnambool by his mother with symptoms of coryzal illness and poor feeding. He is showing signs of respiratory distress including nasal flaring and slight intercostal recession. Auscultation of the chest reveals diffuse wheeze. Pulse oximetry was conducted, and showed a saturation of 93% on room air.

The boy is admitted to the paediatric ward, where he is treated with oxygen delivered via high-flow nasal cannulae.

What is the most likely pathogen that has caused the boy s illness?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The stem above describes a common presentation of bronchiolitis, a respiratory infection seen in infants. Bronchiolitis generally presents with coughing, wheezing, dyspnoea and poor feeding. More severe cases can lead to marked increases in work of breathing (tracheal tug, subcostal recession, nasal flaring), marked hypoxaemia (i.e. SaO2 <90%) and episodes of apnoea.

Bronchiolitis is mostly caused by respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), accounting for over 70% of cases. Parainfluenza virus is more associated with croup (laryngotracehobronchitis), which affects the upper airways compared to the lower airways as seen in bronchiolitis. Haemophilus influenzae is more known for causing pneumonia, epiglottitis and meningitis, however vaccination (Hib) against H. influenzae is making it far less common. Influenza virus results in the common 'flu' and viral pneumonia but is less common in infants. Rhinovirus is the source of the common cold, which presents differently compared to the stem above.

Reference: http://www.rch.org.au/clinicalguide/guideline_index/Bronchiolitis_Guideline/
IncorrectAnswers: Rhinovirus;;Parainfluenza virus;;Haemophilus influenzae;;Influenza virus

Text: In someone with a blood pressure of 141/81, what is the approximate MAP (mean arterial pressure)?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The equation to calculate MAP is 1/3 SBP + 2/3 DBP. 60mmHg is the pulse pressure (SBP - DBP), which could also calculate MAP (DBP + 1/3 pulse pressure).
IncorrectAnswers: 105;;89;;60;;Cannot be measured using the above information

Text: Which of the following best describes bone calcium density, and serum concentrations of phosphate and parathyroid hormone (PTH) in chronic kidney disease following compensatory mechanisms?
CorrectAnswer: Decreased bone calcium; Increased serum phosphate; Increased PTH
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
In mineral bone disease related to chronic kidney disease, the lack of the kidney function in Vitamin D metabolism leads to decreased serum calcium levels and increased serum phosphate levels, which in turn leads to an increase in parathyroid hormone release. PTH then causes bone breakdown to increase serum calcium levels, which also releases phosphate.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Dk8e3zQuadU" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Decreased bone calcium; Increased serum phosphate; Stable PTH;;Decreased bone calcium; Decreased serum phosphate; Increased PTH;;Increased bone calcium; Increased serum phosphate; Increased PTH;;Increased bone calcium; Decreased serum phosphate; Stable PTH

Text:
You are the intern on the Rehabilitation ward and you are about to clerk a patient that has recently had a below knee amputation on their left side. Before you go and see the patient you are trying to revise your knowledge about amputations, in particular you are wondering about the difference between energy consumption related to dysvascular and traumatic aetiology.

Which of the following has the greatest energy expenditure?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswer: Above knee amputation from a dysvascular aetiology
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Reference
IncorrectAnswers: Above knee amputation from a traumatic aetiology;;Below knee amputation from a dysvascular aetiology ;;Below knee dysvascular and above knee traumatic amputations have equally the most;;Below knee amputation from a traumatic aetiology

Text: Which of the following is FALSE regarding the muscles of the forearm?
CorrectAnswer: The extensor carpi ulnaris muscle assists with abduction at the wrist
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The extensor carpi ulnaris (ECU) muscle inserts onto the base of the fifth metacarpal, situated on the medial side of the hand. Although the primary action of this muscle is wrist extension (in conjunction with extensor carpi radials brevis/longus), the ECU also causes adduction (not abduction) of the wrist. Reference: Teach Me Anatomy - Muscles of the Posterior Forearm
IncorrectAnswers: The common flexor tendon originates from the medial epicondyle;;The common extensor tendon originates from the lateral epicondyle;;The muscles of the anterior compartment are mostly innervated by the median nerve;;The palmaris longus muscle is absent in some people

Text: What is responsible for the formation of granuloma in primary TB infections?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Interferon-gamma is required for T cell activation (helper type 1) which is how hypersensitivity type 4 reaction is mediated (activates macrophages which go on to form the granuloma). TNF alpha is produced in the first stage of inflammation mainly by macrophages . It induces activation of lymphocytes and and proliferation of fibroblasts. Bradykinin is produced in inflammation and causes vasodilation. Leucotriene B4 is a chemotactic factor for acute inflammation.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/C3E5COZ1XC8?ecver=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/S0Kak0qQFgM?ecver=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: TNF-alpha;;Bradykinin;;IL-13;;Leucotriene B4

Text: How do thiazide diuretics work to reduce blood pressure?
CorrectAnswer: Inhibits the sodium-chloride transporter in the distal tubule in kidneys
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Following long-term activation (as seen in hypertension) of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system results in increased aldosterone production, as well as a number of other effects. The increased aldosterone production stimulates sodium reabsorption, and therefore the retention of water to increase blood volume. Thiazides inhibit the reabsorption of sodium in the distal tubule so that water can be excreted, reducing blood volume and therefore cardiac output, and over long-term use can cause vasodilation, lowering peripheral resistance.

Beta-blockers target B1 adrenoceptors. ACE inhibitors prevent the conversion of angiotensin I into angiotensin II. Angiotensin receptor blockers inhibit type 1 angiotensin receptors. Calcium channel blockers target L-type calcium channels.
IncorrectAnswers: Blocks type 1 angiotensin II receptors;;Inhibits the formation of angiotensin II;;Inhibits B1 adrenoceptors;;Inhibits the influx of calcium via L-type calcium channels

Text: Which of the following cell types are the most common in the pancreas?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Pancreatic acinar cells are the cells responsible for the synthesis, secretion, and storage of certain digestive enzymes. They outnumber the endocrine cells (e.g. alpha and beta cells) considerably.
IncorrectAnswers: Delta cells;;Alpha cells;;F cells;;Beta cells

Text: Which of the following is true of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease?
CorrectAnswer: It results in dilation of the collecting ducts due to cysts
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) is a rare genetic condition that affects the kidneys, leading to dilation of the collecting ducts due to the formation of cysts.

It is rarer than the autosomal dominant variety of polycystic kidney disease, and is associated with the PKHD1 gene (as opposed to PKD 1 or 2, which is associated with the autosomal dominant condition). It is more common in children, and can skip generations due to the recessive nature of the disease allowing for 'carrier' individuals.
IncorrectAnswers: It is more common in adults;;It can be caused by mutations in genes PKD 1 or 2;;It cannot skip generations;;It is more common overall than autosomal dominant PCKD

Text:
A 23-year-old male is undergoing a regular physical examination prior to joining the army. He reports being fit and well, with a BMI of 23 and blood pressure of 129/89. While carrying out the physical examination, the doctor notes that the patient has signs suggestive of undiagnosed hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM). 

Which of the findings would most likely be present on examination of this patient?
CorrectAnswer: Ejection systolic murmur at upper left sternal edge, louder on Valsalva
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
On examination, HOCM presents with an ejection systolic murmur at the upper left sternal edge, similar to aortic stenosis. HOCM can be differentiated from aortic stenosis on examination by performing the Valsalva manoeuvre. When this is done, a patient with HOCM will have a louder murmur, whereas a patient with aortic stenosis will have a softer murmur. This is because the Valsalva increases intrathoracic pressure, pushing the walls of the left ventricle together. This causes blood to flow in an even more turbulent manner through the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT), which is hypertrophied in HOCM. The valsalva reduces cardiac output by reducing venous return, so there is less blood flowing through the aortic valve. As such, the Valsalva makes aortic stenosis murmurs softer.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/8RnkKB8xvwA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers:
Ejection systolic murmur radiating to the carotid arteries;;Palpable thrill over the left sternal edge
;;Wide, fixed splitting of S2;;S3 added heart sound

Text:
A 19-year-old male is brought into ED by concerned friends who believe he intentionally took an overdose of paracetamol 3 hours ago, estimated to be 30 tablets (equivalent to 15g). The patient is stable and cooperative.

What is the most appropriate action plan for this patient?
CorrectAnswer: Measure serum paracetamol at 4 hours post-ingestion, begin N-acetylcysteine infusion if paracetamol level exceeds nomogram treatment line
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The most appropriate course of action here is to measure serum paracetamol at 4 hours post-ingestion, and begin N-acetylcysteine infusion if the measured paracetamol level exceeds the nomogram treatment line. The most recent guidelines in Australia recommend that activated charcoal should only be given if the person presents with a single acute supratherapeutic paracetamol ingestion (i.e. >200mg/kg, or >10g over a course of 8 hours, whichever dose is lower, NB: only applies if above 6 years old) presents within 2 hours of ingestion. This is controversial as Therapeutic Guidelines still suggest adhering to previous guidelines, which state that activated charcoal should be given only if the person presents within 1 hour of paracetamol ingestion. If patients present between 2 to 8 hours after ingestion, paracetamol levels should be measured between 4-8 hours after ingestion. If the measured level exceeds the treatment line on the nomogram, N-acetylcysteine infusion should be commenced. Reference: Management guidelines for paracetamol poisoning in Australia and New Zealand
IncorrectAnswers: Measure liver function (LFTs) at 4 hours post-ingestion, begin N-acetylcysteine infusion if alanine aminotransferase (ALT) is greater than twice the upper normal limit;;Begin N-acetylcysteine infusion immediately, then measure serum paracetamol at 4 hours post-ingestion ;;Commence treatment with activated charcoal, then measure serum paracetamol at 4 hours post-ingestion and begin N-acetylcysteine infusion if paracetamol level exceeds nomogram treatment line;;Begin N-acetylcysteine infusion immediately, then measure serum paracetamol at 4 hours post-ingestion

Text: Which class of laxative (aperient) medication functions primarily by actively drawing fluid into the bowel lumen, causing stools to become softer?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Osmotic laxatives (e.g. lactulose) function by creating an osmotic gradient for water to pass into the bowels, thus softening stools and allowing for easier passage. Bulk-forming agents (psyllium, dietary fibre) are non-digestible carbohydrates that are used in long-term control of constipation. Iso-osmotic laxatives (e.g. macrogol/movicol) do not actively draw water into the gut lumen. Stool softeners (e.g. coloxyl, parachoc) provide lubrication to stool passage. Stimulant agents (e.g. senna, docusate) act on the gut mucosa and neural network to actively increase stool movement through the bowels. Reference: Deakin ARP Lecture - Management of Constipation and Faecal Incontinence (Dr Rosie Crone)
IncorrectAnswers: Stimulant laxative;;Bulk-forming agent;;Iso-osmotic agent;;Stool softener (emollient agent)

Text: In the following pressure-volume loop, which of the options best represents the period of isovolumetric relaxation?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: isovolumetric relaxation occurs when the ventricles cease contraction and are thus relaxed, but the intraventricular pressure still exceeds atrial pressure. As a result, no blood flow occurs into the ventricles, thus this period is termed 'isovolumetric'. This is identified as D in the above pressure-volume loop.
IncorrectAnswers: B;;C;;E;;A

Text: Which of the following is NOT a chemical buffering system in the body?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: There are a number of important buffer systems active in the body at any one time, which function to ensure the body pH remains strictly regulated. The most important buffer in the blood is the HCO3 (bicarbonate) buffer system, which forms and breaks down carbonic acid (H2CO3) into water and CO2 in response to fluctuations in blood pH. The haemoglobin buffer system is another important blood buffer system, while the protein and phosphate buffer systems act largely intracellularly.
IncorrectAnswers: HCO3 buffering system;;Haemoglobin buffering system;;Phosphate buffer system;;Protein buffer system

Text: Which of the following is an amino acid derivative hormone?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Growth hormone and pro-insulin are peptide hormones, prostacyclin is an eicosanoid , and testosterone is a steroid. Adrenaline and other catecholamines are derived from the amino acid tyrosine.
IncorrectAnswers: Pro-insulin;;Prostacyclin;;Growth hormone;;Testosterone

Text: Which one is correct in relation to T cell development?
CorrectAnswer: T cell development occurs in the thymus and moves from double negative --> double positive (CD4+ and CD8+) --> single positive (CD4+ or CD8+)
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
While the T cell progenitor differentiates in the bone marrow, it migrates to the thymus to undergo development. T cell development occurs in the following sequence: 
1. Starting out as a double negative cell (CD4- CD8-) you have TCR rearrangement
2. The cell expresses both CD4+ and CD8+ (double positive) and undergoes positive selection to see which MHC it has greater affinity to
3. The cell is then positively selected as a single positive (either CD4+ or CD8+) and it is negatively tested for self reactivity by help of thymic medullary cells that express AIRE (autoimmune regulator) that initiates expression of peripheral tissue expression to check for autoreactivity

Reference: Janeway's Immunobiology, page 280 - T cell Development
IncorrectAnswers: T cell development occurs independent of thymic medullary cells;;T cell development occurs in the bone marrow and moves from double negative --> double positive (CD4+ and CD8+) --> single positive (CD4+ or CD8+);;T cells undergo negative selection first then positive selection;;T cells progenitors differentiate in the thymus

Text: A man on the Gen Med ward has only passed 100ml of urine in the past 9 hours. You suspect he has Acute Kidney Injury (AKI). Which potential metabolic disturbance resulting from AKI would you be MOST worried about?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Hyperkalaemia is the most serious electrolyte abnormality that can present as a result of AKI - it can cause potentially fatal cardiac arrhythmias, which is why doctors want to catch it early/prevent it.

ECG changes are a more accuate representation of serum K levels, and changes to look out for in hyperkalaemia include: tented T waves, prolonged QRS complexes, small P waves. When things are getting really bad, a sine wave will form. 

You'd want to consider any medications the patient might be on which contributes to high potassium: beta agonists, unfractionated and LMW heparin, and potassium-sparing diuretics (spironolactone). 

Hyperphosphataemia and hypocalcaemia are characteristic of Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) rather than AKI.
IncorrectAnswers: Hyperuricaemia;;Hypocalcaemia;;Hypernatraemia;;Hyperphosphataemia

Text: A farmer using organophosphate pesticides on his farm arrives at emergency with difficulty breathing. What other symptoms would you expect?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Organophosphate poisoning causes cholinergic effects (lacrimation, hypersalivation, bronchospasm, diarrhoea, miosis...with increased activity at muscarininc and nicotinic receptors. This is due to organophosphates irreversibly inhibiting acetylcholinesterase activity (so acetylcholine cannot be broken down, hence the symptoms associated with excess acetylcholine. Management involves anticholinergic drugs like Atropine.
IncorrectAnswers: Urinary retention;;Pupil dilation;;Constipation;;Hyposalivation

Text:
Ethyl is a 14yo who presents to your clinic, concerned that she is not entering puberty at the same time as her friends. Ethyl s mum explains that she is not concerned as most of the family were  late bloomers .
 
On examination Ethyl is 145cm tall, and weighs 48kg. She is Tanner stage 1 and has not developed any pubic hair. You also notice slight webbing of the neck.
  
Which investigation is likely to provide a diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Turner syndrome - one of most common chromosome anomalies. It is an important cause of short stature and ovarian insufficiency in females. It involves loss of part or all of an X chromosome. Features include short stature, failure to enter puberty, webbed neck, wide set eyes.
IncorrectAnswers: BHCG;;TSH;;FSH/LH;;Trans abdominal ultrasound

Text: Which of the following muscles cannot contribute to medial rotation of the humerus?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The rhomboid (major and minor) muscles do not attach to the humerus, rather they are intrinsic muscles of the back that insert onto the medial border of the scapulae to cause retraction. Reference: TeachMeAnatomy - Intrinsic Back Muscles
IncorrectAnswers: Teres major;;Latissimus dorsi;;Subscapularis;;Pectoralis major

Text:
Magnolia, a 27 year old professional polo athlete who is visiting Geelong for a tournament, presents to your clinic for a routine pap smear. On speculum examination, you notice a muco-purulent endocervical discharge. You send swabs for NAAT and microscopy however you are concerned that she may not return for follow up. 

Which of the following is the most appropriate empiric therapy?
CorrectAnswer: Ceftriaxone 500mg IM and Azithromycin 1g PO, single dose
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
In the setting of cervicitis with purulent discharge, empirical therapy includes treatment for both Chlamydia and Gonorrhoea. See eTG: "Urethritis and Cervicitis":

"Empirical treatment for both gonococcal and chlamydial infection is recommended until the results of investigations are available use the regimen recommended for gonococcal infection because this also treats chlamydial infection."

"Ceftriaxone 500 mg in 2 mL of 1% lignocaine IM, or 500 mg IV, as a single dose

PLUS

Azithromycin 1 g orally, as a single dose."
IncorrectAnswers: Metronidazole 400mg PO, 12-hourly for 5 days;;Benzathine Penicillin 1.8g IM, single dose;;Doxycycline 100mg PO, 12-hourly for 7 days;;Azithromycin 1g orally as a single dose

Text:
A 62-year-old man presents to the GP with a lump in the left groin which has been present for over 2 months. On examination, the lump is above the inguinal ligament. On palpation, the hernia extends into the scrotum, is reducible and has a cough impulse. After it has been reduced, placing a finger just above the midpoint of the inguinal ligament prevents the lump from re-emerging on coughing.

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
When identifying hernias on examination, anatomical position is vitally important. 

A femoral hernia would arise from below the inguinal ligament. An obturator hernia is protrusion of abdominal contents through the obturator foramen and the diagnosis is often made intraoperatively after presenting with bowel obstruction.

While both direct and indirect inguinal hernias can pass through the superficial ring into the scrotum, indirect hernias are more likely to due to the path along the inguinal canal being of lower resistance than a muscular defect. Internally, indirect inguinal hernias pass medially to the inferior epigastric vessels, while direct inguinal hernias will pass laterally to the inferior epigastric vessels. Occlusion of the deep inguinal ring also prevents this hernia from protruding, indicating it is indirect. 

https://radiopaedia.org/articles/hesselbachs-triangle-1
https://geekymedics.com/hernias-explained/


<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/nmD6nZdJtuU" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Incisional hernia;;Femoral hernia;;Direct inguinal hernia ;;Obturator hernia

Text:
A 70 year old man is admitted to the Emergency Department after vomiting blood earlier in the day. 

Which one of the following factors best indicates a significant upper gastrointestinal bleed?
CorrectAnswer: Urea = 15.4 mmol/L on a background of normal renal function
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
- An upper gastrointestinal bleed can act as a protein meal and cause a temporary, disproportionate rise in the blood urea.
- Bleeding into GI tract causes absorption of blood in small bowel, urea is end product of protein metabolism and causes increased urea 
- Acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding causes: 
- Inflammation/Ulceration - Oesophagitis, Peptic Ulcer (H. pylori, Drugs, others), Gastritis, duodenitis 
- Vascular - Varices, Portal HTN 
- Trauma - Mallory Weiss tear, foreign body 
- Tumour - Malignant, benign 
- Other - coagulopathy - drugs, primary, secondary 

Assessment of UGIB: 
Use Blatchford-Glasgow Score at first presentation (does not require information from endoscopy, shows need for intervention - endoscopy or blood transfusion)
- Blood Urea 
- Haemoglobin 
- Systolic BP 
- Other - HR, malaena, syncope, hepatic disease, cardiac failure 
Score > 6, 50% of needing surgical intervention 
Rockall Score (requires info from endoscopy, shows predicted mortality)

Reference: Up To Date - Approach to acute upper GI bleeding in adults

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/q3NfveOcU7I?ecver=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Platelets of 89 * 109/L;;Sodium = 147 mmol/L;;Creatinine = 190 µmol/L on a background of normal renal function;;Potassium = 2.9 mmol/L

Text:
A 22-year old man presents to his GP for a general check-up. On taking his blood pressure, it is found to be unusually high, at 160/90. Blood tests are ordered, and his potassium is found to be 2.7 mmol/L (Normal: 3.5 - 5.0). All other investigations, including FBE, UEC, LFTs, and calcium level, are normal.

What would be the most useful investigation to do next?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The differentials you should think of when you see hypertension with hypokalaemia are: Conn's Syndrome, Cushing's syndrome, Renal Artery Stenosis, and Liddle's Syndrome. 
Determining plasma renin and aldosterone levels will help distinguish a cause, and help inform further more specialised testing. 
Conn's and Cushings = high aldosterone, low renin.
RAS = high aldosterone, high renin
Liddle's = low aldosterone, low renin

TFTs would be appropriate to do in a young person with unexplained hypertension, and in reality would have probably also been done. However, the key to this question is picking up that the hypokalaemia is significant, and thinking about what the likely causes are.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/JBfkGNr01V8" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers:
Abdominal CT scan
;;24 hour urinary catecholamines;;Abdominal Ultrasound;;Thyroid function tests (TFTs)

Text:
Eric, a 25 year old electrician presents with a 6 month history of difficulty hearing in his right ear. He has been otherwise well and has no relevant past medical history. Rienne test shows bone conduction is greater than air on the right side, however air conduction is greater than bone conduction on the left side. Webbers test localises to the left side. The following is found on examination of the right ear (see below image).

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Cholesteatoma; a cyst composed of keratinized desquamated epithelial cells occurring in the mastoid and temporal bone. Produces conductive hearing loss on the affected side. 

Clinical features include history of ototis media (especially if unilateral), ventilation tubes, ear surgery. Symptoms include progressive hearing loss (predominantly conductive although may get sensorineural hearing loss in late stage), otalgia, aural fullness, fever. 

Treatment: there is no conservative therapy for cholestiatoma, Surgical: mastoidectomy +/- tympanoplasty +/- ossicular reconstruction.
IncorrectAnswers: Impacted ear wax;;Ruptured tympanic membrane ;;Otitis media;;Menieres disease

Text:
A 66yo man is BIBA with sudden onset central crushing chest pain, tingling down his left arm and associated shortness of breath and nausea. Paramedics suspect ACS and performed a 12-lead ECG and established 2 x I/V access points en-route to the Emergency Department (shown below). The patient arrives 30 minutes following the onset of symptoms. 

Which of these is NOT an appropriate component of this patients initial management?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Nitrates are contraindicated in inferior infarcts as they will cause a massive reduction in preload due to their potent vasodilatory effects. This causes a subsequent catastrophic drop in blood pressure.

RCA and RCx supply inferior aspect of heart, therefore to determine extent of infarct right sided leads are required.

Morphine PRN and aspirin are utilised in all myocardial infarcts, irrespective of infarct territory. Given the patient arrived only 30 minutes after symptom onset, he is a candidate for PCI.
IncorrectAnswers: Aspirin 300mg;;Morphine 2-4mg I/V stat, followed with titration until good effect;;Call Cardiology Registrar immediately to arrange percutaneous coronary intervention urgently;;Apply Right Sided ECG leads

Text:
A 73-year-old lady with a past history of TIA presents to ED with a unilateral facial droop. She says that her friend noticed it today when they were out for lunch, so she came to ED immediately as she knew this may be a sign of a stroke. On examination, she had an irregular pulse, but all other vital signs were normal. She was unable to demonstrate any power in her right-sided facial muscles, indicating a complete paresis. You note that when asked to wrinkle her forehead, the patient is only able to do so on the left side, and not the right. The remainder of the examination is normal, with no other focal neurological findings.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: When determining the cause of a facial droop, the most important feature to elicit is if the forehead is spared. Upper motor neuron lesions (e.g. stroke) spare the forehead, allowing wrinkling bilaterally due to crossover of supply from both hemispheres of the brain. Lower motor neuron lesions (e.g. Bell's palsy) do not spare the forehead, so there will always be unilateral loss of wrinkling in these cases. Reference: MedConversations Podcast - Facial Droop
IncorrectAnswers: Intracranial mass pressing on cranial nerve VII (facial nerve);;Sarcoidosis;;Stroke;;Herpes zoster (shingles)

Text:
Jimmy, a 6 year old male presents to ED after falling off a trampoline and injuring his right forearm. On presentation, neurovascular examination is unremarkable, however there is tenderness over the distal radius. Initial X-Rays are shown below.

What is the most appropriate management?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Management of buckle fractures in children - RCH guidelines suggest a wrist splint for 3 weeks. 

Note: image sourced from https://radiopaedia.org/cases/incomplete-radial-fracture
IncorrectAnswers: Cylindrical cast 6 weeks ;;Orthopaedic referral;;Collar and cuff for 4 weeks ;;Reassure and discharge

Text: Which of the following is NOT correct in relation to rheumatic fever/heart disease?
CorrectAnswer: Mitral stenosis due to rheumatic heart disease occurs acutely and develops rapidly
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Mitral stenosis due to rheumatic heart disease takes decades to develop. Important points are that rheumatic heart disease is due to the body's immune response recognising valve tissue due to molecular mimicry, as a result of previous streptococcal infection, and not streptococcus infecting the valve directly. Recurrent episodes of rheumatic fever during childhood that are left untreated, result in valve pathology which can take decades to manifest. When the mitral valve is affected, stenosis leads to build up of pressure in the left atrium as well as the pulmonary circulation, leading to common sign of pulmonary hypertension. Rheumatic fever is easily treated (and prevented) with penicillins.

Reference: CR1 - valve pathology lecture slides 37 to 40

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/cXPtewa5PJc" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Mitral stenosis is almost exclusively related to rheumatic heart disease;;Rheumatic fever and thus rheumatic heart disease is easily preventable;;Cross reactivity between streptococcal antigen and valve tissue may lead to valve pathology;;Pulmonary hypertension is a common in those with rheumatic mitral stenosis

Text:
You are the on-call medical/ICU registrar in Warrnambool, where you have been asked to see a 57-year-old man on the acute medical ward late at night. He was admitted yesterday for work-up of a 3-week history of fatigue, anorexia, weight loss, pyrexia and abdominal pain. His past history includes a hypertension, nephrolithiasis and a recent urinary tract infection treated with a course of antibiotics.

You send off blood for UEC, which shows an acutely raised creatinine of 2.5 times his baseline. You note that he has passed 80ml urine over the last 4 hours. MCS of his urine shows coarse granular casts and renal tubular epithelial cell casts are seen. There are no red cell or white cell casts or eosinophils. 

The most likely underlying pathophysiology is:
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This patient is presenting with risk factors for pre-renal, renal and post-renal AKI. He could be potentially under-volumed, suffering damage due to nephrotoxic antibiotics, or have an obstructive lesion causing renal failure.

In this situation, urinalysis can be used to evaluate the cause of AKI. Bland sediment and hyaline casts are consistent with pre-renal AKI. The presence of renal tubular epithelial cells, coarse granular casts and renal tubular epithelial cell casts are evidence for ATN. RBC casts in the urine sediment are indicative of glomerulonephritis. In cases of acute interstitial nephritis, eosinophils and white blood cell casts are seen.
IncorrectAnswers: Acute glomerulonephritis;;Urinary tract obstruction;;Acute interstitial nephritis;;Hypovolaemia

Text: Which of the following is true of the branches of the abdominal vasculature?
CorrectAnswer: The superior phrenic arteries do not arise from the abdominal aorta
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The superior phrenic arteries are small and arise from the lower part of the thoracic aorta; they are distributed to the posterior part of the upper surface of the diaphragm.

The terminal branches of the abdominal aorta are the common iliac arteries. The coeliac trunk splits into the common hepatic artery, left gastric artery and the splenic artery. The left gonadal vein will often join the left renal vein prior to entering the IVC.
IncorrectAnswers: There are 4 paired direct branches of the aorta travelling to the viscera; the gonadal, renal, inferior suprarenal and superior suprarenal;;The left renal, gonadal and adrenal veins drain directly into the IVC;;The coeliac trunk splits into the splenic, common hepatic and pancreatic arteries;;The terminal branches of the abdominal aorta are the femoral arteries

Text:
A mother brings her 5-year old son into the GP clinic because she is concerned that he has developed swelling around his eyes, scrotum and legs. She also says his urine has been quite frothy, and he has been quite tired over the past few days. He has no significant past medical history, although she tells you he has had a persistent cought for five days.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Minimal Change Disease (MCD) is the most common cause (~90%) of nephrotic syndrome in children! This is the most important thing to remember.

Features of nephrotic syndrome include: proteinuria, hypoalbuminaemia, hypercholesterolaemia. As a result of reduced albumin production, patients often develop oedema, as described in this case.

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults.
IncorrectAnswers: Post-infectious nephropathy;;Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN);;Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN);;IgA nephropathy

Text:
A 3-year-old boy is in acute respiratory distress. There is no past history of note except that he has not been immunized. He has a temperature of 40°C, looks flushed and unwell, is drooling, and has an inspiratory stridor. His cough is muffled. A colleague asks for help examining the boy s throat. 

Which is the single most appropriate advice to give?
CorrectAnswer: Do not disturb the child, and call for senior help urgently
CorrectAnswerExplanation: This child is very likely to have epiglottitis. He has not been immunized so is not protected against Haemophilus influenzae type B, and he shows signs of upper airway obstruction. Any disturbance may cause deteriora- tion, and an attempt to examine the throat may cause fatal respiratory arrest. Intubation is difficult due to the swollen epiglottis, and occasionally emergency tracheostomy is required. Senior anaesthetic and ENT help should be summoned urgently.
IncorrectAnswers: Go ahead and examine the throat, but have a laryngoscope and endotracheal tube to hand;;Give nebulized budesonide and then examine the throat;;Go ahead and examine the throat straight away to help to make a diagnosis;;Site an intravenous line and give a dose of cefotaxime first, and then examine the throat

Text: Which of the following pressure volume loops (in red) is best representative of what happens under physiological conditions during exercise? (NB: normal PV loop shown in black)
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Despite a decrease in filling time, venous return increases EDV (bottom right) after filling. Increased inotropy results in reduced ESV (more blood ejected). This results in a higher SV (the width of the curve). The curve is also higher because pressures are greater (greater volumes are being dealt with with a higher contractile force)
IncorrectAnswers: D;;C;;None of these loops are representative of exercise conditions;;A

Text:
A GP treating a patient receives the following thyroid function tests:

Free T4 - 11 nmol/L (10-25)
Total T3 - 40 pmol/L (0.8-2.0)
Plasma TSH - <0.1 mU/L (0.5-4.0)
Thyroid autoantibodies - Negative
Plasma calcitonin - 1.2 pg/mL (<2)

Which of the following is the most likely clinical syndrome this patient is suffering from?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: This patient is hyperthyroid, with elevated T3 and low TSH, indicating a primary thyroid cause. The most common cause of primary hyperthyroidism is Grave's disease, however this patient is less likely to be suffering from this condition given the negative result for autoantibodies that are normally seen in Grave's disease (e.g. Anti-TSH receptor).
IncorrectAnswers: Primary Hypothyroidism ;;Secondary Hypothyroidism;;Addison's Disease;;Grave's Disease

Text:
Paramedics bring to the ED a 7 month old infant with seizure activity. The father reports the infant was in a normal state of health until approximately 3 days ago when she developed a febrile illness, diagnosed by her physician as a viral URTI. Approximately 30 minutes ago she began having left arm jerking which progressed to whole body jerking. The episode spontaneously ceased on the way to the hospital. Vital signs include heart rate 90 bpm, respiratory rate 25 breaths/minute, and temperature 38oC. Your examination reveals a sleeping infant in no respiratory distress. The child s anterior fontanelle is full. The tympanic membranes are dark and without normal landmarks. The lungs are clear, and the heart and abdominal examinations are normal. She has a bruise over the occiput and several parallel bruises along the spine.

Which of the following is the best next step in management?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
You pretty much will never perform a CT in a child.....unless you suspect intracranial haemorrhage. Needs CT with urgent paediatric neurosurgical consult.

Why is it not a simple febrile convulsion?
1. Started as a partial seizure (focal starting point left arm)
2. HR possibly a bit low? Especially with a febrile illness
3. Full fontanelle
4. Tympanic membranes are dark = Haemotympanum
5. Bruise over the occiput = racoon eyes = trauma
6. Several bruises along spine = trauma

Trauma + decreased conscious state = ICH until proven otherwise

(1) ALWAYS consider non-accidental injury (NAI)
(2) Never perform an LP in a patient who may have increased
intracranial pressure
(3) Simple febrile convulsion vs complex febrile convulsion
IncorrectAnswers: Electroencephalogram (EEG);;Observation;;Lumbar puncture;;Phenobarbital

Text:
An 88-year-old woman presents to her GP complaining of difficulty holding the phone with her right hand. She reports chronic morning stiffness that lasts 1 hour, but she has had no recent episodes of acute swelling. Examination of the patient s right hand reveals swelling and several hard nodules across the third digit.
