Her past medical history is notable for chronic kidney disease, with the most recent laboratory tests demonstrating a serum creatinine level of 256 mmol/L (normal, 50 100 mmol/L), and a long history of  rheumatism.

What is the next most appropriate step in management?
CorrectAnswer: Obtain microscopic examination of tissue aspirate and initiate allopurinol
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Although most of the choices can be helpful in diagnosing gout, the gold standard for diagnosis is direct visualization of uric acid crystals under a microscope. This is easily done by obtaining a small amount of aspirate from a swollen joint or, in this case, a tophus. A uric acid level obtained by a 24-hour urine collection may be normal or elevated in patients with gout, as can a serum uric acid level.1 Radiographs may show classic changes of gouty bone erosions, such as  rat bite  or overhanging edges; however, they cannot establish the diagnosis irrefutably. Rheumatoid factor appears to become elevated with age, but this measurement on its own does not denote any specific condition.

Allopurinol. Because this patient is not currently experiencing an attack of gout, there is no need for acute therapy (eg, prednisone, indomethacin, IV colchicine). IV colchicine should not be used in patients with renal failure, and therefore its use would be contraindicated in this patient.3 Similarly, indomethacin is a poor choice in this patient given his age and decreased kidney function. Although often forgotten, probenecid can be used as a uric acid lowering agent; however, it is only beneficial in patients who undersecrete uric acid (24-hour uric acid level < 800 mg) and have a creatinine clearance greater than 60 mg/dL. Allopurinol should be used with caution and at a reduced dose in patients with decreased renal function.
IncorrectAnswers: Obtain serum uric acid level and initiate indomethacin, colchicine and prednisolone;;Obtain serum uric acid level and initiate allopurinol;;Obtain rheumatoid factor and if positive initiate methotrexate;;Obtain microscopic examination of tissue aspirate and initiate indomethacin, colchicine and prednisolone

Text:
A 24 year old male is brought into the emergency department at 23:30, by a concerned friend who found him at home surrounded by 3 empty paracetamol packets. The friends explains that the patient left a party abruptly at around 22:00, appearing  very distressed and had been heavily drinking from 17:30 (> 10 stubbies of full strength beer). He is now complaining of nausea but has not vomited. You establish it is now an hour post ingestion of paracetamol, and the patient is acutely suicidal. 

What is the next step in this patients management?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Serum paracetamol levels should be attained 4 hours after ingestion or immediately on presentation if after 4 hours. This patient presented 1 hour post ingestion and therefore should be given activated charcoal to absorb as much paracetamol as possible and i/v acetylcysteine. 

AST/ALT, INR/PT, electrolytes and renal function, lactate level, and arterial pH should be checked in all patients receiving acetylcysteine or those with clinical indication of liver dysfunction.

Paracetamol OD 
Stage 1 (<24/24 post ingestion) = usually asymptomatic, N & V can occur 
Stage 2 (1-3 days post) = RUQ tenderness, INR, ALT/AST rise peaking @ 48-72 hrs
Stage 3 (3-4 days post) = Fulminant Hepatic Failure (coagulopathy, jaundice, encephalopathy, hypoglycaemia, metabolic acidosis)
Stage 4 (4 days   2 weeks post) = Recovery Phase, Hepatitic Structure & function return to normal
IncorrectAnswers: Serum Paracetamol concentration immediately;;I/V acetylcysteine infusion;;Refer to psychiatry for assessment;;Commence NAC infusion without serum paracetamol level

Text:
A woman presents to the Emergency Department with severe left flank pain, which began approximately 4 hours ago. The pain is radiating to her groin. 

Given the most likely diagnosis, what is the gold standard investigation used for diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The most likely diagnosis here is a kidney stone (nephrolithiasis). The most common type of kidney stone is calcium oxalate. These stones are radio-opaque, and so can be picked up by imaging. The gold standard is a non-contrast CT. The reason no contrast is given is due to the potential for renal function compromise, which has a risk of becoming worse by giving contrast (why you always should check Creatining Clearance before giving anyone contrast). 

Radio-opaque stones could also be picked up on Abdo Xray, however, you should always consider the other types of stones that may be the cause (where a good history comes in handy - pick up on those risk factors). In reality, many doctors do an abdo x-ray first, and may be able to pick up a radio-opaque stone. But in the chance that it is a radio-lucent stone (uric acid stones), an AXR will miss this. 

The gold standard is thus a non-contrast CT.

Reference: radiopaedia.org/articles/urolithiasis
IncorrectAnswers: KUB Ultrasound ;;Urine MCS;;Abdominal X-ray;;Contrast CT scan

Text:
Hillary is an 18 year old aspiring politician who presents to gynaecology outpatients reporting dysmenorrhoea. The pain in not relieved by simple analgesia and often prevents her from attending school. She states that her mother experienced similar symptoms. She has a regular 28 day cycle.

Given the most likely cause of Hilary s pain, which of the following investigations is likely to provide a definitive diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Endometriosis is growth of ectopic endometrial tissue outside of the uterine cavity. 10-15% of women have a degree of endometriosis

Clinical features: Chronic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhoea (pain often starts days before bleeding), deep dyspareunia, subfertility

Investigation: Laparoscopy is the gold-standard investigation. There is little role for investigation in primary care (e.g. ultrasound)- if the symptoms are significant the patient should be referred for a definitive diagnosis

Management depends on clinical features: there is poor correlation between laparoscopic findings and severity of symptoms
NSAIDs and other analgesia for symptomatic relief, combined oral contraceptive pill, progestogens, GnRH analogues, intrauterine system, drug therapy unfortunately does not seem to have a significant impact on fertility rates. 

Surgery: Some treatments such as laparoscopic excision and laser treatment of endometriotic ovarian cysts may improve fertility.
IncorrectAnswers: STI Screen;;Hysteroscopy;;Trans-vaginal Ultrasound ;;Trans-abdominal Ultrasound

Text:
A 62-year-old woman presents to ED after a syncopal episode. She has no past medical problems, and does not take any medications. During the past 36 hours she has felt very unwell, with abdominal pain, persistent diarrhoea and vomiting. Her blood pressure is 141/82 mm Hg, pulse is 72bpm, respiratory rate is 10, and temperature is 37.9°C. 

Pathology results show:
Na+ : 155 mmol/L (N = 135   145) 
K+: 2.1 mmol/L (N = 3.5   5.0)
Cl: 102 mmol/L (N = 95   105)
Which sign or symptom would be present ONLY in Grave's disease?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Grave's disease is the only hyperthyroid condition that will present with exophthalmos as it is inflammation of the extraocular muscles from the underlying autoimmune condition, rather than excess thyroid hormone that causes the classic sign. Whilst all other causes of hyperthyroidism will show signs of increased SNS tone including lid lag, only Graves disease will show exophthalmos. Reference: UpToDate
IncorrectAnswers: Atrial fibrillation;;Lid lag;;Goiter;;Tachycardia

Text: Which of the following hormones is not one secreted by the adenohypophysis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Anti-diuretic hormone (also known as vasopressin), along with oxytocin, is secreted from the neurohypophysis (posterior pituitary gland).

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/YcPicFL5Jnw" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Growth hormone (GH);;Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH);;Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH);;Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)

Text: Which of the following is the correct list of rotator cuff muscles?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The four muscles of the rotator cuff are: - Teres minor - Supraspinatus - Infraspinatus - Subscapularis Reference: TeachMeAnatomy - Rotator Cuff Muscles
IncorrectAnswers: Teres minor; teres major; supraspinatus; infraspinatus;;Teres minor; teres major; supraspinatus; subscapularis;;Teres minor; teres major; infraspinatus; subscapularis;;Teres major; supraspinatus; infraspinatus; subscapularis

Text:
Sandra is a 49 year old female with a spinal cord injury at T4. She presents with headache and blurred vision and is found to have hypertension and bradycardia. Percussion of the suprapubic region is dull.

Given the most likely diagnosis, what is the initial management?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This scenario describes a patient suffering from autonomic dysreflexia (AD), a phenomenon seen in those with spinal cord injuries at and above the level of T6. AD is characterised by:
- Flushing and sweating above the level of SCI
- Hypertension and bradycardia

The most important treatment is the reverse the cause of the AD, which is usually due to bladder irritation (e.g. over dilation, infection). In this case, the stem suggests dilation, so passing a urinary catheter should be the first step in management.
IncorrectAnswers:
GTN spray sublingual
;;Hydralazine IV ;;Urgent referral to urology;;Nifedipine IV

Text:
An otherwise healthy 22-year-old male presents with visible haematuria accompanied by flank pain. He has a 2-day history of sore throat, fever, chills, malaise, and headache. Physical examination reveals erythema and inflammation of the uvula and pharynx, enlarged tonsils with patchy greyish-white exudates, and tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy. The rest of the examination is normal. Urinalysis shows cola-coloured urine with haematuria and 3+ protein.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
IgA nephropathy is a glomerulonephritis that generally presents with haematuria in the presence of an underlying infection. Urinalysis will typically show blood and protein in the urine.

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is a similar condition, however PSGN tends to occur around 10-14 days after a preceding infection.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/794YzMoIc28" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Multiple myeloma;;Haemolytic-Uraemic Syndrome;;Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis;;Goodpasture Syndrome

Text: From the Wigger's diagram, what part of the cardiac cycle is occurring just after the initiation of the QRS complex of an ECG?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The QRS complex represents the electrical depolarisation through the ventricle which initiates contraction - systole. The first part of systole is isometric contraction as both semi-lunar and AV valve are shut whilst the pressure in the ventricles is greater than atrial pressure but less than ventricular pressure. Reference
IncorrectAnswers: Rapid ejection;;Atrial Contraction;;Rapid filling;;Isometric relaxation

Text:
Simon, a 46yo presents to the ED complaining eye discomfort. Over the past 12 hours he has experienced increasing pain, visual blurring and watery discharge. Examination with a fluorescein stain reveals the following (see image below).   

Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
HSV keratitis typically presents as an infection of the superficial layer of the cornea, with punctate or diffuse branching (dendritic) lesions of the epithelium that do not usually involve the stroma. Applying topical glucocorticoid drops to the infected eye (without use of concomitant antiviral medication) can exacerbate the infection and potentially lead to involvement of deeper stromal structures with threat to vision
Topical antiviral therapy has been the standard for treatment of dendritic and geographic HSV keratitis in the past, although oral antivirals are equally effective in randomized trials and are now frequently used because of their convenience
IncorrectAnswers: Immediate Ophthalmology referral ;;Topical antibiotics ;;Oral antibiotics ;;Topical glucocorticoids

Text:
Mrs F is a 83 year old lady who has been in hospital following a recent fall. Over the last 6 months she has had 3 other falls and multiple other near misses. There was concern that she may have fractured her hip in this recent fall but the X Rays have return clear and the orthopaedic surgeon is not concerned. She has a history of knee osteoarthritis, hypertension, diabetes with known retinopathy, and urge incontinence. She currently takes panadol osteo, perindopril, amlodipine, indapamide, metformin and amitriptyline. 

Which of the following interventions would be least effective in the prevention of falls?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Hip protectors do not prevent falls, they merely reduce the likelihood of hip fracture if a person has a fall. All of the other options have been shown to reduce the incidence of falls in the elderly.
IncorrectAnswers: Referral to optometrist for formal vision assessment ;;An OT assessment of the home ;;Arrange physiotherapy referral for muscle strengthening and assessment for gait aid ;;Perform a formal medication review

Text: Potassium regulation is important for many body functions. Which of the following is true of potassium sparing diuretics (i.e. amiloride, spironolactone)?
CorrectAnswer: They reduce function of the epithelial sodium channels in the collecting duct (ENaCs) and thus reduce the electrochemical gradient that usually favours K+ secretion
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Potassium sparing diuretics function by impairing the action of aldosterone, a mineralocorticoid that is part of the renin-angiotensin system. In the collecting duct, aldosterone functions normally to increase sodium and water retention. This occurs because aldosterone leads to an increase in sodium channels on the luminal membrane of the nephron, which creates a large shift of sodium from the nephron lumen to inside the tubule cells. This shift is counteracted by a counter-shift of potassium out of the cells into the lumen of the nephron, where the potassium is subsequently excreted. Potassium-sparing diuretics inhibit this process, thus leading to retention of potassium while also promoting fluid and sodium loss.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/OAkbKN6AuWE" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: By blocking the Na+/K+ ATPase, K+-sparing diuretics cause sodium to be excreted favourably compared to K+;;The Ca2+ sensor on the basolateral membrane also senses K+, and the diuretics trick this sensor into thinking there is a lower [K+] in Se than there is resulting in reabsorption;;Since K+ follows water, these diuretics spare K+ being reabsorbed to prevent hyperkalaemia;;They block the Na/K/Cl transporter in the Loop of Henle which spares potassium being lost in the urine

Text:
A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with generalised tremors. He is noted to be anxious, pacing in the hallway. Initial vital signs show he is hypertensive and tachycardic. On further questioning by the nurse he says he is nauseous and wants something to help with the shakes. During physician interview, he admits to heavy alcohol use and that he is trying to cut down on drinking. He also says that he started developing symptoms a few hours after his last drink.

What is the most appropriate initial therapy to treat this patient's symptoms?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: This patient is presenting with symptoms suggestive of acute alcohol withdrawal (tremor, nausea, agitation). The first line treatment for symptomatic alcohol withdrawal is benzodiazepines such as diazepam. While thiamine is important to administer in patients suspected of alcohol dependency (to avoid Wernicke's encephalopathy), it does not treat the symptoms of alcohol withdrawal. Ondansetron would decrease symptoms of nausea and vomiting, however the overall syndrome of alcohol withdrawal is best treated with benzodiazepine medication. Ketamine is an NMDA-receptor antagonist used as for analgesia and anaesthesia, but not in alcohol withdrawal. Cognitive behavioural therapy and other psychotherapies may be useful for long-term treatment of alcohol dependence, however it is not indicated in the acute setting of symptomatic withdrawal. RACGP Guidelines
IncorrectAnswers: Ondansetron;;Cognitive behavioural therapy;;Thiamine;;Ketamine

Text:
Pip is a 28 year old G1P0, who is at 12 weeks gestation. As part of her routine antenatal review you perform a urine dipstick which returns positive for nitrites and white cells. She reports no frequency, urgency or dysuria. Her vitals are all within the normal range. 

Which of the following the most appropriate management?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Asymptomatic bacteriuria should be treated in pregnancy to reduce the risk of cystitis and pyelonephritis, which may harm the developing fetus. The first line regimes for treatment include:
- Cephalexin 500 mg orally, 12-hourly for 5 days
- Nitrofurantoin 100 mg orally, 12-hourly for 5 days
- Amoxycillin+clavulanate 500+125 mg orally, 12-hourly for 5 days
IncorrectAnswers: Pharmacological management is not recommended;;Trimethoprim 300mg orally daily for 3 days   ;;Norfloxacin 400mg orally, 12 hourly for 7 days;;Await urine MCS before commencing treatment

Text:
You are the intern on the palliative care team and your consultant is unfairly quizzing you on the mechanisms and practical considerations of anti-emetic drugs. Little does she know, you actually recently looked these up, and you are able to answer with conviction. 

Which one of the following is an example of a correct response you would have given her?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswer: Both Domperidone and Metoclopramide work on dopamine receptors, but differ as Metoclopramide works centrally as well as peripherally
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Metoclopramide and domperidone function by acting as antagonists at dopamine receptors. However, domperidone acts peripherally only, as it does not cross the blood-brain barrier, whereas metoclopramide does. This has implications for the side effect profile of these drugs, as the cross-reactivity with dopamine receptors in the brain by metoclopramide may elicit extra-pyramidal side effects (EPSEs) whereas domperidone will not cause these side effects.

Olanzapine may be used as an anti-emetic. Metoclopramide is pro-kinetic in the bowel, therefore would be a poor choice in an obstipated patient. However, metoclopramide is the empiric choice of anti-emetic in palliative care given it's efficacy and cost-effectiveness. Ondansetron is often used first in clinical practice however due to clinician preference. Also, nausea and vomiting should not be treated empirically: the cause of nausea and vomiting should be sought prior to beginning anti-emetic therapy.
IncorrectAnswers: When prescribing anti-emetics you should never consider the mechanism that could be causing the nausea and vomiting;;Metaclopramide is an excellent choice of anti-emetic in a patient who is obstipated;;If you were going to treat nausea and vomiting empirically you would start with Ondansetron;;Olanzapine is not used as an anti-emetic medication

Text:
Sigrid is on her third day on the surgical ward, recovering from diverticulitis when she becomes develops a temperature of 38 degrees, becomes tachycardic and tachypnoeic. You order a chest xray which is shown below. 

What is the most likely cause of Sigrid's pain?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The chest xray shows pneumoperitonism (air in the peritoneal cavity, which is evident from the air lying under the diaphragm); suggesting a bowel perforation.
IncorrectAnswers: Pulmonary Embolism;;Pneumonia;;Ruptured peptic ulcer;;Pneumothorax

Text:
A 32-year-old woman is booked for an elective C-section at 37 weeks due to gestational diabetes. She undergoes spinal anaesthesia successfully. Some time later, the anaesthetist notices a fall in the patient s blood pressure. 

What is the reason for this, and the appropriate pharmacological management?
CorrectAnswer: Reduction of sympathetic tone on systemic vessels due to spinal block   treatment with vasopressor to raise blood pressure
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Spinal anaesthesia inhibits the sympathetic neurons that lie in the thoracolumbar region of the spinal cord. Reducing the firing of these neurons leads to vasodilation via decreased sympathetic tone (i.e. noradrenaline binding to alpha-adrenoceptors on vascular smooth muscle), and there decreased mean arterial pressure.

Hypotension associated with spinal anaesthesia can be managed effectively with vasopressors, which act to increase vascular tone. This is achieved with drugs such as noradrenaline, ephedrine and metaraminol.

The parasympathetic generally does not influence the tone on systemic vessels, ruling out A, B and C. Inotropes are used for the management of cardiogenic shock and occasionally septic shock, not treatment of anaesthesia-induced hypotension.
IncorrectAnswers: Reduction of sympathetic tone on systemic vessels due to spinal block   treatment with inotrope to raise blood pressure;;Reduction of parasympathetic tone on systemic vessels due to spinal block   treatment with inotrope to raise blood pressure;;Increase in parasympathetic tone on systemic vessels due to spinal block   treatment with atropine to raise blood pressure;;Reduction of parasympathetic tone on systemic vessels due to spinal block   treatment with vasopressor to raise blood pressure

Text:
A mother brings in her 5 year old son to the ED. She is frantic and concerned her son is gasping for air. She tells you he s been coughing at night for the past two days and been uncharacteristically inactive. You suspect the child is having an acute asthma attack, despite no history of asthma. There is no audible wheeze. The child is tachypnoeic, looks exhausted and hungry for air. There is significant tracheal tug, tripoding and intercostal recession when you remove his t shirt. 

What is the most appropriate first step in management?
CorrectAnswer: Nebulised Salbutamol 5mg + Atrovent 500 units with oxygen STAT and subsequent continuous nebulised salbutamol
CorrectAnswerExplanation: It is important to recognise that this child is critically ill, with respiratory distress and exhaustion. You should always be wary of the silent chest in a unwell child with asthma. Reference: Australian Asthma Handbook An exhausted child will struggle to use a spacer. Hyrdrocortisone would be part of ongoing management, but not first step.
IncorrectAnswers: Initiate hour of power using salbutamol inhaler and Volumatic spacer;;Reassure the mother as there is no wheeze;;I/V Hydrocortisone 100mg ;;Oxygen via non-rebreather mask and I/M Adrenalin 500mcg

Text:
A 66-year-old man presents with a 24 hour  history of visual loss in his left eye that began suddenly yesterday. He wears glasses for short-sightedness, and had successful cataract surgery 2 years ago. He has never injured his eyes in the past, and has had no other ocular conditions. There was no pain was associated with the vision loss, and his blood pressure is well controlled with perindopril. The patient describes the loss of vision as a veil covering the visual field. On questioning, the patient reports experiencing visual flashes and floaters over the last 48 hours.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Retinal detachment (RD) is a condition associated with sudden, painless vision loss. This patient has several risk factors for retinal detachment including age, myopia and previous cataract surgery. A history of flashes and floaters is also suggestive of RD. Temporal Arteritis would present with headache and jaw claudication along with vision loss. There is often a history of concomitant polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR). Temporal Arteritis (AKA Giant Cell Arteritis) classically has a significantly raised ESR, and is treated with high dose corticosteroids ASAP to avoid vision loss. Optic neuritis is a condition closely associated with Multiple Sclerosis (MS), of which it is a common first presentation. The acute vision loss associated with optic neuritis differs from RD as it is painful, especially on eye movement. Diabetic retinopathy is seen in poorly controlled diabetes, where there is gradual loss of vision (i.e. not sudden loss as seen in the above stem). If diabetic retinopathy was the correct answer, there would have been a history diabetes in the patient, as associated retinopathy takes many years to develop. Central retinal artery occlusion presents similarly to RD, however it is not usually associated with flashes and floaters. NOTE: For any patient complaining of sudden loss of vision, this almost always requires immediate and urgent referral to an ophthalmologist. Reference: NSW Eye Emergency Manual.
IncorrectAnswers: Central retinal artery occlusion;;Temporal arteritis;;Optic neuritis;;Diabetic retinopathy

Text:
Johan, a 68 year old male presents to ED after developing a severe unilateral headache. The headache has been increasing in intensity over the past 24 hours, and in the past 20 minutes he has lost vision in the ipsilateral eye. He described sudden vision loss, like a curtain coming down over his eye. 

Given the likely diagnosis, what is the most appropriate next step?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Giant Cell Arteritis; Symptoms include jaw claudication, severe headache, visual symptoms, scalp tenderness and malaise.

Elevated ESR and CRP are common, however ESR may be normal initially. 

Management (eTG); If there is strong clinical suspicion, start treatment immediately, without waiting for histological confirmation  
-Immediate methylprednisolone 1g IV (for patients with visual symptoms) 
-For patients without visual symptoms: 40-60mg oral pred

100% oxygen is the treatment of cluster headaches
IncorrectAnswers: Temporal Artery Biopsy ;;100% Oxygen at 10L/min via a nonrebreather mask ;;Immediate CT brain;;Prednisolone 60mg orally

Text:
Harry is a 74-year-old male who presents to pre-admission clinic for review prior to a planned elective hernia repair. He has a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia and ischemic heart disease. Harry states that several weeks ago, he experienced a bad bout of chest pain while on holiday, which was diagnosed as a NSTEMI and managed conservatively. His current medications include telmisartan, atenolol, atorvastatin and aspirin. On examination, you note a pulse of 80 with a relatively normal blood pressure of 132/92. You take an ECG, which reveals the following finding (see below) that was not present on ECGs prior to Harry s NSTEMI.

Which artery was most likely implicated in Harry s recent myocardial infarction?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The above ECG shows complete heart block, with total dissociation between the atrial rate (P wave frequency) and ventricular rate (R wave frequency). This implies that there is a conduction defect that has effectively blocked signal conduction between the atria and the ventricles. This is most likely to have occurred in the region of the AV node, which is supplied in the vast majority of people by the right coronary artery.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/iiinZvwBSuE?ecver=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Left anterior descending artery;;Left coronary artery;;Left circumflex artery;;Left marginal artery

Text:
A 18 year old boy presents to ED form football training with a sore ankle after landing awkwardly in a drill. He has been unable to weight bare since the incident (over an hour ago). His foot is swollen and he is apprehensive to move it. On examination, he is not tender at the base of the 5th, navicular bone or in the 6cm above the posterior-medial malleolus. 

Which of the following is true about his management?
CorrectAnswer: X Ray required regardless if he is tender on palpation of the lateral posterior malleolus (inc. 6cm above)
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The Ottawa Ankle Rules state that an ankle X ray is required if there is pain in the malleolar zones (medially and laterally), and one of the following are present:
1. Bony tenderness at the posterior edge or tip of the lateral malleolus
2. Bony tenderness at the posterior edge or tip of the medial malleolus
3. Inability to weight bear both immediately and in ED

The Ottawa Ankle Rules also include criteria for foot X ray, which are required if there is pain in the midfoot zone, as well as one of the following:
1. Bony tenderness at the base of the 5th metatarsal
2. Bony tenderness at the navicular
3. Inability to weight bear both immediately and in ED

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/KDkkhGZF1TI" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: MRI of foot & ankle required as fracture is unlikely to be seen on X Ray;;X Ray required only if he is tender on palpation of the lateral anterior malleolus (inc. 6cm above);;X Ray required only if he is tender on palpation of the lateral posterior malleolus (inc. 6cm above);;No X Ray required

Text:
John, a 69-year-old male presents to ED on a particularly hot summer s day. His family brought him in as they found him sitting on his porch alone, looking parched and confused. On further questioning, you learn that John has a history of congestive cardiac failure, for which he takes spironolactone and metoprolol, as well as type 1 diabetes which requires regular insulin injections. He also takes perindopril for hypertension. A set of basic bloods are taken and an ECG is performed. He is noted to have a raised potassium of 6.4mmol/L, with peaked T waves on his ECG. Finger prick blood glucose monitoring reveal a blood sugar level of 21.2mmol/L, and mildly raised ketones.

Which of the following is LEAST likely to have caused John s hyperkalaemia?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Of the above list of potential causes of John s hyperkalaemia, underlying congestive cardiac failure (CCF) is the least likely contributor. With CCF, the failure of the heart to pump and thus adequately perfuse the body s organs leads to renal hypoperfusion. Renal hypoperfusion results in a fall in GFR, which stimulates renin to convert angiotensinogen to angiotensin I, which is followed by conversion to angiotensin II by angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE). Angiotensin II causes release of aldosterone from the adrenal cortex, which then acts on renal tubule collecting ducts to reabsorb sodium and water, while excreting potassium. Thus, CCF may lead to increased renin-angiotensin-aldosterone activity, thus causing hypokalaemia.

Spironolactone inhibits aldosterone by acting as an antagonist at the mineralocorticoid receptor, thus revering the excretion of potassium from the kidneys. Perindopril and other ACE inhibitors may cause hyperkalaemia through decreased GFR, which is caused by preferential relaxation of the efferent arteriole. Ketoacidosis (or any acidotic state) increases serum potassium concentration through exchange of hydrogen ions with potassium ions in various cells. Acute kidney injury essentially impairs the kidney s ability to excrete potassium from the body, thus leading to accumulation and hyperkalaemia. 

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/JpkIOlFhyJo?ecver=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Perindopril;;Ketoacidosis;;Acute kidney injury secondary to hypovolemia;;Spironolactone

Text:
A 26-year-old male presents to ED with a painful left eye and impaired vision. He was working as a metal-worker, and felt sudden onset pain in his left eye when he was operating machinery with no eye protection. You inspect the eye (see image below), and record his visual acuity, which is markedly reduced on the left side compared to the right.

What is the most appropriate course of action?
CorrectAnswer: Immediate referral to ophthalmologist, arrange CT scan of orbit, commence broad spectrum IV antibiotics
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This presentation is suggestive of a penetrating eye injury, which requires immediate review by an ophthalmologist. A CT scan of the orbit should be conducted to assess for retained foreign body in the eye. Broad spectrum IV antibiotics should also be commenced.

This is an ocular emergency, as the patient is at risk of permanent blindness if not treated immediately by an ophthalmologist. CT imaging is the preferred imaging modality as it is more sensitive in detecting and locating foreign bodies.

Reference: NSW Eye Emergency Manual
IncorrectAnswers: Provide topical steroids and chloramphenicol eyedrops, refer patient to follow-up with GP in 7 days;;Referral to outpatient ophthalmologist, arrange plain X-ray of orbit, give topical steroid eyedrops for pain relief;;Referral to outpatient ophthalmologist, arrange CT scan of orbit, give topical steroid eyedrops for pain relief;;Immediate referral to ophthalmologist, arrange CT scan of orbit, commence topical chloramphenicol

Text:
Mr JD is a 78 year old gentleman who is currently on the GEM ward following a fall at home. While on the ward, he becomes confused and it is evident that he is having visual hallucinations. The nurse from the night previous informs you that Mr JD did not sleep well last night and was quite agitated. A dipstick was performed on Mr JD which was cloudy and positive for leukocytes and nitrites. Mr JD has a past history including hypertension, peripheral vascular disease, diabetes and along with appropriate medications for this he is known to take Levodopa and Carbidopa.

Of the following, which is most contraindicated in Mr JD?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Typical (first generation) antipsychotics are contraindicated in this patient, as the stem suggests he has Parkinson's Disease (evident by his medications including levodopa and carbidopa). Typical antipsychotics are associated with the extra-pyramidal side effects of parkinsonism, tardive dyskinesia, akathisia and acute dystonia.

Low stimulus environments and one to one nursing are appropriate therapy for delirium (which this patient has). While lorazepam is not indicated in delirium or Parkinson's Disease, it does not have the same significant side effects seen in those taking haloperidol or other typical antipsychotics. Atypical antipsychotics are less likely to cause extra-pyramidal side effects, therefore making them safer to use in this population than haloperidol.
IncorrectAnswers: One to one nursing;;Lorazepam ;;Low stimulus environment;;Atypical antipsychotic therapy

Text:
Millicent, a 46 year old presents to your general practice complaining of eczema of the nipple. On examination you note a small amount of excoriation around the right nipple extending from the duct. 

What is the most appropriate next step?
CorrectAnswer: Immediate referral to breast surgeon for biopsy
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Paget s disease: Ductal carcinoma that invades the nipple with scaling. Accounts for 1-3% of invasive breast cancers. Patient requires triple test: clinical examination, imaging and biopsy.
IncorrectAnswers: Prescribe steroid cream, review in 2 weeks ;;Routine referral to breast surgeon (6 week wait);;Referral to dermatology ;;Reassurance

Text:
Margaret is recovering from the delivery of her 3rd child when she requests contraception as approximately 9 months ago she discovered that breastfeeding was ineffective. She intends to breastfeed this child.
 
Which of the following is not recommended whilst breastfeeding?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
In postpartum women who do not breastfeed, ovulation returns at a mean of 39 days postpartum (earliest ovulation reported 25 days after delivery). As many as 60 percent of these ovulations are potentially fertile. Since the first ovulation often occurs before the first menses, we educate women that return of menses cannot be used as a reliable marker for when to initiate contraception.

For breastfeeding women, the resumption of ovulation appears to be influenced by the frequency and duration of breastfeeding.

Impact of lactation   Women who exclusively breastfeed typically have a delay in resumption of ovulation postpartum due to prolactin-induced inhibition of pulsatile gonadotropin-releasing hormone release from the hypothalamus. The degree to which breastfeeding suppresses ovulation is modulated by the intensity of the breastfeeding, the basal nutritional status of the mother, and the body mass index of the mother. 

While breastfeeding is associated with subfertility, anovulation is likely only when all of the following specific conditions are met:
Ï%Less than six months postpartum
Ï%Breastfeeding exclusively (ie, not providing food or other liquid to the infant and no interval of >4 to 6 hours between feeding episodes)
Ï%Amenorrhea

Under these conditions, there is approximately 98 percent protection from pregnancy. Oestrogen containing contraception is not considered compatible with breastfeeding since oestrogens suppress breast milk production.
IncorrectAnswers: Mirena;;Barrier methods;;Progesterone only pill ;;Depo-Provera

Text: Which of the following nerves innervates the muscles of mastication?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The muscles of mastication (e.g. masseter, temporalis) are innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve.
IncorrectAnswers:
Facial nerve (CN VII)   Zygomatic branch
;;Trigeminal nerve   Opthalmic nerve (CN V1);;Facial nerve (CN VII)   Marginal mandibular branch;;Trigeminal nerve   Maxillary nerve (CN V2)

Text:
James, a 13 year old has noticed a small lump in his neck, just to the right of the midline. The lump is non tender, mobile and well defined. The lump elevates when you ask Jameson to protrude his tongue.
 
What is the most likely cause of the lump?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Thyroglossal Duct Cyst:
The thyroid originates as a ventral midline diverticuluc at the base of the tongue caudal to the junction of the 3rd and 4th branchial arches and migrates down to the inferior aspect of the neck. Thyroglossal duct cysts are vestigal remnants of the tract. They usually present in childhood or during 20-40s as a midline cyst that enlarges with URTI and elevates with swallowing and tongue protrusion. 

Treatment: pre-operative antibiotics to reduce inflammation
Small potential for neoplastic transformation so complete excision of cyst and tissue around tract up to to base of tongue recommended
IncorrectAnswers: Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid;;Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid;;Branchial cleft cyst ;;Lymphoma

Text:
A 3 year old boy presents for his second visit to see you. Two days ago he was seen with a 4-day history of intermittent fever spiking 400C and irritability. His examination at that time was remarkable for bilateral conjunctivitis, oropharyngeal injection, and dry, cracked lips. He was sent home with instructions for symptomatic care. Today he returns with persistent fever and irritability. The physical findings noted previously are still present, but now he has a maculopapular truncal rash and a large right anterior cervical lymph node.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
(1) Acute medium-sized vessel vasculitis of unknown aetiology (NOT contagious)
ð  Can affect coronaries and cause aneurysm hence importance of diagnosis (most common cause of acquired heart disease in children in developed countries). Need an ECHO
(2) Diagnostic criteria = fever > 5 days + 4 of CREAM
ð  Conjunctivitis (non-purulent, bilateral)
ð  Rash (polymorphous)
ð  Erythema/Oedema (peripheral oedema and erythema, desquamation)
ð  Adenopathy (cervical lymphadenopathy >1.5cm, typically unilateral, single)
ð  Mucosal involvement (red fissured cracked lips, strawberry tongue, injected pharynx)
(3) Treatment
ð  Admission for IVIG and aspirin (one of the few exceptions to withholding
aspirin in children due to Rey syndrome)
ð  Echo (at least twice: at initial presentation and, if negative, again in 6-8 weeks)

Scarlet fever: Group A strep, rash that affects the face (red cheeks, pale mouth). 
Stevens-Johnson syndrome: a rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes. It's usually a reaction to a medication or an infection. Often, it begins with flu-like symptoms, followed by a painful red or purplish rash that spreads and blisters.
IncorrectAnswers: Acute rheumatic fever;;Scarlet fever;;Systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis;;Stevens-Johnson syndrome

Text:
A 6-year-old girl has had vomiting and central abdominal pain for 3 days. She has eczema and poorly controlled asthma. She looks pale and has a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 11/15. Her abdomen is generally tender, but there is no rigidity, rebound, or guarding. Bowel sounds are present and normal. Her respiratory rate is 36 breaths/minute, with no recession. Her heart rate is 160 bpm and her capillary refill time is 4 seconds. She is given a 20 mL/kg bolus of fluid. Blood tests show:
Ï% Haemoglobin 13 g/dL
Ï% White cell count 22 × 109/L **** high
Ï% C-reactive protein 25 mg/L **** high
Ï% Sodium 120 mmol/L **** low
Ï% Potassium 6.8 mmol/L **** high
Ï% Urea 9.3 mmol/L **** high
Ï% Creatinine 110 ¼mol/L. **** high

Which is the single most important next investigation?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
With any sick child, remember ABCDEFG Airway, Breathing, Circulation and Don t Ever Forget Glucose. This girl is shocked and dehydrated, and has altered consciousness and a relative hyponatraemia and hyperkalaemia caused by hyperglycaemia. 

The diagnosis is diabetic ketoacidosis, and a capillary blood glucose test will confirm this.

Abdominal ultrasound = gall stones or free fluid in the abdomen
CT scan head = hypertension + bradycardia, neurological symptoms, unwitnessed fall with head strike
Serum ammonia = severe liver or kidney disease ...even then it will rarely be the right answer
Urine osmolality = SIADH serum < urine
IncorrectAnswers: CT scan of the head;;Serum ammonia;;Urine osmolality;;Abdominal ultrasound scan

Text: Which is the correct description of the ligaments of the shoulder?
CorrectAnswer: The coracoclavicular ligament consists of the trapezoid and conoid ligaments
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The coracoclavicular ligaments are attached to the coracoid process and the distal portion of the clavicle. They are strong reinforcers of the shoulder girdle. Reference: TeachMeAnatomy - Shoulder
IncorrectAnswers: The glenohumeral joint is stabilised by the anterior and posterior glenohumeral ligaments, and the trapezoid ligament;;The coracohumeral ligament consists of the trapezoid and conoid ligaments;;The transverse humeral ligament joins the acromion and the greater trochanter of the humerus;;The sternoclavicular joint is stabilised by the costoclavicular ligament and coracoacromial ligaments

Text: Which of the following best describes the action of vasopressin (ADH) in the kidney?
CorrectAnswer: Its action results in upregulation of aquaporins to promote water retention
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Vasopressin is released from the posterior pituitary gland in response to increased plasma osmolality and other stimuli. In the kidney, vasopressin leads to aquaporins becoming inserted into the luminal collecting duct membrane to promote water retention.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/8dQdfbE8kFU?ecver=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: It blocks the Na+/K+ ATPase to reduce blood volume;;It is a steroid hormone that binds intracellularly to alter gene transcription;;It works on the collecting duct to upregulate ENaCs at the apical membrane;;It is a peptide hormone that binds intracellularly to alter gene transcription

Text:
A 68-year-old man is in ICU on postoperative day 6 for a coronary artery bypass graft. He was initially extubated on postoperative day 1, but was then re-intubated the following day for presumed aspiration pneumonia, which had worsened despite administration of IV penicillin and gentamicin. His current medications also include frusemide, aspirin, and clexane. One hour ago, he passed a large volume of black tarry stool. His temperature is 38.8, blood pressure is 180/94 mmHg, and pulse is 102/min. Coarse crackles are heard bilaterally. He has a regular, rapid heart rhythm with a soft systolic murmur. His abdomen is soft with mild epigastric tenderness, however no masses are palpable. Rectal examination reveals no masses, but melaena is present on withdrawal of the gloved finger. Pathology shows a raised white cell count and reduced haemoglobin. 

Which of the following is the most likely source of this patient's bleeding?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Gastric ulcers are a common occurrence in ICU patients, due to the stress response initiated by the patient's severe illness. As such, PPI prophylaxis is commonly prescribed.

This clinical picture is suggestive of an upper GI bleed, which rules out cecal arterial venous malformations. Erosive oesophagitis and diffuse gastritis are less likely to cause significant upper GI bleeding. Varices are usually accompanied by a history of chronic alcoholism and liver disease.
IncorrectAnswers: Diffuse gastritis;;Oesophageal varices;;Cecal arterial venous malformations;;Erosive oesophagitis

Text:
A 40-year old man complains of widespread pruritis for the past 2 weeks. The itching is particularly bad at night time, and is disrupting his sleep. On examination he has numerous linear erythematous lesions between his fingers and toes. 

Given the most likely diagnosis, what is the first line treatment?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This is a characteristic description of a presentation of someone infected with scabies. The mite burrows into the skin, quite typically between the fingers and toes. The first line management is 5% permethrin, and it is important to tell your patients that the pruritis does last for 4-6 weeks post-eradication. 

Reference: http://www.dermnetnz.org/topics/scabies/
IncorrectAnswers:
Simple analgesia;;Wait for it to pass, but avoid contacting people
;;Referal to dermatologist;;Topical corticosteroids

Text:
A 10-year old boy presents to his GP with a sore throat that has been present for several days. On examination it is found he has tonsilitis with exudate and cervical lymhadenopathy. The patient is febrile, tachycardic and tachypnoeic. You notice a rash of tiny pinkish-red spots that cover the whole body. Auscultation of the chest is clear.

How should this patient be managed?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: This question is detailing a case of scarlet fever (Group A strep tonsillitis with the typical rash). The first line treatment for this is Penicillin V and paracetamol (for analgesic and antipyretic effect). Aspirin should never be given to children (except in Kawasaki Syndrome) due to the risk of developing Reye's syndrome. Steroids are part of the the first-line management for Croup, not tonsillitis. Clarithromycin is the second-line antibiotic used for scarlet fever. Paracetamol alone would not treat this child, as they need antibiotic therapy. Reference: RCH Clinical Practice Guidelines
IncorrectAnswers: Single dose of oral Dexamethasone 0.15mg/kg;;Clarithromycin and paracetamol;;Paracetamol only;;Aspirin only

Text:
A 6-year-old boy has had vomiting for 24 hours and has been unable to keep any liquids down, although he has not wanted to eat any food. Today he has central abdominal pain, which was coming and going but is now constant and sharp. He has pain when he tries to pass urine, and gets very upset if he is moved. He has opened his bowels once today and passed a loose stool. 

Which is the single most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Appendicitis is the commonest cause of acute abdomen, and should not be forgotten in children. It is rare in children under 5 years, and becomes more common with increasing age thereafter. The classic presentation is with central, colicky abdominal pain, which then spreads to the right iliac fossa and becomes constant in nature. However, the pain may not always be in a classic position, so other clues need to be looked for. Vomiting is almost universal, together with associated anorexia. Loose stool and dysuria may occur as a result of irritation from the inflamed appendix, so in a child with other symptoms one should not automatically assume that these are due to simple gastroenteritis or urinary tract infection.
IncorrectAnswers: Gastro-oesophageal reflux;;Mesenteric adenitis;;Volvulus;;Viral gastroenteritis

Text: Congestive heart failure is a condition in which, for whatever reason, the heart is unable to pump blood effectively to the circulation to maintain perfusion, leading to congestion in the circulatory system. Which of the following mechanisms is intended to correct the problem and return the body to homeostasis?
CorrectAnswer: All of the systems listed here are activated in the intent to return to homeostasis
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
All of these systems are intended to correct problems; the first 3 are predominantly due to hypoxia and reduced perfusion and are intended to increased blood pressure, while the NP system is intended to reduced cardiac workload (on an already stressed heart).

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/x8aBKMYqGPY" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Chemoreceptor reflex;;Baroreceptor reflex;;RAAS;;Natriuretic peptide system

Text:
A 75-year-old man with diabetes and osteoarthritis is evaluated in your clinic for recurring falls.

Which of the following is most predictive of future dependence in his activities of daily living?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswer: Taking 23 seconds to rise from a chair, walk three metres, turn around, and sit down in the chair
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Patients who suffer from falls are at the greatest risk of requiring future dependence on support in their activities of daily living. The timed up and go (TUG) test should take no more than 10 seconds. Patients who require more than 10 seconds to perform this task are at a significantly increased falls risk, which will therefore make them at a significant risk of requiring support in their ADLs into the future.

While osteoporosis (DEXA Scan with T-score of -2.7), orthostatic hypotension, peripheral neuropathy and cognitive impairment are all risk factors for future decline in function and thus increased support in ADLs requirement, they are not as predictive as a prolonged TUG test.
IncorrectAnswers: A greater than 20 mmHg drop in systolic blood pressure from sitting to standing;;A MMSE score of 20 / 30;;Impaired two-point discrimination in his lower extremities;;A DEXA scan with T-score of -2.7

Text:
Philip, a 68 year old male presents to your clinic complaining of intense constant calf pain that began this morning. The pain occurs from his thigh to his feet, but not in his buttock. He has previously experienced this pain on his morning walks. The pain would come on after about 200m and subside with 5 minutes of rest. 
Phillip is a current smoker, and has type 2 diabetes. His BMI is 40.   

What is the most likely cause?
CorrectAnswer: Thrombotic occlusion of the external iliac
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Thrombotic occlusion: gradual occlusion of blood vessel allowing time for the development of a collateral blood supply. Usually occurs in vasculopaths; smoking, overweight and diabetes. 
The external iliac becomes the superficial femoral artery as it passes underneath the inguinal ligament. This supplies the leg from the thigh down. The internal iliac has a branch that supplies the gluteal muscles.   

Embolic occlusion occurs rapidly, with the pain onset occurring over seconds. The original source of the clot must be identified and treated.
IncorrectAnswers: Embolic occlusion of the internal iliac;;Embolic occlusion of the external iliac;;Thrombotic occlusion of the common iliac;;Embolic occlusion of the common iliac

Text:
A 58-year-old man has unremitting right-sided chest pain, worse on deep inspiration and coughing. He has urinary hesitancy, diminished stream, and post-micturition dribbling. He is tender in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, and in the lower chest on palpation of the costal margin and lower ribs. His abdomen is soft. He has a hard enlarged prostate. His alkaline phosphatase is 260U/L. 

Which is the single most appropriate initial investigation?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This man is presenting with signs and symptoms highly suggestive of prostate cancer that has metastasised to bone. The tenderness over the lower chest and ribs indicates secondary cancer in the ribs, which is consistent with the high alkaline phosphatase. At this stage, it is important to exclude any underlying lung pathologies that could be causing the chest pain, which is best done with a chest x-ray. This scan will also show bone metastases if they are present radiologically. 

An abdominal x-ray and ultrasound will not show the metastases here. A transrectal ultrasound is indicated to stage the primary tumour, and gain information on its morphology. The serum PSA test is a screening test, and should not be used in confirming the diagnosis of prostate cancer.
IncorrectAnswers: Transrectal ultrasound scan ;;Serum prostate specific antigen ;;Abdominal X-ray;;Abdominal ultrasound

Text:
A 12 year old girl presents to the ED unable to weight bear after landing awkwardly on her right ankle when playing netball. An X-ray is taken (see opposite) 

What type of Salter-Harris Fracture is this?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The fracture in this X ray extends through the growth plate, from above and below, thus it is a Salter-Harris IV. See Radiopaedia for more information.
IncorrectAnswers: V;;II;;I;;III

Text:
Pablo, an 86 year old male presents to the ED after spiking a temperature at the nursing home where he lives. On admission he is confused and disorientated. The nursing home records suggest that he is currently being treated for a lower limb cellulitis with flucloxacillin and vancomycin.

His vitals are as follows:
HR 130
BP 90/60
Temperature: 40.2 
O2: 97% 
RR: 16 
BSL: 5.6

After blood cultures are sent, and fluids commenced, which regimen of empiric antibiotics is recommended?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Empirical therapy for sepsis in adults: 
Without MRSA risk factors: empiric treatment: Gentamicin and Flucloxacilin    
Sepsis of unknown origin in a patient with risk factors for MRSA (nursing home, previous infection), give Piperacillin and Tazobactam

Likely respiratory source: Piperacillin and tazobactum
Likely urinary source: Gentamycin and amoxicillin 
Likely GIT: Gentamicin, amoxicillin and metronidazole
Likely Biliary: Gentamycin and amoxicillin
IncorrectAnswers: Continue Flucloxacilin and vancomycin;;Benzylpenicillin + Ceftriexone;;Gentamicin + Flucloxacillin;;Benzylpenicillin + Doxycycline

Text:
A 48 year old man is BIBA with acute back pain following an accident at work. He has central back pain in the L4-5 area with shooting pain down both legs. His pain is excruciating an preventing him from walking. He has no history of back pain, is on no regular medications and is fit and well. You conduct an examination, noting his pants are wet. 

Which of the following findings would be most alarming?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: This scenario depicts cauda equina syndrome. The mnemonic SPINE (saddle anaesthesia, pain, incontinence, numbness, emergency) is worthwhile knowing. This requires urgent neurosurgery consultation, as paralysis and ongoing neuraxial impairment may result if not treated rapidly.
IncorrectAnswers: Positive slump test in both legs (R>L) ;;Reduced sensation bilaterally in the lateral calf;;Pain on passive flexion of both hips;;Tenderness in the paravertebral column at L4/5

Text: Which of the following parts of the ECG is representative of the time of AV node conduction delay?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Atrial contraction begins at the commencement of the P wave, and ends at the commencement of the QRS complex. Passage of the cardiac action potential through the AV node involves a slowing/delay, allowing the ventricles to adequately fill prior to ventricular contraction. The PR interval represents the time between the wave of depolarisation reaching the AV node, to the point of ventricular depolarisation and contraction.
IncorrectAnswers: QT Interval;;ST Segment;;QRS Complex;;P Wave

Text:
Mr V is a 82 year old gentlemen who has been brought into your clinic as his wife is concerned about his recent behaviour. As the patient enters the room you notice that his movements are slow and that he has a shuffling gait. When he is sitting you further notice that he has a tremor and upon assessing his tone he is noted to have cogwheel rigidity. 

Given the likely diagnosis, which of the following best describes the tremor likely to be seen?
Topics: General Medicine(Year 3);;Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswer: Unilateral tremor that improves with voluntary movement
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This patient has the classic symptoms of Parkinson's Disease (PD): rigidity, tremor and bradykinesia. Shuffling gait is also pathognomonic of PD.

The tremor of PD typically improves when the patient is distracted by asking them to carry out a specific movement. The tremor tends to be asymmetric, in keeping with the asymmetric pattern of degeneration of the basal ganglia structures that underpin the pathology of PD.
IncorrectAnswers: Coarse symmetrical tremor that improves when patient is distracted ;;Symmetrical tremor that worsens when arms outstretched ;;Tremor is not seen in this pathology, and is likely a result of another condition ;;Tremor that increases as the patient tries to reach the examiners finger

Text: Examine the following pathological image of a thyroid specimen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Papillary carcinoma can be identified on histology by Orphan Annie nuclei (nuclei with uniform staining, which appear empty due to powdery chromatin and marginal micronucleoli) and Psammoma bodies (collections of calcium).

Follicular adenoma and adenomcarcinomas is very difficult to distinguish on histology.
IncorrectAnswers: Graves  disease;;Normal thyroid specimen;;Follicular adenocarcinoma;;Follicular adenoma

Text:
Parents bring their 4 week old son to see you at the Paediatric Outpatient rooms because they are concerned. They report over the past day or so he has been vomting a lot, and seems to be sleeping more than usual. Despite this he is still maintaining his appetite. He seems lethargic to you. 

What is the most likely provisional diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This is a classical explanaiton of pyloric stenosis. Other buzzwords that would help you be more confident making this diagnosis are: hypochloraemic hypokalaemic metabolic alkalosis, peristalsis in LUQ, non-bilious vomitting, projectile vomting. 

If it was GORD, the stem would give more clues indicating that this happens more commonly directly after eating. It would also not be projectile, but more so 'spitting up' of milk.

Cow's milk allergy would be indicated by GIT symptoms (vomiting, diarrhoea, blood in stools), but also typical allergic reactions, such as hives.

Hirschprung's disease is a congenital anomaly of the rotation of the midgut. For this to be the correct response, the stem would indicate bilious vomiting, crampy abdo pain, a distended abdomen, and presence of blood and mucous in stool.

Malrotation of the gut is a form of megacolon that results in diffculty passing stool. For this to be the correct response, the stem would indicate that a newborn has not passed a bowel motion within the first 24-48h of life.
IncorrectAnswers: Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease;;Cow's milk protein allergy;;Malrotation of the gut;;Hirschprung's disease

Text:
Thelma, a 34 year old weight lifter, presents to your clinic after being unable to conceive for 18 months. She reports irregular menstruation. On examination she has a BMI of 32, and evidence of facial hirsutism. 

Which of the following interventions should be prescribed as a first line to increase Thelma s probability of conception?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Clomiphene is the first line treatment for infertility related to PCOS. 

Although Metformin is used widely it is not considered the first line agent and has less evidence than Clomiphene. It may be considered if this patient had evidence of insulin resistance, however this is not mentioned in the stem. 

Levonorgestrel 125mg plus ethinyloestradiol 50mg is a high dose combined oral contraceptive pill and is useful to regulate the cycle in patients with PCOS, however it is going to prevent pregnancy. 

The other two agents are used to regulate menstruation when the COCP is contraindicated. 

Source: eTG
IncorrectAnswers: Referral for commencement of IVF treatment;;Norethisterone 5 mg orally;;Levonorgestrel 125mg plus ethinyloestradiol 50mg;;Medroxyprogesterone acetate 150mg/mL IM

Text: Which of the following is false regarding the anatomy of the thyroid?
CorrectAnswer: The anterior relations of the thyroid include the sternohyoid muscle and hyoid bone
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The hyoid bone sits in the superior portion of the neck, whereas the thyroid gland is in the inferior portion. The sternohyoid muscle indeed does lie anterior to the thyroid gland as it traverses down the neck from its attachment at the hyoid bone.
IncorrectAnswers:
Approximately 10% of people have an artery that supplies the thyroid isthmus with
blood;;The thyroid is located in the neck, approximately between the levels of C5-T1;;The superior and inferior thyroid arteries arise from the external carotid and
thyrocervical trunk;;The thyroid veins form a plexus around the thyroid on the anterior surface

Text:
A 65-year-old man presents to ED. He has a history of small cell lung cancer and ischaemic heart disease. His cancer was diagnosed five months ago and he has recently completed a course of chemotherapy. From a cardiac point of view he had a myocardial infarction two years ago following which he had primary angioplasty with stent placement. He has had no angina since. 

For the past week he has become increasingly short-of-breath. This is worse at night and is associated with an occasional non-productive cough. He has also noticed that his wedding ring feels tight. Clinical examination is of his chest is unremarkable. He does however have distended neck veins and periorbital oedema. 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: SVC Obstruction can occur due to compression by a tumour. The clinical signs of increasing dyspnoea, swelling of face and upper limbs and distended neck veins make this the most likely diagnosis in this context.
IncorrectAnswers: Nephrotic Syndrome secondary to chemotherapy;;Hypercalcemia;;Tumour Lysis Syndrome;;Heart Failure secondary to chemotherapy

Text:
Henrietta is a 39 year old urology trainee who presents to your gynaecology clinic after not menstruating for 6 months. Her past medical history includes anxiety, for which she takes fluoxetine. She has no family history of breast, endometrial, or ovarian cancer. 

Investigations reveal the following:    
BHCG - Negative
FSH - Elevated
LH - Elevated
Estradiol - Undetectable 
TSH/Prolactin - NAD 

What is the optimal length of Hormone Replacement Therapy in this patient?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
As per eTG and BMJ Best Practice guidelines, women with premature or early menopause should be treated with HRT. The recommended duration of HRT is at least until the median age of menopause (i.e. 51 years).  Hence in this case 12 years is the correct answer. Note this does not preclude individual circumstances where HRT may be continued beyond this point if indicated.

See references:
https://tgldcdp-tg-org-au.ezproxy-f.deakin.edu.au/viewTopic?topicfile=female-hypogonadism&guidelineName=Endocrinology#toc_d1e268
https://bestpractice-bmj-com.ezproxy-f.deakin.edu.au/topics/en-us/1004/management-approach
IncorrectAnswers: 12 months ;;5 years;;HRT is not indicated in this patient ;;Until she achieves symptomatic control

Text: Which of the following is NOT a function of the kidney?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The kidney does not act as a major site of glycogen storage. This is largely done by the liver.

Aside from the major role of the kidneys of filtering blood and making urine, the kidneys other roles include:
- Secretion of EPO in response to hypoxaemia
- Long term blood pressure and circulating volume regulation through renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system
- Vitamin D regulation and activation, which in turn supports calcium levels and bone health
- Long term regulation of acids and bases (pH) in the body
IncorrectAnswers: Secretion of renin;;Production of erythropoietin (EPO);;Metabolic activation of vitamin D;;Maintenance of blood acid-base balance

Text:
A 61-year old man presents to ED with an 8-hour history of double vision. He has been otherwise well. He has diagnosed hypertension, for which he takes amlodipine, and diabetes, which is diet controlled.

On examination there is some watering of the right eye, a slight droop of the right eyelid, and the right eye is dislaced to the right. He has full range of movement in both eyes, and pupils are equal and reactive to light. 

What is the likely cause of his symptoms?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Painless CN3 palsy, pupil sparing = complication of diabetes. 
Painful CN3 palsy, pupil involvement(dilation) = PCA aneurysm
IncorrectAnswers: Bell's palsy;;Hypertension;;Horner's syndrome;;Aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery

Text: Which of the following are considered the  support  cells of the glomerulus?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Mesangial cells are specialised cells in the glomerulus that provide support to the other cells and structures.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/ygN9HIwO_Fw?ecver=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Podocytes;;Granular cells;;Endothelial cells;;Macula densa cells

Text:
Steve is a 53-year-old male with a significant history of alcoholism. Despite many attempts to reduce his alcohol consumption, his current intake equates to 16 standard drinks per day.

Which of the following would you not expect to find on examination of Steve?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Liver failure is accompanied by a number of signs on examination, including:
- Spider naevi (angiomas)
- Palmar erythema
- Ascites
- Hepatomegaly (cirrhotic in late stage)
- Abnormal collateral veins (i.e. caput medusae)
- Hepatic encephalopathy

Reference: Talley and O'Connor - Gastrointestinal Examination
IncorrectAnswers: Gynaecomastia;;Caput medusae;;Palmar erythema;;Spider angioma

Text:
A male newborn born at 35/40 via LUSCS is noted to be tachypnoeic (respiratory rate of 80) with cyanosis and mild increased work of breathing (e.g. expiratory grunt, nasal flaring) 90 minutes after delivery. Examination reveals normal breath sounds of normal intensity bilaterally and no adventitious sounds. Heart sounds are S1, S2 with nil added. Pre-and post-ductal saturations are normal. Initial bloods reveal moderate hypoxaemia, mild hypercapnia and a mild respiratory acidosis. A portable CXR is performed  which the radiology report says demonstrates  bilateral perihilar linear streaking with patchy infiltrates and high-normal lung volumes. No evidence of 'pleural effusion . Supportive oxygen therapy is commenced (via hood at 28% FiO2) and over the next 12 hours the patient s respiratory rate and work of breathing stabilise then begin to decrease while oxygen saturations are maintained >93%.

The most likely diagnosis in this patient is?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Gestational age   
ð  premature (?RDS) 
ð  near-term (?TTN)
Mode of delivery -
ð  LUSCS (?TTN)
Antenatal issues incl  
ð  poor intrauterine growth, meconium-stained amniotic fluid, FHR
abnormalities etc (?persistent pulmonary hypertension) 
Onset of symptoms & progression - 
ð  RDS   onset soon after birth, marked respiratory distress, gets progressively worse
ð  TTN   onset within 2 hours of birth, symptoms usually corrected with supplemental oxygen (<40% FiO2) and resolves within 24-72hrs

CXR:P
ð  TTN   normal/high lung volumes + bilateral perihilar linear streaking + interlobar effusion + patchy infiltrates that clear within 24-48hrs
ð  RDS   low lung volumes +reticulogranular ground glass appearance with air bronchograms
ð  Pneumonia   bilateral alveolar densities with air bronchograms + pleural effusion (suggests pneumonia > RDS)
IncorrectAnswers: Respiratory Distress Syndrome (Hyaline Membrane Disease);;Persistent Pulmonary Hypertension;;Congenital/Neonatal Pneumonia;;Apnoea of Prematurity

Text:
A 68 year old woman presents with painless jaundice. On examination there is a palpable gallbladder. Blood is taken in order to screen for serum tumour markers.
 
Which of the following tumour markers would be most likely to be positive?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The clinical history of painless jaundice and a palpable gallbladder is highly suggestive of carcinoma of the head of the pancreas. The most reliable marker to be positive in pancreatic cancer is CA19-9.

CEA is generally raised in colorectal cancer. HCG is a reliable marker for testicular cancer and other germline cancers. CA125 is used for detecting ovarian cancer.
IncorrectAnswers: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA);;Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG);;Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP);;CA125

Text: What is the leading cause of CKD in Australia?
IncorrectAnswers: IgA Nephropathy;;Hypertension;;Multiple myeloma;;Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis

Text:
An elderly man with a history of BPH comes to your clinic complaining of longstanding urinary incontinence. He says that he is frustrated because he is nearly always wet, and doesn t notice when he is about to become incontinent. When he does go to the bathroom to void, he has difficulty initiating a urinary stream, and has some post-void dribbling.

What type of incontinence does this patient likely have?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
A history of unnoticed incontinence is suggestive of overflow incontinence, especially in the context of longstanding BPH. Difficulty initiating a stream is characteristic of bladder neck obstruction by an enlarged prostate, which makes it difficult to initiate and terminate urination.

Oxybutynin is an anti-cholinergic medication that is used to treat urge incontinence and overactive bladder. Stress incontinence is associated with coughing, straining and laughing. There is no suggestion in the stem of UTI symptoms (e.g. frequency and dysuria).
IncorrectAnswers: The type of incontinence that is best treated initially with Oxybutynin;;Incontinence transiently caused by a urinary infection;;Stress incontinence;;Urge incontinence

Text: Which of the following muscles of mastication does NOT contribute to elevation of the mandible?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The lateral pterygoid functions include: - Acting bilaterally, the lateral pterygoids protract the mandible, pushing the jaw forwards. - Unilateral action produces the  side to side movement of the jaw. The lateral pterygoid does not contribute to elevation of the mandible. Reference: TeachMeAnatomy - Muscles of Mastication
IncorrectAnswers: Masseter;;All of these muscles contribute to elevation;;Medial pterygoid;;Temporalis

Text:
Marjorie is a 28 year old woman who is currently 20 weeks pregnant with her second child. Unfortunately, her 2 year old son has contracted chicken pox after not receiving any vaccinations. Concerned that she may have been exposed to the virus, she asks your advice on what she should do. She reports that she has not previously contracted chicken pox. 

What is the most appropriate next step?
CorrectAnswer: Immunoglobulin test, wait for result, then administer immunoglobulin (VZIG) if needed
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Management of chickenpox exposure:
1. If there is any doubt about the mother previously having chickenpox maternal blood should be urgently checked for varicella antibodies
2. If the pregnant women is not immune to varicella she should be given varicella zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG) as soon as possible. VZIG is effective up to 10 days post exposure.
3. Oral aciclovir should be given if pregnant women with chickenpox present within 24 hours of onset of the rash

Risks to the mother - 5 times greater risk of pneumonitis

Fetal varicella syndrome (FVS)
Risk of FVS following maternal varicella exposure is around 1% if occurs before 20 weeks gestation. Studies have shown a very small number of cases occurring between 20-28 weeks gestation and none following 28 weeks. Features of FVS include skin scarring, eye defects (microphthalmia), limb hypoplasia, microcephaly and learning disabilities.

Other risks to the fetus include:
- Shingles in infancy: 1-2% risk if maternal exposure in the second or third trimester
- Severe neonatal varicella: if mother develops rash between 5 days before and 2 days after birth there is a risk of neonatal varicella, which may be fatal to the newborn child in around 20% of cases
IncorrectAnswers: Give varicella vaccination immediately;;Counsel patient regarding foetal abnormalities that will occur;;Immunoglobulin test and administer immunoglobulin (VZIG) immediately;;Reassure and discharge

Text: What is the structure indicated in the following anatomical image of a kidney?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The renal column is a medullary extension of the renal cortex in between the renal pyramids. It allows the cortex to be better anchored.
IncorrectAnswers: Renal papilla;;Renal pyramid;;Ureter;;Minor calyx

Text:
You order an ultrasound for a woman presenting with amenorrhea. The ultrasound of the ovaries shows a string of pearls. 

What is the likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: This is the classic presentation of a woman exhibiting PCOS on ultrasound. However, it is not essential for diagnosis as only 2 of 3 features are necessary: hyperandrogenism (e.g. hirsutism), polycystic ovaries on ultrasound and amenorrhea.
IncorrectAnswers: Uterine fibroid;;Ovarian tumour;;Endometrial hyperplasia;;Ectopic pregnancy

Text:
Charlotte, a 39 year old woman presents with a mallet finger deformity after defending herself from a basketball that was thrown at her by surprise. 

What features should you expect to find during your physical examination?
CorrectAnswer: Full passive but incomplete active extension of the distal interphalangeal joint
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Mallet finger involves disruption of the extensor mechanism of the finger at the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP). Passive extension is permitted, but active is not possible due to disruption of the extensor mechanism. See Radiopaedia and OrthoBullets for more information.
IncorrectAnswers: Swelling of the thenar eminence;;Inability to pinch the index finger and thumb together;;Limited extension and flexion of the proximal interphalangeal joint;;Inability to flex or extend the distal interphalangeal joint

Text:
Phillice is a 98yo who has been ailed by recurrent bouts of constipation for the past few years. When she presents to the emergency department complaining of sever abdominal pain you order an abdominal x-ray which reveals the following (see below image).

What is the most appropriate intervention?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This patient has a sigmoid volvulus (SV) with the classic  coffee bean  finding on abdominal xray. 
SV is most common in elderly patients who have had recurrent bouts of constipation. In the elderly population, who are not good surgical candidates, endoscopic decompression is preferred, although SV is likely to reoccur.
In younger patients, who were better surgical candidates, a surgical resection would be the preferred option.
IncorrectAnswers: Osmotic laxative;;Surgical resection;;Pain relief and supportive care;;Gastrografin

Text: Which of the following is not an anterior forearm muscle?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The muscles of the anterior forearm work to cause flexion of the wrist and fingers, as well as pronation of the forearm. Reference: Teach Me Anatomy - Muscles of the Anterior Forearm
IncorrectAnswers: Palmaris longus;;Pronator quadratus;;Flexor carpi radialis;;Flexor digitorum superficialis

Text:
Harris, a 54 year old known Asthmatic presents to the ED with significant shortness of breath. He is unable to talk. On examination you notice significant recruitment of accessory breathing muscles. He has had 2 previous ICU admissions for exacerbations of asthma, one requiring intubation.  

Vitals are as follows:
HR: 148
BP: 140/80 
Temperature: 35.5 
O2: 86% 
RR: 30 

Which of the following is NOT part of the initial management?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Treatment of acute asthma in adults

Initial management:
Oxygen 
Nebulised salbutamol
Ipratropium bromide 
IV hydrocortisone. 
If inadequate response consider mag sulphate

There is some evidence that magnesium sulfate may have bronchodilator effects. The sickest patients appear to be the most likely to benefit from intravenous magnesium sulfate. Guidelines recommend considering intravenous magnesium sulfate in severe and life-threatening acute asthma after first-line bronchodilator therapy (ie salbutamol and ipratropium) has been initiated. However, a recent randomised controlled trial (that excluded patients with acute severe asthma) failed to demonstrate a clinically worthwhile benefit from intravenous or nebulised magnesium sulfate in adults.
IncorrectAnswers: Hydrocortisone 100mg IV ;;Nebulised Ipratroprium Bromide 500mg  ;;Oxygen;;Nebulised Salbutamol 5mg

Text:
Pgc = 48 mmHg; Àgc = 24 mmHg; Pbs = 12 mmHg; Àbs = 23 mmHg. (À = oncotic pressure, bs = bowman's space, gc = glomerular capillary)

Which of the following is true?
CorrectAnswer: There is a severe abnormality in the amount of protein in the Bowman s space
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
In normally functioning nephrons, there is essentially zero filtration of protein into Bowman's space. This is a result of the podocytes forming very thin spaces for molecules to pass through, which are not large enough for protein molecules to pass through. Furthermore, the negative charge of the basement membrane of the filtration barrier repels the overall negatively charged protein molecules.

Protein passing into the nephron will lead to protein in the urine (proteinuria), which is a central feature of nephrotic syndrome and diabetic nephropathy.
IncorrectAnswers:
There is a severe abnormality in the capillary hydrostatic pressure of the glomerulus;;The net filtration pressure is 39 mmHg;;The net filtration pressure is 37 mmHg;;No net filtration will occur from the glomerular capillary into the Bowman s space at
these values

Text:
A 5-year-old child was admitted overnight awaiting surgical repair of a broken right ankle and was noted to have a raised blood pressure consistently above 130/90mmHg despite adequate analgesia.
