On examination he has a plaster on his right foot and appears comfortable at rest. On auscultation there is a soft systolic murmur heard at the right upper sternal edge. His femoral pulse is difficult to find, but present bilaterally. When felt with the radial pulse, the impulse in the femoral pulse occurs slightly later. His abdomen is soft and there are no bruits heard. The blood pressure done in the right arm is 136/92mmHg but the left arm gives a reading of 124/80. 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: This child is hypertensive in both arms but there is a discrepancy between the right and left arm with a radio-femoral delay and a systolic murmur heard in the aortic area, supporting a diagnosis of coarctation of the aorta. This is likely to be a mild stenosis which is why it was not picked up earlier. The restricted blood flow to the abdomen and kidneys results in feedback loops producing hypertension to maintain perfusion. The blood pressure in the left arm is still high but it is lower than the right arm because of the coarctation restricting blood flow to the left and lower body. There is no bruit heard on examining the abdomen and other findings point to coarctation, making renal artery stenosis unlikely, but to rule it out an abdominal ultrasound with Doppler would be required. Phaeochromocytoma is a rare cause of hypertension caused by an adrenal tumour producing catecholamines and imaging would be required to diagnose this; therefore it is extremely unlikely to be the correct answer. White coat hypertension is raised blood pressure associated with anxiety, induced by the presence of medical professionals. There is an underlying reason found on examination for his hypertension; therefore is not the correct answer.
IncorrectAnswers: Phaeochromocytoma;;White coat hypertension;;Normal blood pressure in the left arm with a spurious result from the right;;Renal artery stenosis

Text: Angiotensin II is an important hormone in the control of blood volume and pressure. Which of the following is not a role that ATII has in the body?
CorrectAnswer: Venous dilation to decrease workload on the heart
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Venous dilation occurs endogenously via the action of ANP and BNP (natriuretic peptide system). Angiotensin II is a hormone formed from Angiotensin I (by the enzyme ACE), which has a number of functions including:
- Vasoconstriction 
- Stimulating release of aldosterone from adrenal cortex
- Stimulating release of ADH from pituitary gland
- Indirectly leading to sodium reabsorption through the action of aldosterone

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Oges5YqDLHY" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Sodium reabsorption by the kidneys;;Causes release of aldosterone;;Vasoconstricting the majority of arteries and arterioles;;Stimulate ADH release from the posterior pituitary

Text: A septic patient on the ICU is noted to be oozing blood from a central venous catheter insertion site. The following laboratory tests support a diagnosis of disseminated intravascular coagulation EXCEPT?
CorrectAnswer: Target cells on the blood film
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Target cells are a feature of haematological conditions such as thalassemia and splenectomy, and are not seen in DIC.
IncorrectAnswers: Prothrombin time of 52 seconds;;Prolonged thrombin time;;Platelet count of 50x 10^9/L;;Fibrinogen 0.5g/L

Text:
You are the intern on the palliative care team in Warrnambool. Your consultant has asked you to change a patient from their usual oral morphine dose to subcutaneous morphine, as the patient is no longer able to tolerate oral medications. The patient currently is taking 15mg oral morphine (sustained release) BD.

What would be the most appropriate new regimen for this patient's morphine?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation: When converting from oral to parenteral (IV, SC, IM) morphine, the conversion ratio is 2-3:1. This means that the total daily dose should be divided by 2-3 (i.e. 10-15mg in this patient) to achieve the roughly equivalent dose of morphine. Care should be taken when changing to dosing routes, so the lower dose should be trialled first to avoid unwanted and dangerous side effects (e.g. respiratory depression). A comprehensive guide to opioid dose conversions can be found at this link.
IncorrectAnswers: 10mcg subcutaneous morphine;;30mg subcutaneous morphine;;5mg subcutaneous morphine;;60mg subcutaneous morphine

Text:
A 1-day-old girl has a harsh systolic cardiac murmur all over the precordium with a thrill at the left sternal edge. Femoral pulses are palpable. A chest X-ray shows an enlarged heart, and an ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy. 

Which is the single most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Heart murmurs are heard in many neonates. It is important to know the characteristics that signify congenital heart disease. Significant murmurs are usually harsh sounding and may be associated with thrills. In this case, the systolic murmur indicates a lesion where turbulent flow occurs in sys- tole (i.e. aortic stenosis, pulmonary stenosis, ventricular septal defect, and atrial septal defect). The thrill at the left sternal edge indicates turbulent flow in the area of the septum. A patent ductus has a continuous murmur as blood flows across the ductus in both systole and diastole. Normal femoral pulses argue against a severe aortic stenosis or coarctation.
IncorrectAnswers: Aortic stenosis;;Patent Ductus Arteriosus;;Coarctation of the Aorta;;Pulmonary Stenosis

Text:
A 15-year-old boy is worried that he is shorter than all his friends and that he has not yet started puberty. He is otherwise well. His father started puberty at around the age of 14 years. The boy s parental heights are both on the 25th centile. His growth chart is shows his height and weight have down tracked from the 50th Centile to the 9th Centile over the past 3 years. 

Which single aspect of his growth and pubertal development will be most likely to assist with diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: This boy is most likely to have constitutional delay in growth and puberty. As testicular enlargement is the first sign of puberty in boys, measurement of testicular volume (using an orchidometer, consisting of a string of testicle-shaped beads of different volumes) will indicate whether he has started puberty even in the absence of other signs. If his testicular size is greater than 4mL, you can reassure him that he has entered puberty, and that the other signs and a growth spurt will follow. The pubertal growth spurt is a late event in boys. All of the other items are relevant and should be recorded.
IncorrectAnswers: Pubic Hair Stage;;Head Circumference Centile;;Height Velocity Centile;;Axillary hair stage

Text:
A 16 year old student presents to the General Practitioner with several days of fever, sore throat, malaise and a rash which developed today. She first started feeling ill 10 days ago with general malaise, headache and nausea. Four days later she developed a temperature of 39.4degreesC that has persisted. She has a worsening sore throat and difficulty swallowing solid foods; she is drinking well. She denies emesis, diarrhoea and sick contacts. She takes an oral contraceptive pill daily. On examination, she is febrile at 39oC, has mild supraorbital oedema, bilaterally enlarged tonsils that are covered in shaggy grey exudate and generalised lymphadenopathy. Abdominal examination is significant for a palpable mass in the left lateral subchondral region. 

What is the most appropriate management of this patient?
CorrectAnswer: Advise avoiding contact sports for at least a month
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Infectious mononucleosis 
(1) Caused by EBV in 90% (CMV also)
 ð  Transmitted by saliva  kissing virus 
(2) Self-limiting and DOES NOT require treatment 
ð  Penicillins can precipitate a rash!
(3) Triad of fever + generalised lymphadenopathy  glandular fever + pharyngitis/tonsillitis
ð  Splenomegaly in ~50% 
àð rupture is rare but the blood loss is life threatening (hence the advise regarding avoiding contact sports)
(4) Characteristic haematological finding 
ð  = atypical lymphocytosis
(5)  Monospot test  = heterophile antibodies
ð  Sensitivity = 81-95%
ð  Specificity = 98-100%
ð  **Not reliable in children under 5àð perform antibody testing**
IncorrectAnswers: Commence a five day course of oral Augmentin;;Commence a three day course of oral acyclovir;;Refer for HIV serology;;Commence a three day course of oral prednisolone

Text: Which of the following is NOT a branch of the facial nerve supplying the muscles of the face?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The 5 beaches of the facial nerve are: - Buccal - Temporal - Marginal mandibular - Zygomatic - Cervical Reference: TeachMeAnatomy - Facial Nerve
IncorrectAnswers: Marginal mandibular;;Buccal;;Temporal;;Zygomatic

Text: A slightly acidic drug that is excreted by the kidneys is highly ionised at a pH of 8. Which of the following is true?
CorrectAnswer: The drug will be cleared more quickly in urine basic conditions
CorrectAnswerExplanation: An acidic drug will more likely remain in the nephron and therefore be excreted than an alkaline (i.e. basic) drug when the urine is basic, and vice versa.
IncorrectAnswers: The rate of drug elimination is not dependant on pH;;A drug is cleared more easily when in its non-ionised form;;The drug will be cleared more quickly in urine acidic conditions;;At a lower urine flow, more of the drug will be cleared

Text:
Cecelia is a 69yo who presents with sudden onset severe generalised abdominal pain, which began one hour ago. Her past medical history is unremarkable. On examination she has generalised abdominal tenderness. 
Her vitals are as follows:
 
HR: 145bpm irregular 
RR: 18bpm
BP: 138/90
T: 37.5 
O2: 98% on room air 
What is the most likely cause of her pain? 
A.	
E.
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Embolic mesenteric ischemia

Clinical features: severe abdominal pain out of proportion to physical findings, vomiting, bloody diarrhoea, bloating, minimal peritioneal signs early in course. 

Common sites of obstruction: SMA supplied territory. Watershed areas of the colon- splenic flexure, left colon, sigmoid colon.
IncorrectAnswers: Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis;;Incarcerated femoral hernia ;;Pancreatitis;;Ruptured abdominal aortic aneurism

Text: At what level does the aorta pass through the diaphragm?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The aorta passes through the aortic hiatus in the diaphragm, which is found at the level of T12.

Text:
Tabitha, a 46 year old pharmacist is recovering from a recent thyroidectomy when she reports tingling in her fingers. Whilst the medical student takes her blood pressure Tabitha experiences involuntary clenching of her hand on the same arm. The intuitive medical student then gently taps over her temple which produces twitching of the face on the ipsilateral side.

What is the most likely underlying electrolyte disturbance?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Common complication of thyroidectomy hypocalcemia secondary to hypoparathyroidism. 
Clinical presentation of hypocalcemia; Latent tetany, Trousseau sign (eliciting carpal spasm by inflating the blood pressure cuff and maintaining the cuff pressure above systolic), Chvosteks sign (tapping the inferior portion of the cheek bone will produce facial spasms).

Other complications of thyroidectomy include recurrent/superior laryngeal nerve injury (hoarse voice), neck haematoma, infection, thyrotoxic storm.
IncorrectAnswers: Hypercalcemia;;Hypokalemia;;Hyperphosphatemia;;Hyperkalemia

Text:
A 29-year-old woman has been admitted with symptoms suggestive of gastroenteritis, including abdominal pain and significant vomiting and diarrhoea. While on the ward, the patient is suddenly noted to have rolled her eyes back and is unable to prevent protrusion of her tongue. She is currently being treated with a several different medications for her suspected gastroenteritis. 

Which single drug is most likely to have caused these symptoms?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Metoclopramide is an anti-emetic drug that functions as an antagonist at the dopamine receptor. Activation of dopamine receptors  in the vomiting centres of the brain normally triggers emesis, so any drug that blocks these receptors will likely reduce vomiting. Metoclopramide also functions in the GIT to increase gastric emptying and speed up bowel transit. Because it acts centrally on dopamine receptors, metoclopramide may cross-react with dopamine pathways associated with control of movement. As such, antagonising receptors in these pathways may lead to extra-pyramidal side effects, including oculogyric crises, tardive dyskinesia and parkinsonism.
IncorrectAnswers: Omeprazole;;Cyclizine;;Ondansetron;;Hyoscine butylbromide

Text: Chloride handling along the nephron is important to maintain fluid balance in the body. Which of the following best describes chloride handling?
CorrectAnswer: Chloride is reabsorbed at the proximal tubule in exchange for secretion of bases to help maintain acid-base balance
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Chloride exchange for bases (e.g. HCO3-) allows the body to maintain its acid-base balance, while also maintaining electrical neutrality in the nephron.
IncorrectAnswers: In the beta-intercalated cell of the colleting tubule, Chloride is co-transported out of the cell over the apical membrane with HCO3-;;Chloride is barely filtered at the glomerulus and instead is predominantly excreted across the rest of the nephron;;Chloride is never reabsorbed paracellularly;;At the thick ascending Loop of Henle, Chloride is co-transported out of the cell over the basolateral membrane with HCO3-

Text:
A 78-year-old male with chronic kidney disease presents to ED with muscle weakness. The intern in ED suspects this may be a case of hyperkalaemia secondary to poor renal function, so she orders an urgent UEC and ECG. The potassium comes back as 7.2 (N = 3.5   5), and the ECG confirms the diagnosis of hyperkalaemia.
  
What is the most important next step in management of this patient s condition?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Calcium gluconate is the first line medication to manage hyperkalaemia, as it acts on the myocardial membrane to electrically stabilise it and therefore reduce the likelihood of the patient developing a dangerous dysrhythmia. Other measures to treat hyperkalaemia are utilised, by only after calcium gluconate is given. These measures include: - Insulin and glucose (drives K+ into cells) - Oral resonium (increases excretion through GIT) - Frusemide (increases excretion through kidneys) - Haemodialyis (used only if other measures are not effective) Reference: LITFL - Management of Hyperkalaemia
IncorrectAnswers: Haemodialysis;;Administration of IV insulin + glucose;;Oral resonium;;Frusemide IV

Text:
Phyllis is a 96 year old who presents to emergency department following a fall. 

When examined, her eyes open spontaneously, however when you ask if she knows where she is, she replies with incomprehensible babble. She is unable to obey commands, however when you press on her nailbed she pushes you away. 

What is her GCS?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Eyes: 4 (spontaneous) 
Voice: 2 (incomprehensible sounds) 
Motor: 5 (localises to pain) 
GCS: 11

Text: Which of the following statements best describes the influence of parasympathetic innervation on the heart?
CorrectAnswer: Parasympathetic innervation reduces heart rate by mechanisms including reducing maximum diastolic membrane potential of the pacemaker cardiomyocytes
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Increased parasympathetic innervation of the heart clinically leads to reduced heart rate, via vagal stimulation of the SA node. At the cellular level, this occurs through hyperpolarisation of the cell membrane.
IncorrectAnswers: Parasympathetic innervation will only occur in the complete absence of sympathetic innervation and seeks to reduce heart rate and contractility;;Parasympathetic innervation reduces heart rate by mechanisms including increasing the steepness of the slow depolarisation phase of the pacemaker cardiomyocytes;;Parasympathetic innervation will only occur in the complete absence of sympathetic innervation and seeks to reduce heart rate only;;There is no parasympathetic innervation of the heart

Text: Which of the following is NOT a 'renal' cause of acute kidney injury?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Retroperitoneal fibrosis is a 'post-renal' cause of acute kidney injury as there is obstruction of urine flow outside of the kidney causing back flow and impaired renal function. The other answers are all causes of 'renal' acute kidney injury, as their site of injury is in the parenchyma of the kidney.
IncorrectAnswers: Acute tubular necrosis;;Interstitial nephritis;;Small-vessel vasculitis;;Glomerulonephritis

Text:
Chuck, a 5 year old full time child presents to the emergency department complaining of a one day history of right iliac fossa pain that began in the midline. On examination he is febrile and tachycardic. Rovsings sign is positive. Being a diligent intern you ensure that an urgent surgical referral is made, however on laparoscopy a perfectly healthy appendix is found. 

What is the most likely cause of Chuck's pain?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Meckels diverticulum; remnant of the vitelline duct (connects the yolk sac with primitive midgut)  

Rule of 2 s for Meckels Diverticulum: Affects 2% of the population, 2:1 ratio male to female, Symptomatic in 2% of cases, found within 2 feet of the iliocecal valve, 2 incehes in length, 2 inches in diametes, 2 types of tissue (gastric, pancreatic).
IncorrectAnswers: Coeliac disease;;Abdominal migraine;;Incarcerated inguinal hernia;;Constipation

Text:
You are the ED nights intern in a rural emergency department. You attend a trauma call, where the patient is a 24yo male who was ejected from the passenger seat of a car during a MVA at approximately 65km/h. He was not wearing a seatbelt. 

After completing your primary survey, he becomes increasingly short of breath after you have completed your secondary survey. His O2 Saturations have dropped from 99% to 93% on room air. You note asymmetrical chest expansion R>L and and the trachea is slightly deviated to the right. You perform an urgent supine CXR (shown below). 

What is your next step in management?
CorrectAnswer: Needle thoracostomy = 14G cannula into the 2nd intercostal space, left mid-clavicular line
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This patient is now showing signs suggestive of tension pneumothorax - haemodynamically unstable, CXR showing midline shift with collapsed lung, asymmetric chest expansion. This requires urgent needle thoracotomy, in the 2nd intercostal space, mid-clavicular line on the side of the pneumothorax.

A chest drain should be inserted once the patient is stable.
IncorrectAnswers: Call the on-call surgical registrar for urgent insertion of a chest drain;;Insert the chest drain yourself, there is no time to wait for the surgical registrar;;Apply 16L of oxygen via non-rebreather mask;;Needle thoracostomy = 14G cannula into the 2nd intercostal space, right mid-clavicular line

Text:
A 24-year-old male presents to his GP with cramping abdominal pain for several days. He reports loose bowel motions and roughly 7kg of weight loss over the last few months, along with increased fatigue. On examination, his temperature is 37.6°C, and other vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is soft with normal bowel sounds and moderate tenderness in the right lower quadrant, without guarding or rigidity. Rectal examination reveals evidence of pus discharge from a small lesion on the external anal skin.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
A patient with low-grade fever, abdominal pain, loss of weight and altered bowel habits in this context should be considered for inflammatory bowel disease. Given the suggestion of peri-anal disease, with RIF pain (terminal ileitis is common in Crohn's), the likely diagnosis here is Crohn's disease, which should be confirmed on colonoscopy.

IBS will not present with peri-anal disease or fever, while diverticulitis is not common in this age group.
IncorrectAnswers: Ulcerative Colitis;;Coeliac Disease;;Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS);;Diverticulitis

Text:
A 63 year old female presents to ED with a severe migraine episode. Prior to treating, you review her current medications - Oxycodone, Sumatriptan, and Sertraline. After taking further history you find that she has been recently diagnosed with depression in the context of her migraines and chronic back pain. 

What change should be made to her medications?
CorrectAnswer: Cease Oxycontin and replace with Pregabalin
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
It is important to recognise this patient is at risk of Serotonin Syndrome. Changing one of her medications would reduce this patients risk.

Whilst amitriptyline is an option for treating chronic pain, TCAs are known to increase the risk of SS. Pregabalin is an effective agent in treating neuropathic pain and does not increase the risk of SS. Triptans are highly efficacious as a treatment for migraines whilst Topiramate can be used only as a preventative measure and would not aid in treatment of migraine. SNRIs and SSRIs are known to increased the risk of SS. Whilst theoretically a good idea, given amitriptyline could cover both the pain and depression; TCAs are not routinely used for depression given their lethality in overdose through QT prolongation.

Reference: UpToDate Serotonin syndrome (serotonin toxicity) Table 2
IncorrectAnswers: Cease Sertraline and replace with Desvenlafaxine;;Stop Oxycodone and replace with Amitriptyline;;Cease Oxycodone and Sertraline and replace with Amitriptyline;;Cease Sumatriptan and replace with Topiramate

Text:
Mary is a 82 year old lady who is 2 days post-op recovering on the ward following correction of a moderately displaced left subcapital neck of femur fracture. As the intern on night cover you get called to come and see Mary as the nurse is concerned that she is  confused . Diligently, on the way to check on the patient you review her recent bloods which are all within normal limits. When you arrive at the bedside you notice Mary staring and pointing at the wall and she asks you if you can call the cleaner as the hospital has a bug problem. When trying to talk to Mary, you find that she has trouble following you and is easily distracted.

What would be the best tool used in order to diagnose the most likely problem going on?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Mary is suffering from delirium, as evidenced by confusion and impaired concentration. The best diagnostic tool to confirm delirium is the confusion assessment method (CAM).
IncorrectAnswers: ABCD Score;;MMSE;;Alcohol Withdrawal Scale;;MoCA

Text: Which of the following does NOT drain into the hepatic portal vein?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The left hepatic vein drains directly into the inferior vena cava.

See CR2 anatomy prac
IncorrectAnswers: Left gastric vein;;Inferior mesenteric vein;;Splenic vein;;Superior mesenteric vein

Text:
Janis is a 32yo who presents at 10 weeks gestation, having recently taken a pregnancy test. She has poorly controlled T1DM, and reports that her blood sugars have been  all over the shop  for the past few months. She inquires as to the effect this may have on the fetus. 

Which of the following is her fetus at highest risk of developing?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Maternal complications of diabetes include:
- Polyhydramnios - 25%, possibly due to fetal polyuria
- Preterm labour - 15%, associated with polyhydramnios

Neonatal complications of maternal diabetes include:
- Macrosomia (although diabetes may also cause small for gestational age babies)
- Hypoglycaemia (secondary to beta cell hyperplasia)
- Respiratory distress syndrome: surfactant production is delayed
- Polycythaemia: therefore more neonatal jaundice
- Malformation rates increase 3-4 fold e.g. sacral agenesis, CNS and CVS malformations (hypertrophic cardiomyopathy)
- Stillbirth
- Hypomagnesaemia
- Hypocalcaemia
- Shoulder dystocia (may cause Erb's palsy)
IncorrectAnswers: Sacral Agenesis;;Neural Tube Defects;;Cystic Kidneys;;Trisomy 21

Text:
A 67-year-old male presents to his GP complaining of worsening vision. When his vision is tested, the GP notes that visual acuity is preserved. However, visual field testing is notable for poor lateral peripheral vision in both eyes.

Which of the following pathologies would account for this pattern of vision loss?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: A mass pressing on the junction of the left and right optic nerves (optic chiasm) will give a classic 'bitemporal hemianopia', where lateral vision is lost on both sides.
IncorrectAnswers: Optic neuritis of the right eye;;Occlusion of the central retinal artery;;Papilloedema secondary to raised intracranial pressure;;A stroke affecting the left temporal lobe

Text:
A 72 year old gentleman is brought into the clinic by his family. They are concerned in regard to his recent decline in cognition over the past 3 months. He is normally well and has been independent until recently. There is no history of weight loss and no headache. He has however been suffering from unilateral ringing in the ear and sensorineural hearing loss. His family have mentioned that he has started to need adult diapers due to recent urinary incontinence and that they are worried he is going to topple over all the time.

Given the likely diagnosis, which of the following best describes the type of gait seen on examination?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This patient is exhibiting the triad of ataxia, cognitive impairment and urinary incontinence, which is seen in normal pressure hydrocephalus, potentially secondary to an acoustic neuroma.

Hemiplegia is associated with strokes, while antalgic gait is associated with injury and/or degeneration in the lower limbs. Festinating (shuffling) gait is most often seen in Parkinson's Disease, while Trendelenburg gait is due to weakened hip adductors resulting in collapsing of the pelvis during the gait cycle.
IncorrectAnswers: Trendelenburg;;Hemiplegic;;Antalgic;;Festinating

Text:
Geoffrey, a 65 year old presents to the emergency department complaining of intense abdominal pain. He has a past medical history of hypertension, hyperlipidaemia and has a BMI of 40. His only previous surgery was a cholecystectomy 10 years ago.  An abdominal x-ray reveals the following (see below):

What is the most likely cause of Geoffreys pain?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Common causes of bowel obstruction:
Extramural- Adhesions, mass effects of cancer, volvulus    
Intramural- Adenocarcinoma, diverticulitis, structures, intersusseption,     
Intraluminal- Pseudoobstruction

The most common cause of small bowel obstruction is adhesions.
IncorrectAnswers: Sigmoid volvulus;;Adenocarcinoma;;Pseudo-obstruction;;Mesenteric ischemia

Text:
Janice, a 68 year old janitor presents to the emergency department reporting a 6 hour history of increasing right upper quadrant pain, accompanied by fever. Her past medical history includes diabetes, gall stones and hypertension. On examination she is tender over the right upper quadrant and appears jaundiced. 

What is the most likely cause of Janice's presentation?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Classic presentation of ascending cholangitis; charcots triad (fever, RUQ pain, jaundice- occurs in 50-70%)  
Ascending cholangitis occurs due to stasis in the biliary tract due to obstruction or stricture. Given this patient's past history of gall stones, this is the likely cause of obstruction. Infection originates in the duodenum or spreads hematogenously from the portal vein.
IncorrectAnswers: Choledocholithiasis;;Pancreatitis;;Biliary Colic;;Cholelethiasis

Text:
A 26-year old woman is brought into ED by her friend, who found her in her room this morning. They had been out drinking together the night before, and the woman had been upset after being dumped by her partner. 

She is drowsy and confused. Examination reveals a respiratory rate of 32, a heart rate of 120, and a BP of 130/90. She has a palpable bladder, and exaggerated reflexes. Her pupils are large bilaterally and slow to react to light.

Which substance has she most likely taken?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The woman presents with signs and symptoms of an anti-cholinergic toxicity: drowsiness, irritability, large pupils, tachycardia (also pyrexia). This is most often seen with TCA overdose, as these medications classically exhibit anti-cholinergic side effects.

The risk is for ventricular arrhythmias and seizures, so she needs to be monitored closely. A metabolic acidosis is likely, and needs to be treated with bicarbonate.

Paracetamol presents with few symptoms, but can later lead to fulminant hepatic failure.
Opiates (think about their clinical use - pain killers causing respiratory depression) - would cause small pupils and depressed respirations.
 
Benzodiazepines cause few symptoms besides marked drowsiness.
IncorrectAnswers: Benzodiazepines;;Opiates;;Paracetamol;;Alcohol intoxication

Text:
A 50 year old woman has had intermittent nipple discharge from her left nipple. The discharge is slightly blood-stained. There are no discrete lumps and no axillary lymphadenopathy. On gentle squeezing of the left nipple there is a single point of discharge. A mammogram is normal. 

What is the single most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
When discussing benign breast conditions, there a number of common histories that pertain to each condition:
  Intraductal Papilloma - bloody discharge secondary to a solitary intraductal benign polyp

Text: Which of the following is least likely to be found in a patient with Cushing s Syndrome?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Cushing's syndrome can be identified on examination with a number of clinical signs, including:
- Abdominal weight gain
- Proximal myopathy
- A  buffalo  hump of fat high on the back
- Round, red and puffy-looking face ( moon face )
- Thin skin, easily bruised, slow healing and ulcers
- High blood pressure
- High white blood cell count, low serum potassium
- High blood sugar (in 80 per cent of patients)
- Mood swings, irritability, anxiety, depression
- Impotence
- Irregular menstrual periods or no menstrual periods
- Increased facial hair in women
- Osteoporosis

Reference: Talley and O'Connor - Endocrine
IncorrectAnswers: Easy bruising;;Hypertension;;Abdominal striae;;Impaired glucose tolerance

Text: Which type of joint is the elbow joint?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The elbow joint is classed as a "hinge synovial" joint, which means it has a hinge shape with the normal synovial structure of a joint capsule, synovial membrane and hyaline cartilage on the articulating surfaces. The elbow joint complex technically includes three joints: 1. The humero-ulnar joint 2. The radio-humeral joint 3. The proximal radio-ulnar joint References: TeachMeAnatomy - Classification of Joints and Elbow Joint
IncorrectAnswers: Symphysis;;Plane synovial;;Syndesmosis;;Ball-and-socket synovial

Text:
Rosie, a 3 year old child is brought in to the ED by her concerned mother Edna, after she developed a rash this morning (pictured). The rash began on her chest, before spreading to both arms and legs. Edna states that two days previously Rosie had a fever of 40 degrees, however her GP reassured her that it was likely a viral illness. She has had normal oral intake, however cries and clings to her mother when you attempt to examine her.   

Rosie s vitals are:
HR 120
BP 95/50
Temperature 36.6
O2 99%
RR 24
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Resolved high fever + blanching rash: roseola infantum.
Viral self resolving infection caused by HHV6

Given that the child is no longer febrile, and well, reassurance and discharge is adequate, with advice to return if the child becomes unwell. No need to do a septic workup because the child is no longer febrile.
IncorrectAnswers: Fluid resuscitation, dexamethasone + ceftriaxone;;CXR, FBE, blood cultures, urine MCS, Lumbar puncture;;Admission for observation;;CXR, FBE, blood cultures, urine MCS

Text:
Mr. Smith started to experience short and sudden attacks of extreme pain on the left side of his face. This pain could be elicited by stroking the left side of the face, brushing his teeth or talking.

Which Cranial Nerve is affected?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Mr Smiths sensory perception is affected which is innervated by the trigeminal nerve. These symptoms align with trigeminal neuralgia most likely affecting V2 and/or V3 branches.
IncorrectAnswers: Vestibulocohlear nerve (VIII);;Vagus nerve (CNX);;Trochlear nerve (CNIV);;Facial nerve (CN VII)

Text:
Donald, a 14 year old boy, presents to the Emergency Department with severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. On examination he has generalised abdominal tenderness. 

Vitals are as follows: 
HR 120
BP 100/50
Temperature 37.5 
O2 99%
RR 30 
BSL 22 

Blood Gas Results:
pH: 7.26 (7.35-7.45) 
PaCO2: 18mmHg (35-45mmHg)
[HCO3-]: 8mEq/L (22-26mEq/L)  

Which of the following will NOT form part of your initial management?
CorrectAnswer: Reduce potassium levels using Magnesium Sulphate
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Management of diabetic ketoacidosis 
1.	Fluids
2.	Insulin (short acting)- ensure serum potassium concentration is above 3.5 before commencing 
3.     Potassium replacement- total body potassium is depleted in DKA- check for ECG changes
IncorrectAnswers: FBE, UEC, VBG;;Bolus of 5-10U of short acting insulin;;Bolus of Normal Saline;;ECG

Text:
A 76-year-old female presents to her GP complaining of palpitations that have been bothering her for several weeks. The lady has a past history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes, for which she takes perindopril and metformin. The practice nurse at your clinic carries out a 12-lead ECG and prints off the patient s rhythm strip, which is shown below.

What is the best course of management for this patient's underlying arrhythmia?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Atrial fibrillation is the most common arrhythmia in this context, and is evident in the rhythm strip with an irregularly irregular rhythm with no P waves. The long-term management of AF is either rhythm control (with DCR or anti-arrhythmics) or rate control (with anticoagulation). If a patient has been in AF for an undefined length of time, cardioversion is contraindicated as there may be a clot in the left atrium that could dislodge with DCR. Anti-arrhythmics are usually used in young people with structurally normal hearts. Rate control with a beta-blocker (cardioselective = bisoprolol, metoprolol and carvedilol) and anticoagulation with warfarin or a NOAC (e.g. rivaroxaban) is the mainstay treatment for the patient described above. Reference: Medical Journal of Australia
IncorrectAnswers: Digoxin;;Amiodarone;;Low-dose aspirin;;Immediate DC cardioversion

Text:
A mother brings her 8 month old son into the emergency department on a cold winters evening. They have recently moved to Australia, and are yet to vaccinate their son using a catch-up schedule. He is struggling to breath, looks toxic, has a marked stridor, is irritable and drooling. He is febrile at 38.7!. His mother says he is worse now than when they left home. 

What is the diagnosis and management?
CorrectAnswer: Epiglottitis - Secure airway + supplemental oxygen + I/V ceftriaxone (50-75mg/kg/day paeds dose) + corticosteroids
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This boy has Epiglottitis, his vaccination status & drooling are the key give-aways. He also lacks the pathognomonic barking cough and his symptoms did not improve in the cold night air as you would expect in croup. 

Securing this boys airway is primary objective, and prolonged intubation is often a feature of epiglottitis Mx. This should be carried out by a highly experienced clinician, as the airway is liable to be very difficult with the associated swelling with epiglottitis.
IncorrectAnswers: Croup   corticosteroids + supportive care;;Epiglottitis   Secure airway + supplemental oxygen + Give HIB vaccination;;Croup   corticosteroids + supportive care + inhaled adrenaline;;Epiglottitis   Supplemental oxygen + corticosteroids + inhaled adrenaline

Text: Which cells produce myelin in the peripheral nervous system?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Schwann cells produce myelin in the peripheral nervous system. Oligodendrocytes produce myelin in the central nervous system. Ependymal cells line the ventricular system and are involved in the production of CSF. Satellite cells and Astrocytes are neuro-supportive cells in the PNS and CNS, respectively. All these cells are types of glial cells.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/fBfrT_WXBQA?ecver=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Satellite cells;;Astrocytes;;Oligodendrocytes;;Ependymal cells

Text:
A 17-year-old boy presents with chronic low back pain for the past 8 months. He was the most promising member of the high school swim team but was forced to quit because of his back pain. The pain begins frequently at night, radiates down the thighs, and is accompanied by pronounced stiffness of the lumbar spine. He denies any gastrointestinal or genital infections. His temperature is 37.0. Examination reveals moderate limitation of back motion and tenderness of the lower spine. A diastolic murmur along the left sternal border is heard on chest examination. Laboratory investigation shows an elevated ESR and negative rheumatoid factor. X-ray films of the vertebral column and pelvic region show flattening of the lumbar curve and subchondral bone erosion involving the sacroiliac joints.

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The patient's young age, occurrence of pain at night, negativity of rheumatoid factor, and especially, bilateral involvement of sacroiliac joints are consistent with ankylosing spondylitis. This is one of the seronegative spondyloarthropathies, characterized by onset before 40 years of age, absence of circulating autoantibodies, frequent association with HLA-B27 histocompatibility antigen, and common involvement of the spinal column. Ankylosing spondylitis should be suspected in any young person complaining of chronic lower back pain and confirmed by radiographs or CT scans of sacroiliac joints. The disease usually progresses to involve the whole vertebral column, producing ankylosis and respiratory failure secondary to restrictive lung disease. Uveitis and aortic insufficiency are additional manifestations.
IncorrectAnswers: Seronegative rheumatoid arthritis;;Reiter syndrome;;Still disease;;Degenerative joint disease

Text:
Joan is a 78 year old woman who is currently admitted to the palliative care ward as her pain has recently not been well controlled. Joan's pain medication regime is:

Regular MR Morphine 15 mg BD with 5 mg IM Morphine PRN

Yesterday, Joan took her regular medication along with 20 mg of PRN IM Morphine. 5 mg of this which was used when she took a shower in the morning. 

What should Joan s new pain regime be?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswer: Regular MR morphine 45 mg; Breakthrough dose 7.5 mg
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
An opioid dose for breakthrough pain is calculated as one-twelfth to one-sixth of the total amount of opioid taken in the previous 24 hours. More than 3 PRN breakthrough requirements in a 24 hour period is an indication that the regular background (extended release) opioid is not sufficient to manage ongoing pain. Thus, the background dose should be increased by 50% in this patient.

Reference: Therapeutic Guidelines - Pain: opioid therapy in palliative care
IncorrectAnswers: Regular MR morphine 50 mg; Breakthrough dose 7.5 mg;;Regular MR morphine 45 mg; Breakthrough dose 15 mg;;No change is necessary to control the patients pain;;Regular MR morphine 50 mg; Breakthrough dose 15 mg

Text:
June is a 78 year old lady who presents to you with recurrent  falls and wobbles  over the last 3 days. On history you distinguish that she has been suffering from true vertigo and that she is having issues with her balance. She notes that she has been feeling rather nauseated since this came on suddenly 3 days ago but denies having any tinnitus or hearing problems. Examination of June reveals nystagmus at rest and she loses her balance when her eyes are closed.

Of the following examination findings, which would be likely found in keeping with the most likely diagnosis?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Dysdiadochokinesia is impaired ability to perform rapid, alternating movements, and is associated with cerebellar lesions.
IncorrectAnswers: Carotid bruit;;Antalgic gait ;;Unilateral sensorineural hearing loss ;;Nystagmus that improves on visual fixation

Text:
A 73 year old woman presents to ED from her low level care nursing home on Sunday evening after staff noted she became increasingly confused and disorientated. She was previously alert and oriented, with no history of cognitive impairment. On examination, her GCS is 13 (E4V3M6). She is afebrile 36.8!, her blood pressure is 107/60, Heart Rate is 74/min and her respiratory rate is 26/min. 

What is the highest priority in managing this patient?
CorrectAnswer: Establish IV access, 2 x blood cultures, empirical IV antibiotics.
CorrectAnswerExplanation: This patient satisfies 2 of the 3 qSOFA criteria (RR >22, Systolic BP <100mmHg, change in mentation), thus the diagnosis is sepsis until proven otherwise, and a sepsis protocol should be initiated. While the other options may be valid, especially investigating for sepsis source, checking blood glucose and urinalysis, this patient requires antibiotics as soon as possible. Reference: Surviving Sepsis Campaign
IncorrectAnswers: Check FBE/UEC/LFTs;;Check Blood Glucose levels & Urine Dip Stick;;Discharge and advise GP follow up on Monday morning;;Orientate the Patient to Time, Place & Person in a quiet room

Text:
Millicent, a 38yo magician presents to the emergency department complaining of right upper quadrant abdominal pain. The surgeons waste no time in performing a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, during which they discover a number of perihepatic adhesions. 
  
What was the most likely cause of these adhesions?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Fitz-Hugh Curtis syndrome is a rare complication of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) involving liver capsule inflammation leading to the creation of adhesions. The most common causative organism is chlamydia trachomatis.

The major symptom and signs include an acute onset of RUQ abdominal aggravated by breathing, coughing or laughing, which may be referred to the right shoulder. Abdominal ultrasound and LFTs are typically normal.
IncorrectAnswers:
Ruptured ectopic pregnancy ;;Cholecystitis
;;Focal nodular hyperplasia;;Endometrioma

Text:
A 68-year-old woman has had central abdominal pain for 3 days. Over the last 12 hours, the pain has become more intense and she has vomited four times. She has not opened her bowels for 2 days. She has type 2 diabetes and takes aspirin 75mg once daily and gliclazide 80mg twice daily. 

T 36.4°C, HR 90bpm, BP 128/80mmHg. 

An abdominal X-ray is performed (see image below). Her abdomen is distended with a tympanic percussion note. 

Which is the single most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Caecal volvulus is a condition that involves twisting of the caecum, causing obstruction and subsequent dilation of that portion of the large bowel. The symptoms of caecal volvulus include pain, no passage of bowel movements, and nausea/vomiting after the volvulus has been present for some time. Abdominal x-ray of caecal volvulus shows a large dilated bowel loop.

A perforated ulcer would give a more haemodynamically unstable picture, and tends not to be associated with change in bowel habit. 

Small bowel obstructions will present with nausea/vomiting much earlier in the clinical picture, and have an abdominal x-ray that shows multiple dilated bowel loops with lines crossing the entire width of the bowel.

An incarcerated epigastric hernia would cause abdominal pain, but is unlikely to give such an abdominal x-ray. There will also be a hernia on examination of the abdomen.
IncorrectAnswers: Incarcerated epigastric hernia;;Constipation;;Small bowel obstruction ;;Perforated gastric ulcer

Text: A 32 year old woman presents to her GP concerned about a small lump behind her right nipple. It is associated with unilateral bloody nipple discharge. Upon questioning, she has no known family history of breast cancer, nor has she noticed any other symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Intraductal papillomas are the most common cause of bloody nipple discharge. A papilloma is a papillary tumour growing from the lining of the breast duct, considered hyperplastic rather than malignant or pre-malignant. The discharge associated with a papilloma can be clear or grossly bloody.
IncorrectAnswers: Paget's disease of the nipple;;Duct ectasia;;Fibroadenoma;;Ductal carcinoma

Text:
Alice, a 24 year old woman, attends your GP clinic requesting advice on emergency contraception. She normally takes Levlen, a combined oral contraceptive pill. She missed her pill yesterday morning but she took her normal pill this morning. It is over 24 hours since the missed pill. She had unprotected sex last night. She is on day 26 of her cycle and due to commence sugar pills in 2 days. 

How would you advise her on catch-up contraception?
CorrectAnswer: This is a 'missed pill'. Take your missed pill when you get home and skip the sugar pill period.  Use barrier contraception for the next 7 days.
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
There is an important distinction between a 'late pill' (<24 hours late) and a 'missed pill' (>24 hours late). For a late pill, the missed pill should be taken as soon as they remember plus their normal pill. Two or less pills within 24 hours is okay and no barrier/emergency contraception is required. 

For a missed pill, there is a '7 day rule'. 
- Active pills should always been taken for 7 days after a missed pill, even if they are due for sugar pills. Miss the sugar pills if they are near the end of the cycle.
- Barrier contraception must be used for those 7 days.
- The BEGINNING of a cycle is the most dangerous. If any of the previous 7 pills were sugar pills, they require emergency contraception. See your doctor or pharmacist. 

So according to the 7 day rule, Alice must take her missed pill, skip her sugar pills for active pills and she must use barrier contraception for 7 days.
IncorrectAnswers: Take your missed pill and miss the sugar pills. There is no need for barrier contraception.;;Forget it, you're pregnant already. Stop all pills. ;;This is a 'late pill'. Take your missed pill once you get home. Then continue as per normal. ;;Don't worry Alice, you are at the end of your cycle. Just forget the missed pill and go on as per normal.

Text: Which of these deaths is a 'reportable death'?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswer: A 88-year-old woman is found dead in her recliner by district nursing services. Two doctors are called to determine the cause of death but cannot do so after 24 hours of deliberation.
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Doctors are required to inform the coroner of 'reportable' and 'reviewable' deaths.

Reviewable death- the death of the second child in a family (unless that child never left the hospital from birth). This applies to the 13-year-old boy.

Reportable deaths- there are multiple, familiarise yourself with the document below. 
The death of the 79-year-old woman was expected. 
The death of the 60-year-old man took place during a medical procedure but it would be reasonable to expect his death due to the terrible prognosis of a ruptured AAA and his near-exsanguination on presentation. 
The death of the 70-year-old man would have been reportable if he were still in prison, on bail, a police informant, or in any way still engaged with the justice system. His death was not violent or accidental. 

The correct answer is reportable because the death certificate is not likely to be signed by the doctors if they cannot determine a cause of death. This should be reported promptly to the coroner. They might request that the body be sent to Melbourne ASAP after some more information, or they might send the police on their behalf to gather more information. In this case, her body would likely be sent for autopsy so a cause of death can be put on the death certificate. 




http://www.health.vic.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0006/356667/Guidance-Note-for-the-Verification-of-Death-Feb-2010.pdf
IncorrectAnswers: A 70-year-old man who has served his time in prison for theft dies in hospital of advanced chronic liver disease. ;;A 79-year-old woman dies after a long deterioration in the palliative care ward as a result of her metastatic breast cancer.;;A 60-year-old man presented with a ruptured AAA and an immeasurable blood pressure. He dies on the table of cardiac arrest despite the best efforts of the vascular surgeon.;;A 13-year-old boy dies of Duchenne's muscular dystrophy in the hospital after his older brother died of the same disease two years earlier.

Text:
John is an 85 year old man presenting to the GP for a review. 
You notice John has a resting tremor, mask-like face, and a shuffling gait. 
John discusses his vivid hallucinations with the GP. During the discussion, John seems to vary spontaneously in his alertness and attention. 
John has been having trouble sleeping as he often acts out his dreams, resulting in him falling out of bed.

Given the likely diagnosis, which medication should the GP NOT prescribe?
Topics: Mental Health(Year 3);;Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
John has Lewy Body Dementia suggested by his Parkinsonian features + hallucinations. 
LBD core features: 
-Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variation in attention and alertness
-Recurrent visual hallucinations
-Spontaneous motor features of Parkinsonism 

Typical antipsychotics should be avoided in LBD
Haloperidol is a typical antipsychotic (D2 antagonist) which may cause severe confusion, worsening of Parkinsonian features, sedation, neuroleptic malignant syndrome and even death in patients with LB dementia 

L-dopa may improve motor function
Donepezil (acetylcholinesterase inhibitor) may help in early stages to treat psychiatric symptoms such as hallucinations 
Memantine (NMDA blocker) may improve cognitive function 
Melatonin is a safe way to help with REM sleep behaviour disorder (benzos may cause sedation, paradoxical agitation)
IncorrectAnswers: Memantine;;Donepezil;;Melatonin;;L-dopa

Text:
Jenna is a 22-year-old woman who has presented to the Emergency Department following an overdose of Diazepam. This is her fourth such presentation in the last 3 months. She is tearful and is refusing to talk to nursing staff, lashing out when they attempt to assess her.

On history, Jenna describes persistent suicidal ideation and relates that she regularly self-harms by cutting or burning herself. She has received counselling in the past but states it is not working despite seeing several different counsellors over the past year. She relates that she hears her own voice speaking to her negatively in her head. 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Personality disorders:

Cluster A - odd, bizarre, eccentric. Characterised by social awkwardness and withdrawal. Include schizoid, schizotypal, paranoid. 
Cluster B - Dramatic, emotional, erratic. Characterised by emotional instability and impulsivity. Include narcissistic, borderline, histrionic, antisocial. 
Cluster C - Anxious, fearful. Characterised by excessive anxiety. Include avoidant, dependent and obsessive compulsive. 

Jenna exhibits many classical features of cluster B personality disorders. Hearing her own voice in her head is designed to trick you into thinking this is an auditory hallucination. 

NOTE: This was a Deakin MCQ in 2017 and 2018. Personality disorders are extremely common in Deakin MCQs, so read up on them.
IncorrectAnswers: Major depression;;Personality disorder cluster c;;Psychotic depression;;Schizophrenia

Text:
Mrs Litchfield is a 72 year old woman with Stage 4 ovarian cancer, who is known to the palliative care team. She lives independently at home. She has attended the Emergency Department with increasing pain secondary to abdominal metastases. Mrs Litchfield has been thoroughly evaluated and her acute pain managed with intravenous Morphine. She is now comfortable and stable, and keen to return home. 

Mrs Litchfield takes 40mg BD slow-release oxycodone at home. 

What PRN dose of quick-release oxycodone is appropriate?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
PRN dosing: 1/10 to 1/6 of basal opioid. 

Mrs Litchfield's daily basal opioid is 80mg (40mg x2). 

1/10 is 8mg, 1/6 is 13.3mg. 

Therefore 10mg is the best practical dose. The other suggested doses are either excessive or inadequate. 

There is no evidence that Mrs Litchfield should be commenced on a syringe driver - there is no suggestion of being unable to tolerate oral medications or malabsorption of oral medications and the patient continues to live independently at home. High oral opioid doses alone are not and indication for syringe driver commencement.
IncorrectAnswers: 2.5mg;;20mg;;Due to her already high opioid doses, Mrs Litchfield should be commenced on a syringe driver.;;5mg

Text: Which of the following is NOT a complication of gestational diabetes?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Complications of GD for the foetus:
- Increased risk of miscarriage and late term foetal death in utero
- Foetal macrosomia: baby excessively large, can cause birth traumas eg shoulder dystocia
- Polyhydramnios: Excessive amniotic fluid, increases risk of breech presentation
- Congenital malformations
- Neonatal HYPOglycaemia (not hyper)
IncorrectAnswers: Polyhydramnios;;Foetal macrosomia;;Malpresentation;;Late term foetal death in utero

CorrectAnswer: Compensatory strategies required to maintain independence
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
A patient who can utilise compensatory strategies to maintain their independence in ADLs would be considered to have Mild Neurocognitive Disorder as opposed to Major Neurocognitive Disorder. The defining feature between the two is interference with independence in ADLs. 

https://www.dementia.org.au/files/helpsheets/Helpsheet-DementiaQandA11-DiagnosticCriteriaForDementia_english.pdf
IncorrectAnswers: Interferes with independence in ADLs;;Impairment in one or more cognitive domains;;Significant decline from previous performance;;Not attributable to another mental disorder

Text:
You are working as a GP. Your patient, Mrs Wells, has recently been diagnosed with temporal lobe epilepsy.

During the consultation, Mrs Wells discloses to you that she is continuing to drive, despite her neurologist instructing her that she must not. She has not informed VicRoads of her condition.

Which of the following is true of your legal responsibility in this situation?
CorrectAnswer: You are not legally obligated to report Mrs Wells
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
In Victoria, you are not legally obligated to report a patient whose medical condition excludes them from driving. You should inform Mrs Wells that her medical condition demands her exclusion from driving for a period of time, however Mrs Wells herself is responsible for reporting to VicRoads. You could also inform Mrs Wells that if she does not disclose her condition to VicRoads and continues to drive, she may be liable in the event of an accident. 

A voluntary, anonymous report can be made by doctors or relatives. However, informing her relative would be a breach of confidentiality.
IncorrectAnswers: You are legally obligated to inform the Victoria Police of Mrs Wells illegal behaviour;;You should inform a relative of Mrs Wells about her behaviour and encourage them to report it;;You are legally obligated to report Mrs Wells to VicRoads ;;You must inform Mrs Wells that if she refuses to inform VicRoads, you will do so within 2 weeks

Text:
Larry is a 70 yo man who presents to his GP with progressive low back pain. On examination there is mild midline tenderness on palpation. Investigations reveal alkaline phosphatase 355 (30-110), Calcium 2.25 (2.10-2.60) and Phosphate 0.80 (0.75-1.50). The lumbar spine xray report describes cortical sclerosis, vertical trabecular thickening and loss of normal concavity of the anterior margin of the vertebral body. 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This is a classical description of Paget's disease. 

https://radiopaedia.org/articles/paget-disease-bone
https://www.rcpa.edu.au/Library/Practising-Pathology/RCPA-Manual/General-Information/IG/Table-6-Reference-intervals-harmonised-chemical

NOTE: This was a Deakin MCQ in 2017, it had a waaaay bigger stem and a lot of extraneous details.
IncorrectAnswers: Ankylosing Spondylitis;;Boney metastases;;Osteoporosis;;Osteomalacia

Text: Which of these neuroplastic changes is NOT observed with repeated exposure to addictive substances?
CorrectAnswer: Abnormal deposits of a protein called alpha-synuclein in the brain (behaviour changes)
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Abnormal deposits of a protein called alpha-synuclein are referred to as Lewy Bodies and are found in Lewy body dementia. The other changes mentioned are all observed in addiction.
IncorrectAnswers: Changes to basal ganglia circuitry (behavioural tics/habits);;Increased receptor expression (tolerance);;Increased spine density on medium spiny neurons of mesolimbic dopamine pathway (reinforcement);;Reduced prefrontal cortex activity (reduced impulse control)

Text: Which of the following is FALSE regarding spinal canal stenosis?
CorrectAnswer: Symptomatic stenosis is likely to deteriorate without surgical intervention
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Spinal canal stenosis is the narrowing of the vertebral or intervertebral canal and is often multifactorial. The lower three lumbar levels are most frequently affected. Spinal canal stenosis can be asymptomatic and is detected on imaging in over 20% of people older than 60 years of age without a history of back pain.

Symptomatic disease generally presents with low back pain radiating to the buttocks and legs, and is usually bilateral. Patients can also present with leg pain alone and no back pain. Pain may be aggravated by walking or standing, and relieved by sitting or leaning forward (neurogenic claudication or pseudoclaudication); this must be distinguished from the similar symptoms of claudication due to arterial insufficiency. Radicular leg pain in a single dermatomal distribution is more suggestive of single nerve root compression (see Symptomatic lumbar disc herniation).

The clinical course of symptomatic spinal canal stenosis is variable, and can be unpredictable, with flares and stable periods over time. Approximately 50% of patients remain clinically stable, while 25% deteriorate over time and the remaining 25% improve over time. Despite the common perception of a progressive course, patients with mild to moderately symptomatic spinal canal stenosis have a favourable outcome in 30 to 50% of cases.

Source: eTG "Symptomatic Spinal Canal Stenosis"
IncorrectAnswers: Pain is usually bilateral;;Patients complain of pain which improves when going uphill;;Is detected on imaging in over 20% of asymptomatic people over 60;;L3-5 are the most commonly affected sites

Text:
Georgia is a 45 year old woman who has presented for review after you noted a blood pressure of 155/95 at your last visit. You asked Georgia to monitor her blood pressure at home and return in three months following some blood tests. 

On review, Georgia tells you her blood pressure at home ranged from 145/90 to 158/95. She is experiencing no symptoms of high blood pressure. She is a non-smoker and drinks 1-2 glasses of alcohol 3 times weekly. On examination, Georgia has a BMI of 22. Her apex beat is felt at the midclavicular line at the 5th intercostal space. Her pulse is regular at 75bpm. Her lung fields are clear. There are no audible carotid, renal, abdominal or femoral bruits. Her ECG is unremarkable.

Her investigations reveal HbA1c of 5.5, Total Cholesterol 3.8 with HDL 1.2, UEC NAD and normal albumin-creatinine ratio. 

What treatment would you recommend for Georgia?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Although you will not have the absolute CVD risk calculator to hand in the exam, you should be familiar with the components of the Absolute CVD risk score. 

These include: 
- Sex
- Age
- Systolic blood pressure
- Smoking status
- Total Cholesterol
- HDL
- Diabetes
- ECG evidence of LVH

As a young non-smoking female with a healthy BMI and lipid profile and no diabetes, Georgia has a low absolute CVD risk profile, which you can tell without using the calculator. Georgia shows no signs of end-organ damage. Current Heart Foundation recommendations support lifestyle therapy alone in patients with low absolute CVD risk profiles and mild hypertension (140-159 systolic). 

An ACE-I, Calcium channel blockers or ARB would be an appropriate first line medication in a patient with moderate absolute CVD risk. BP targets are <140/90 unless the patient is diabetic, in which case aim for <135/85. 

http://www.cvdcheck.org.au/
https://www.heartfoundation.org.au/images/uploads/publications/PRO-167_Hypertension-guideline-2016_WEB.pdf
IncorrectAnswers: Lifestyle modifications; commence ACE-I; aim for BP <140/90;;Lifestyle modifications; commence ARB; aim for BP <140/90;;Lifestyle modifications; commence beta blocker (Atenolol); aim for BP <140/90;;Lifestyle modifications; commence ACE-I; aim for BP <135/85

Text: Which of the following is correct regarding abortifacient medications?
CorrectAnswer: Mifepristone competitively binds to progesterone receptors and induces myometrial contaction.
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Mifepristone - synthetic steroid. Competitively binds to progesterone receptor, blocking effects of progesterone and induces myometrial contaction. Otherwise known as RU-486

Misoprostol - synthetic prostoglandin. Induces uterine contractions.

In Australia these are usually used in combination to induce a medical abortion. 

Both are efficacious up to 49 days of gestation, may be used up to 63 days.
IncorrectAnswers: Mifepristone is a synthetic prostoglandin which induces uterine contractions.;;Misoprostol blocks effects of progesterone and induces myometrial contaction.;;Misoprostol is otherwise known as RU-486. ;;Misoprostol is a synthetic steroid.

Text: Which of the following is NOT a function of surfactant?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Surfactant decreases hysteresis, which is the difference in inflation and deflation volumes at a given pressure, due to the air-water surface tension that occurs at the beginning of inflation.
IncorrectAnswers: Preventing pulmonary oedema;;Innate immunity;;Preventing alveolar overexpansion;;Preventing alveolar collapse

Text:
Jeremy is a 27 year-old man who presents to his GP for a repeat script of his antidepressant. Knowing that Jeremy is an infrequent visitor, his GP engages in preventative health care and suggests Jeremy undergo STI screening. 

On questioning, Jeremy has sex with women only. He uses condoms "most of the time". He has had 11 sexual partners in the last 12 months. He has no current symptoms of an STI. 

What screening should be undertaken for Jeremy?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
In an asymptomatic heterosexual man, a urine chlamydia is sufficient (a swab is indicated in the presence of discharge only). 

Gonorrhoea is not routinely tested in asymptomatic men unless they have sex with men, live in remote areas of Australia or have recently returned from high prevalence areas overseas. As you are already obtaining a first pass urine, it could be considered, but it is not generally routine. 

High risk heterosexual men should be tested for bloodborne viruses. Having >10 sexual partners in 12 months places Jeremy in a high risk group. 

http://www.sti.guidelines.org.au/standard-asymptomatic-check-up
http://www.sti.guidelines.org.au/sexually-transmissible-infections/gonorrhoea#diagnosis
IncorrectAnswers: Urethral swab for Chlamydia, HIV/Hep B/Syphilis serology;;Urethral swab for Gonorrhoea and Chlamydia;;Urine Chlamydia alone;;No testing is indicated

Text: Of the options below, what is the most important prognostic factor when evaluating melanoma?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
http://www.mmmp.org/MMMP/import.mmmp?page=prog_factors.mmmp

NOTE: This was  Deakin MCQ in 2017. Other important prognostic factors that were not included in this answer are ulceration, lymph node involvement and distant metastasis.
IncorrectAnswers: Clark level;;Regression;;Patient age at diagnosis;;Size

Text: Which of the following is NOT a trigger for malignant hyperthermia?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Malignant hyperthermia is triggered by volatile agents and depolarising muscle relaxants (suxamethonium).
IncorrectAnswers: Suxamethonium;;Isoflurane;;Halothane;;Desflurane

Text: Which of the following is NOT a component of the SOFA criteria?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
SOFA or Sequential Organ Failure Assessment criteria are used to determine prognosis of patients admitted to the ICU with sepsis. The score is calculated based on markers of six organ systems:

Respiratory - PaO2
Coagulation - Platelet count
CVS - MAP or vasopressor requirement
Renal - Creatinine or urine output
CNS - GCS
Hepatic - Bilirubin

Respiratory rate is used in the qSOFA criteria which are applied in the Emergency Department to identify patients with suspected sepsis.
IncorrectAnswers: Bilirubin;;GCS;;Platelet count;;Urine output

Text:
Peter is a 78 year old man admitted to the Palliative Care ward. He was diagnosed with prostate cancer several years earlier and now has developed metastases to his spine and pelvis. Despite his advanced disease Peter has been living comfortably in the community with his wife and is still independent with toileting, with his wife acting as a carer for him in other ADLs. He ambulates well with a 4WW and has no falls history. Although problematic in the past, his pain is now well controlled on 40mg BD oxycontin and 5-10mg Endone PRN, which he needs up to three times daily. He has been admitted to the Palliative Care ward for carer's respite as his wife is on holiday. 

On the Monday morning ward round, Peter complains to you that his pain has returned in force. He complains of sharp, shooting central thoracic back pain which radiates to his ribs which has built up over the weekend. He has been using his PRN pain relief maximally, up to 8 times in 24 hours, with little effect. Peter is visibly in pain as he ambulates to the bathroom and catches his foot on the threshold, stumbling a little. Neurological examination reveals hip flexion 4/5, with no other abnormality. 

What is the most important step to take regarding Peter's complaint?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Palliative patients may present with spinal cord compression with new or severe back pain and subtle initial neurological findings, such as mild proximal weakness. Spinal cord compression is a medical emergency and rapid response is required in order to prevent paraplegia. 70% of patients that are still walking at the time of diagnosis will continue to walk after treatment. For a patient such as Peter, who are ambulant and independent, diagnosis and management of spinal cord compression could prevent paraplegia and save his quality of life.
IncorrectAnswers: Add a neuropathic agent eg Pregabalin;;Commence a syringe driver;;Increase his PRN oral analgesia;;Increase his Basal oral analgesia

Text:
Jacinta is an 8-month-old infant whose parents have noticed that her breathing is persistently noisy over the last 3 weeks. She has a constant audible wheeze during the day, however it is absent when she is sleeping. She is otherwise well and thriving. 

What is the diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The way to approach this question is to first recognise that the child is too young for a diagnosis of asthma and the duration of symptoms is too long for croup, leaving you with three possible congenital diagnoses. The wheeze of laryngomalacia is more pronounced during sleep due to positioning and relaxation of the surrounding musculature, which rules this out. 

Of the remaining options, congenital subglottic stenosis is rare and unlikely to present with constant daytime noisy breathing if it is mild - and if it were more severe than this there would likely be other manifestations. This leaves the congenital vascular ring, which fits with the symptoms described.

NOTE: This somewhat ridiculously hard question was used in the Deakin MCQ exam in 2018, which is why it is included here. Sorry! But better to get it wrong here than on the actual test. 

https://www.cincinnatichildrens.org/health/v/rings
https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/vascular-ring
IncorrectAnswers: Laryngomalacia;;Asthma;;Croup;;Subglottic stenosis

Text:
Harriet, a 66 year old woman, has presented to her GP for a check up. She is known to have essential hypertension, with blood pressure 163/95 at diagnosis and was commenced on Perindopril 5mg 6 months prior. She is tolerating this medication well and is feeling well, with no current health concerns. At her last visit, 3 months ago, her GP noted her blood pressure was 155/93. Her blood pressure remains elevated today, and Harriet reports it has also been this level at home. Her TFTs and renal function are normal and have not deteriorated in the last 6 months. She is not diabetic. Her BMI is 22. 

What is the most appropriate management?
CorrectAnswer: Add low dose calcium channel blocker
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The Heart Foundation recommendations state that if target blood pressure is not achieved within 3 months of initiating a low dose first-line agent, adding a second low-dose agent is preferable to increasing the dose of the existing agent in order to maximise antihypertensive efficacy and minimise adverse effects. The combination of ACE-I and CCB is superior to ACE and diuretics or beta blocker and diuretics in terms of cardiovascular risk and mortality (see page 33 in the link below). 

Changing to an ARB would be appropriate if Harriet was experiencing side effects of the ACE-I. 

Investigating for an underlying cause is unlikely to yield any useful information - the most common cause of secondary hypertension in this age group is renal artery stenosis and so you would likely have observed a deterioration in renal function when treated with an ACE-I. Thyroid dysfunction is the other likely cause of secondary hypertension in this group but her thyroid function is normal. She has had a response to her ACE-I and could not be said to be resistant to it per se. See the link below for details. Investigating for a secondary cause is also not management. 

Use of ARBs in combination with ACE-Is is not recommended.

https://www.heartfoundation.org.au/images/uploads/publications/PRO-167_Hypertension-guideline-2016_WEB.pdf
https://www.aafp.org/afp/2010/1215/p1471.html
IncorrectAnswers: Increase the dose of perindopril;;Add an ARB;;Change to ARB;;Investigate for an underlying cause

Text: In which of the following is a right-to-left shunt observed:
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
There are four defects in Tetralogy of Fallot:
- Ventricular septal defect
- Pulmonary stenosis
- RV Hypertrophy
- Overriding aorta

This results in a high RV pressures and shunting of deoxygenated blood into the systemic circulation, resulting in hypoxia.
IncorrectAnswers: Patent ductus arteriosus;;Aortic coarctation;;Ventricular septal defect;;Atrial septal defect

Text:
Byron is a 2-week-old infant brought in by his mother who is concerned about his feet. 

On examination, you note that both of Byron's feet are plantar flexed. His toes are swung medially and his soles face inward. This positioning is correctable by gentle manipulation of the feet.

Given the likely diagnosis, what other condition is Byron at risk of?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Children with congenital talipes are more likely to have hip dysplasia. 

https://www.rch.org.au/uploadedFiles/Main/Content/ortho/factsheets/POSITIONAL-TALIPES.pdf
IncorrectAnswers: Osteomyelitis;;Osteosarcoma;;Intellectual disability;;Juvenile idiopathic arthritis

Text:
Keith presents to his GP seeking advice regarding safe sex. He is worried about his risk of contracting HIV. 

On history taking, Keith has sex with men but not with women. In the last 12 months Keith has had 10 sexual partners. He prefers receptive anal sex. He uses condoms as much as possible, however has been known to get "caught up in the moment". He currently has no symptoms of an STI and feels well. He recently underwent STI screening which was negative for Chlamydia, Gonorrhoea, HIV, Syphilis and Hepatitis B. He has had no new sexual partners since the screening. 

What is the most effective preventative strategy that could be implemented for Keith?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is the use of HIV anti-viral medications to prevent the transmission of HIV. When taken daily, PrEP is up to 99 per cent effective in preventing HIV. Currently only one medication is approved for use as PrEP: co-formulated tenofovir and emtricitabine. It has been used for many years to treat HIV under its
brand name, Truvada. 

Regular HIV screening should be undertaken while on PrEP, however this is not a preventative measure. While 100% condom use is a useful preventative activity, it is unrealistic, as is determining his partner's HIV status prior to intercourse. While post-exposure prophylaxis is as effective as PrEP, commencing PrEP now eliminates the risk that Keith will find himself in a situation where he is at risk and unable to get to a doctor. 

http://www.mshc.org.au/HealthProfessional/PrEP/tabid/1080/Default.aspx
IncorrectAnswers: Determine his partner's HIV status prior to engaging in intercourse;;Advise 100% condom use;;Request post-exposure prophylaxis in the event of an unprotected sexual encounter;;Attend regular screening for HIV

Text:
Joseph is a 75 year old man with prostate cancer. He complains of increasing low back pain. Imaging reveals blastic metastatic disease to two adjacent lumbar vertebrae. 

What is the next step in management of his back pain?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
TREATMENT OF PATIENTS WITH SYMPTOMATIC BONE METASTASES

External beam radiation therapy   External beam radiation therapy (RT) is the treatment of choice for men with castration-resistant prostate cancer and bone pain that is limited to one or a limited number of sites. (UpToDate)

NOTE: This was a 2017 Deakin MCQ
IncorrectAnswers: External beam radiation of prostate;;Watchful waiting;;Radical prostatectomy;;Anti-androgens

Text: Which of the following is NOT an absolute contraindication to thrombolysis in the setting of STEMI?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Ischaemic stroke within 3 months is an absolute contraindication, outside of this period it is not an ABSOLUTE contraindication (however it is a relative contraindication).

The following are absolute contraindications to thrombolysis:
- Risk of bleeding with active bleed or coagulopathy
- Closed head injury or facial trauma <3mth
- Suspected aortic dissection
- Ischaemic stroke <3mths
- ICH at any time
- Known cerebrovascular lesion
- Known intracranial tumour

Source: eTG "Principles of management of STEMI"
IncorrectAnswers: Closed head injury 2 months prior;;Suspected aortic dissection;;PHx ruptured Berry aneurysm repaired 10 years prior;;Known glioblastoma multiforme

Text:
Dr Smith, an anaesthetist, is called to the Emergency Department for a patient involved in a motor vehicle accident with chest injury. When Dr Smith arrives, the patient's GCS is 7 (E1V2M4), his blood pressure is 80/45, his oxygen saturation is 85% and he is tachycardic at 140bpm. 

Concerned about the patient's airway, Dr Smith performs a rapid sequence intubation. Shortly afterwards, the patient goes into cardiac arrest. 

Which of the following is LEAST likely to have contributed to the patient's cardiac arrest?
CorrectAnswer: Use of Ketamine as an induction agent
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Intubation in the shocked patient can precipitate cardiac arrest by worsening acidosis, hypoxia and hypotension. 

Positive pressure ventilation contributes by decreasing venous return. Propofol is a cardiac depressant, venodilator and vasodilator, thus will reduce cardiac output, worsening hypotension. Ketamine is the induction agent of choice as it has the least cardiac depressant effects.

Techniques for minimising this risk are effective pre-oxygenation, fluid resuscitation and inotropic support if necessary prior to intubation, low dose induction agents (even omitting if pt is sedated enough as a result of shock). 

Source: https://lifeinthefastlane.com/ccc/rapid-sequence-induction-of-the-shock-patient/
IncorrectAnswers: Inadequate pre-oxygenation;;Use of Propofol as an induction agent;;Positive pressure ventilation;;Inadequate fluid resuscitation

Text: Which of the following is MORE common among women who have sex exclusively with women compared with women who have sex exclusively with men?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Prevalence of bacterial vaginosis among the WSW population is significantly higher than in the WSM population. 

Prevalence of HPV is similar in both groups. 

Female to female transmission of gonorrhoea and chlamydia is uncommon. 

Current evidence indicates that women who have sex with women (WSW) have the same rate of STIs as heterosexual women, however the prevalence of particular STIs differs between these groups. WSW should not be presumed to be at low or no risk for STIs based on sexual orientation. 

http://www.sti.guidelines.org.au/populations-and-situations/wsw-women-who-have-sex-with-women#testing-advice
IncorrectAnswers: All are less common;;HPV;;Gonorrhoea;;Chlamydia

Text: Which of the following is CORRECT regarding central control of breathing?
CorrectAnswer: The pontine respiratory group is a key region for rhythm setting and the 'off-switch' for inspiration
IncorrectAnswers: The DRG is active during expiration only;;The dorsal respiratory group is active only during vigorous exercise;;The central pattern generator is located in the Pre-botzinger complex;;The central rhythm generator can be found in the Pons

Text: On the Wigger's diagram, the dicrotic notch indicates
IncorrectAnswers: Closure of the mitral valve;;Ventricular contraction;;Opening of the mitral valve;;Atrial contraction causing the atrial 'kick'

Text:
A 28-year-old woman presents at 32+2 weeks gestation to a rural hospital. She has had an uncomplicated pregnancy so far, but half an hour prior she complained of a sensation of wetting herself. She has an unknown GBS status. She is G0P2 with one previous miscarriage. On palpation her abdomen is non-tender and the fundus is soft and palpable at 30cm. Aside from being obviously anxious, the mother is well. Foetal HR is 145 with variability and no decelerations. 

What treatment should be initiated while she is being transferred to a tertiary centre?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This is a difficult question (which featured in 2018 Deakin MCQs).
