The way to arrive at the correct answer is first to identify that the patient is presenting in PPROM (preterm premature rupture of membranes). She is presenting prior to 34 weeks, therefore she needs steroids for prophylaxis for neonatal respiratory distress. This rules out two answers in which steroids are not included. Ideally, she needs 2 doses of steroids 24 hours apart. As such, she will have prolonged rupture of membranes and therefore will need antibiotic prophylaxis. Erythromycin is currently recommended for women over 32 weeks. 

The option of terbutaline is a distractor, as based upon the stem the patient is not in active labour. 

https://thewomens.r.worldssl.net/images/uploads/downloadable-records/clinical-guidelines/rupture-of-membranes-preterm-premature-pprom_160517.pdf
IncorrectAnswers: Betamethasone;;Penicillin;;Terbutaline and Penicillin;;Betamethasone and Terbutaline

Text: Which of the following is NOT a component of active third stage management?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Maternal positioning such as squatting or sitting is used in physiological third stage management, where the placenta is expelled via maternal effort. 

https://thewomens.r.worldssl.net/images/uploads/downloadable-records/clinical-guidelines/third-stage-labour-management_150517.pdf
IncorrectAnswers: Uterine massage;;Prophylactic oxytocin administration;;Early cord clamping;;Controlled cord traction

Text:
Richard is a 27 year old snowboarder who was involved in a high velocity accident, in which his sustained a complete spinal cord injury at T4. He was transferred to the rehabilitation ward many months ago and is slowly working on strategies that will allow him to leave hospital. 

You attend Richard's room to check on him and he complains of a pounding headache, blurry vision and a blocked nose. He feels anxious and his face appears flushed. You note in his chart that he has not moved his bowels in three days. On taking his vital signs you find that his blood pressure is 125/80 and his heart rate is 55bpm. 

How would you manage Richard?
Topics: Emergency Medicine(Year 4);;Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This scenario depicts autonomic dysreflexia. 

Patient's with a lesion higher than T6 are vulnerable to this condition. A noxious stimulus below the level of the lesion triggers an exaggerated sympathetic response. 

Classic signs are a pounding headache, nasal congestion, flushing and sweating above the level of the lesion, bradycardia and an elevated blood pressure 20-40mmHg above the patient's baseline. It is important to note that a spinal injured patient will have a lower than average blood pressure so readings may appear normotensive to the inexperienced practitioner (As mentioned in "Common Conditions in Rehab 2" lecture.
IncorrectAnswers: Prescribe a decongestant;;Prescribe opioid analgesia;;Obtain a CT brain;;Prescribe aperients

Text: Of the options below, what is the most important prognostic factor when evaluating melanoma?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
http://www.mmmp.org/MMMP/import.mmmp?page=prog_factors.mmmp

NOTE: This was  Deakin MCQ in 2017. Other important prognostic factors that were not included in this answer are ulceration, lymph node involvement and distant metastasis.
IncorrectAnswers: Regression;;Patient age at diagnosis;;Clark level;;Size

Text: Which of the following is NOT associated with increased risk of being unable to live independently after a lower limb amputation?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
All patients will benefit from inpatient rehabilitation post-operatively, especially in a facility specialising in amputation.

Most patients living independently prior to major amputation remain independent postoperatively. Highly motivated patients, as evidenced by commitment to a strict rehabilitation program including smoking cessation and weight loss, are more likely to achieve long-term success [82]. Patients with financial resources that allow participation in a well-organized rehabilitation program are also more likely to be successful. The following preoperative factors were found to be significantly associated with an increased risk of being unable to maintain independent living status following amputation [80]:

Ï%Age e70 years (hazard ratio [HR] 4.0

Text: Which of the following vaccinations is NOT routinely given at 12 months of age?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Rotavirus oral vaccine is given at 2 and 4 months. 

While rote-learning the schedule might seem like a waste of time, it has come up in previous MCQs so revising it is not a bad idea. 

https://beta.health.gov.au/health-topics/immunisation/immunisation-throughout-life/national-immunisation-program-schedule
IncorrectAnswers: Pneumococcal if born prematurely (<28 weeks);;MMR;;Hib;;Meningococcal C

Text: Which of the following is NOT observed in COPD?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Although the functional capacity of the lungs is reduced in COPD, the total lung capacity is increased.
IncorrectAnswers: Reduced FEV1 to FVC ratio;;Flattening of the diaphragm;;Increased respiratory dead space;;Expanded 'barrel-shaped' chest

Text: In which of the following conditions is the following ECG change observed?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
These are J or Osborn waves which are characteristically observed in severe hypothermia. 

https://lifeinthefastlane.com/ecg-library/basics/osborn-wave-j-wave/
IncorrectAnswers: Hypermagnesaemia;;Hyponatraemia;;Pericarditis;;STEMI

Text:
Eloise is a 45-year-old woman sent into ED after her GP discovered elevated liver function tests in the setting of fatigue and lethargy. 

The liver function tests are as follows:
ALT 1010 (<35)
AST 876 (<40)
GGT 124 (<30)
ALP 130 (30-110)
Bilirubin (total) 50 (<20)

On history Eloise reports 1 week of fatigue, lethargy and mild nausea. Past history reveals obesity and chronic right knee pain which Eloise manages with Panadol Osteo. It has flared up recently requiring Eloise to use Panadiene Forte at times. She also takes the oral contraceptive pill. She is a non-smoker and drinks a glass of wine a night. On examination, Eloise is obese and has mild scleral icterus. You note a palpable liver border which is mildly tender but Murphy's sign is negative. 

What is the most likely cause for Eloise's presentation?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Paracetamol OD is the most common cause of acute liver failure, accounting for 46% of presentations. In Eloise's case, the clue is her uncontrolled right knee pain which she has been managing with multiple paracetamol-containing products. Unintentional overdoses are more common than expected and are important to recognise. 

Autoimmune hepatitis is a possibility in this age group with a hepatitic pattern of LFTs and is the major distractor here, however this is less common than paracetamol OD and in an MCQ you would expect to see a personal or family history of autoimmune disease. 

Eloise fits the demographics for gallstones however her LFTs show a hepatitic, not obstructive, pattern and she is Murphy's negative. Pancreatic cancer would likely have features of weight loss and would also show an obstructive pattern. 

Alcoholic liver disease would typically show elevated AST>ALT.
IncorrectAnswers: Autoimmune hepatitis;;Choledocolithiasis;;Alcoholic hepatitis;;Pancreatic cancer

Text:
Josephine is a 77-year-old woman who lives alone after her husband died 12 months prior. She is brought in by her concerned daughter who has noticed that her mother is "slowing down". Since her husband died she has experienced agitation during the day and wanders at night, for which she has been commenced on Haloperidol as required. Josephine has experienced recent falls and mobilises with a shuffling gait. On examination you note stiffness in Josephine's limbs and a significant postural drop. 

What is the next step in management?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Haloperidol is associated with extrapyramidal side effects and should be ceased in this case. 

Although a Parkinson's or Parkinson's plus disorder could also explain Josephine's symptoms, iatrogenic causes should be excluded prior to initiating new therapies. 

NOTE: This question was included in Deakin MCQ exams in 2017 AND 2018 (although it had an even longer stem if you can believe that).
IncorrectAnswers: Commence Diazepam;;Commence Benztropine;;Commence Olanzepine;;Commence Levodopa

Text: Which of the following is NOT included in instructions to patient's commencing bisphosphonate therapy?
CorrectAnswer: Take on a full stomach to minimise GI side effects
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Due to poor oral absorption of bisphosphonates, food, drink (apart from water) and medication should be avoided before and after administration, according to the product information for each drug. Calcium salts, antacids, and iron and magnesium supplements inhibit absorption, and should not be taken within 2 hours of bisphosphonates.

Source: eTG - "Treating osteoporosis"
IncorrectAnswers: Adverse effects include oesophagitis and diarrhoea;;Oral or intravenous preparations are available;;Remain sitting upright for 30 minutes post taking;;Attend a dental check up prior to commencing

Text: Which of the following does NOT cause urethral discharge in men?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
DDx for male urethral discharge should include all of the listed answers except Syphilis, which typically presents in the first instance (primary syphilis) with one or more painless genital ulcers (chancre) and inguinal lymphadenopathy. 

Other DDxs for male urethral discharge include Herpes Simplex, Adenoviruses and Ureaplasma urealyticum. 

http://www.sti.guidelines.org.au/syndromes/urethritis-male#possible-causes
IncorrectAnswers: Trichomonas;;Gonorrhoea;;Mycoplasma Genitalium;;Chlamydia

Text:
Harold is a 56-year-old lawyer with Type 2 Diabetes, managed with oral Metformin and insulin. He presents to the Emergency Department disoriented and feeling very unwell. He reports feeling excessively thirsty and passing copious urine. He has recently received a course of oral antibiotics for a left leg cellulitis which is not improving. As he has not had much of an appetite, he has omitted his usual insulin. His BGL reads "high" on the machine. 

You suspect Harold is experiencing Hyperosmolar Hyperglycaemic Syndrome (HHS). 

When should IV insulin be commenced?
CorrectAnswer: Once his BGL plateaus after IV fluid resuscitation
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
In HHS, dehydration must be corrected prior to administering insulin. IV fluid administration alone may cause blood glucose to drop by 4-11 points. 

While potassium greater than 3.5 is also a criterion for commencing insulin, his potassium may be 3.5 now - however you would still not commence insulin prior to adequate fluid resuscitation. This is the main distractor. 

IV insulin would be ceased once he commences oral intake. 

There is no need to wait until the blood glucose level is returned from pathology - a reading of "High" indicates a BSL of >33 and in this clinical setting that is sufficient to commence treatment. You would also likely send off an ABG which would give you a BSL immediately. 

Source: eTG
IncorrectAnswers: Immediately;;Once his blood glucose level is obtained from pathology;;Once he commences oral intake;;Once his potassium level is known to be >3.5

Text:
Harry is a 34-year-old who presents to the Emergency Department in an agitated state. On examination you observe piloerection, rhinorrhoea, dilated pupils and frequent yawning. 

What is Harry withdrawing from?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This is a classic description of opioid withdrawal. 

NOTE: This was a Deakin MCQ in 2017.
IncorrectAnswers: Cannabis ;;Alcohol;;Cocaine;;Benzodiazepines

Text:
Theresa is a 90 year-old resident of a high level nursing home who has been diagnosed with pneumonia after experiencing several days of fever, worsening cough and shortness of breath.

What is the most common causative agent of pneumonia in high-level care nursing homes?
Topics: General Medicine(Year 3);;Emergency Medicine(Year 4);;Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4);;General Practice(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Unlike hospital acquired pneumonias, the most common cause of pneumonia in nursing home residents is Streptococcus Pneumonia. Agents such as E Coli and Pseudomonas are common in admitted patients. Mycoplasma is particularly common in young adults. Haemophilus predominantly affects patients with COPD.

https://tgldcdp-tg-org-au.ezproxy-f.deakin.edu.au/viewTopic?etgAccess=true&guidelinePage=Antibiotic&topicfile=community-acquired-pneumonia&guidelineName=Antibiotic&sectionId=toc_d1e1225#toc_d1e1225 
https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/234916-overview
https://academic.oup.com/cid/article/35/10/1205/296925
https://www.aafp.org/afp/2009/0601/p976.html

NOTE: This was a Deakin MCQ in 2017.
IncorrectAnswers: Escherichia Coli;;Mycoplasma Pneumoniae;;Haemophilus Influenza;;Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Text: Which of the following is NOT a known risk factor for difficult intubation?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Edentulous patients are less likely to have a difficult intubation. 

NOTE: This was a Deakin MCQ in 2017
IncorrectAnswers: Mallampati score 4;;Cervical fusion;;Retrognathia;;Neck circumference >40cm

Text: The reaction which results in the outer layer of the ovum becoming impenetrable to other sperm is referred to as the:
IncorrectAnswers: Fusion;;Calcific reaction;;Pellucida reaction;;Zona pellucida

Text:
Mr Smith is a 67 year old who presents to the Emergency Department with fever, shortness of breath and productive cough. After thorough history and examination, the medical team suspects pneumonia to be the cause of his illness. 

Which of the following is not used as part of determining Mr Smith's mortality risk?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This question requires familiarity with the CURB-65 scoring system which estimates a patient's 30 day mortality risk from community acquired pneumonia. 

Components include:
Confusion
Urea/BUN >7mmol/L
Respiratory rate >30
Blood pressure SBP <90 +/- DBP <60
Age 65+

https://www.mdcalc.com/curb-65-score-pneumonia-severity
IncorrectAnswers: Confusion;;BUN;;Age;;Blood pressure

Text: Which of the following is NOT part of the evaluation of a woman seeking a surgical termination of pregnancy (STOP)?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
See Dr Deepika Monga's lecture titled "Termination of pregnancy" on the Women's Health Cloud site. 

Beta-hCG and ultrasound will confirm an ongoing viable pregnancy, STI screening for chlamydia is important to stratify risk of post-operative endometritis and blood group is important to determine if anti-D should be given. 

Vaginal examination will be undertaken intra-operatively and is not essential prior to procedure.
IncorrectAnswers: Blood group;;beta-hCG;;Ultrasound;;STI screening

Text:
Jessie is an 89-year-old woman undergoing a repair of her fractured left neck of femur after she had a fall. Due to her age, her anaesthetist performs a femoral nerve block so as to avoid a general anaesthetic. 

As the surgery begins, Jessie complains of tingling of her tongue and lips, although they do not appear swollen. She become agitated, moving around on the table, reporting feeling anxious and annoyed by the ringing in her ears. Her blood pressure begins to rise.

What is the definitive management of the condition Jessie is displaying?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The scenario above depicts LAST syndrome (local anaesthetic systemic toxicity), due to excessive or accidental systemic administration of local anaesthetic during a femoral nerve block. The early hallmarks of this condition are perioral tingling, tinnitus and agitation. If untreated, Jessie is at risk of neurological and cardiovascular complications: namely seizure and shock-refractory arrhythmias. 

IV Intralipid is administered in order to bind free circulating local anaesthetic. 

IM Adrenaline would be administered in the event of anaphylactic reaction to anaesthetic agents. Although Jessie does have perioral tingling which may indicate anaphylaxis, the absence of swelling makes this less likely. Anaphylaxis also does not explain the tinnitus or agitation. 

Dantrolene is used in management of malignant hyperthermia. Sedation might be appropriate in the setting of patient anxiety. 

Ceasing the surgery is an important step but would not manage the condition.
IncorrectAnswers: Reassure and consider sedation;;Adrenaline;;Cease the surgery;;Dantrolene

Text:
Leah is a 26 year old who presents to her GP seeking the oral contraceptive pill. 

Which of the following is NOT an absolute contraindication to prescribing the OCP to this patient?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Smoking is not considered an absolute contraindication unless the woman is >35 years of age and smokes >15 cigarettes a day. 

https://www.ranzcog.edu.au/RANZCOG_SITE/media/RANZCOG-MEDIA/Women's%20Health/Statement%20and%20guidelines/Clinical-Obstetrics/Combined-hormonal-contraceptives-(C-Gyn-28)-Review-March-2016.pdf?ext=.pdf
IncorrectAnswers: Previous DVT;;< 6 weeks postpartum;;Migraine with aura;;Breast cancer

Text: To which lymph nodes is testicular cancer most likely to spread?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The testes (and ovaries) drain to the para-aortic lymph nodes. 

NOTE: This question has come up in both 2017 and 2018 Deakin MCQs.
IncorrectAnswers: Femoral;;Iliac;;Inguinal;;Pudendal

Text: Which of the following is NOT a prognostic indicator in acute pancreatitis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Ranson's Criteria:
LDH >350
Age >55
WBC >16
AST >250
Glucose >10

NOTE: This was a Deakin MCQ in 2017
IncorrectAnswers: Age >55;;AST >250;;Glucose level >10;;LDH >350

Text:
Mr Brown is a 55-year-old patient recovering on the Cardiology Ward after suffering from a NSTEMI. He was taken to the Cath Lab after suffering from an episode of chest pain and associated Troponin rise. Mr Brown's cardiologist reports that diffuse vessel disease was observed, for medical management. 

You are preparing Mr Brown's discharge instructions and attend to take a brief history to guide management. Mr Brown's past history includes hypertension, smoking and asthma which is triggered by exercise, cold air and NSAIDs but is currently well controlled. He has had a previous nasal polypectomy. His admission bloods showed a healthy lipid profile and normal renal function. 

Which of the following should you seek his Cardiologist's advice on prior to discharging Mr Brown?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This is a difficult question and relies upon your knowledge of contraindications to Aspirin therapy. 

Mr Brown has a history of NSAID-induced asthma and sinus surgery, which indicates Samter's triad. Mr Brown should have aspirin desensitisation therapy before commencing on regular Aspirin. He may be suitable for Clopidogrel alone, or possibly another anticoagulant, depending on the degree of disease. 

Although he has a normal lipid profile, statins are still recommended for secondary prevention. 

A beta-blocker would also be contraindicated in the presence of asthma.
IncorrectAnswers: Perindopril 5mg daily;;Smoking cessation;;Atorvastatin 40mg daily;;Clopidogrel 75mg daily

Text:
Mr Jones is a 74-year-old who presents to the Emergency department following a fall. He was not injured but could not get himself off the floor, and was incontinent of urine. Mr Jones relates that he has had a number of recent falls, usually on rising from his bed. He sleeps poorly so gets up a lot at night. He becomes dizzy prior to falling. 

In the course of your examination you notice that a tremor in both of his hands which is suppressed when he attempts motor tasks. He displays cogwheel rigidity and hypertonia when you attempt to move either wrist. He walks with a shuffling gait. 

What is the most likely underlying diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
MSA is one of the Parkinson's Plus disorders and should be considered alongside Parkinson's Disease. 

Although it is difficult to distinguish from PD, especially early in the disease course, features that may suggest MSA as a more likely diagnosis are:

- Symmetrical distribution of tremor
- Early urinary incontinence
- Prominent autonomic symptoms (as seen in this case in Mr Jones's orthostatic hypotension)

Parkinson's disease is typically asymmetrical at onset and autonomic symptoms are less pronounced. Dementia with Lewy bodies is a possibility but in an MCQ you would expect some mention of cognitive symptoms, which typically precede motor symptoms or feature within one year of symptom onset. 

Orthostatic hypotension is present in the stem but is a symptom, rather than a diagnosis. UTI is a possibility but is not strongly suggested.
IncorrectAnswers: Dementia with Lewy bodies;;Urinary tract infection;;Orthostatic hypotension;;Parkinson's Disease

Text:
Mr Walker is a 60-year-old gentleman who comes to his GP complaining of joint pain and stiffness over the last several months. On history, he is experiencing pain in both shoulders. It is worst in the mornings when he has a great deal of trouble getting out of bed. His hips are also "giving him trouble". He is feeling very lethargic and has lost 3 kilos of weight over the period of unwellness. 

Given the likely diagnosis, what examination should be performed in addition to examining his affected joints?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The likely diagnosis here is Polymyalgia Rheumatica, given the symmetrical shoulder girdle and hip girdle pain coupled with constitutional symptoms. 

15% of patients with PMR also have Temporal Arteritis (Giant cell arteritis). This is a serious and potentially sight-threatening condition which requires specialist treatment. Patients with PMR should be screened for GCA by asking about headaches, jaw claudication, scalp tenderness and visual changes in history and palpating the scalp over the superficial temporal artery, noting pain, palpable pulsation or thickening of the artery. 

The rest are irrelevant to PMR. 

Source: eTG "Polymyalgia Rheumatica"
IncorrectAnswers: Back examination;;PR exam;;Lung auscultation;;Skin examination for rashes

Text: Which of the following is NOT true of malignant hyperthermia?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Signs of malignant hyperthermia include muscle rigidity (detected by palpation of the masseters), HYPERcapnoea (not hypocapnoea), acidosis and hyperthermia.
IncorrectAnswers: Caused by excessive calcium release;;Results in rhabdomyolysis if untreated;;Tends to run in families;;An early sign is masseter rigidity

Text: Regarding viral rashes, which of the following is INCORRECT?
CorrectAnswer: Roseola - rash coincides with high fever
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The rash of Roseola appears as the fever subsides

https://www.dermnetnz.org/topics/exanthems/

Rubella
- Rash begins on the face that spreads to the neck, trunk and extremities.
- Appear as pink or light red spots about 2 3 mm in size.
- Lasts up to 5 days (average is 3 days).
- May or may not be itchy.
- As rash passes, affected skin may shed in flakes.
- Usually not as widespread as in measles

Varicella
- Initial appearance on face and trunk, in crops. 
- Extremely itchy
- Predominantly central and proximal upper extremities, relative sparing of lower limbs. May affect oropharynx. 
- Lesion progression: macule > papule > vesicle > crusted. 
- Typically 250-500 lesions at different stages.

Roseola
- Rash appears around days 3 to 5, as fever subsides
- Typically small rose-pink or red raised spots (2 5 mm in diameter) that blanch (turn white) when touched
- Some spots may be surrounded by a lighter halo of pale skin
- Mainly affects trunk and rarely spreads to involve neck, face, arms and legs
- Similar spots occur on soft palate and uvula (Nagayama spots)
- Non-itchy, painless and does not blister
- May fade within a few hours or persist for as long as 2 days

Measles
- 2 3 days into the prodromal phase, Koplik spots appear. These are blue-white spots on the inside of the mouth opposite the molars, and occur 24 48 hours before the exanthem (rash) stage.
- Red spots ranging from 0.1 1.0cm in diameter appear on the 4th or 5th day following the start of symptoms.
- This non-itchy rash begins on face and behind the ears. Within 24 36 hours it spreads to the entire trunk and extremities (palms and soles rarely involved).
- The spots may all join together, especially in areas of the face.
- Rash usually coincides with the appearance of a high fever >/= 40C.
- Rash begins to fade 3 4 days after it first appears. To begin with it fades to a purplish hue and then to brown/coppery coloured lesions with fine scales.
IncorrectAnswers: Measles - Non-itchy rash;;Roseola - Non-itchy rash;;Measles - Rash coincides with high fever;;Varicella - lesions appear in crops

Text: In an infant born prematurely at 20 weeks, which of the following would NOT be observed?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: A 21 week infant has not yet developed type II pneumocytes, and thus cannot respond to glucocorticoids.
IncorrectAnswers: Sternal retraction;;Unevenly expanding alveoli;;Low DPPC levels compared to a term infant;; Increased hysteresis compared to a term infant

Text: Which of the following chest x-ray features suggests ARDS rather than APO?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: http://www.svuhradiology.ie/case-study/adult-respiratory-distress-syndrome-ards-chest-x-ray/
IncorrectAnswers: Kerley B lines;;Cardiomegaly;;Perihilar distribution in early stages;;Pleural effusions

Text: In Australia, which of the following is NOT a recommended method of controlling nausea and vomiting during pregnancy?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This will catch you out if you have been studying exclusively from PassMedicine!

Although widely used in the UK for nausea and vomiting during pregnancy, Cyclizine is not approved for general use in Australia and is available under Special Access only, where it is typically used in palliative care. 

The other options are recommended on eTG - Nausea and vomiting during pregnancy. 

This one is more to prevent you suggesting Cyclizine if you get a N&V in pregnancy in OSCE TBH.
IncorrectAnswers: Powdered Ginger;;Ondansetron;;Prochlorperazine;;Pyridoxine plus doxylamine

Text: In comparing pulmonary and systemic circulations, which of the following is FALSE?
CorrectAnswer: Systemic circulation exhibits a higher flow than pulmonary circulation.
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Systemic and pulmonary circulations have equal flow.
IncorrectAnswers: The primary site of pressure loss across the pulmonary circulation is capillary beds, versus arterioles in systemic circulation;;The valveless nature of the pulmonary circulation increases it's vulnerability to oedema;;Low oxygen environments result in systemic vasodilation and pulmonary vasoconstriction;;Resistance in systemic circulation is significantly higher than in pulmonary circulation

Text:
A 3-week-old baby is brought to the Emergency Department with fever and vomiting. She was born at term via a normal vaginal delivery with no antenatal or postnatal complication. Her GBS status is unknown. She is fully breastfed. Her sister and father have both been unwell with nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea. On examination you observe normal tone and colour. Central capillary refill is <2s, temp 39, HR 150.

What should the next step be?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
A febrile infant of less than one month should have a comprehensive septic workup. 

https://www.rch.org.au/clinicalguide/guideline_index/Febrile_Child/ \

NOTE: This was a Deakin MCQ in 2017.
IncorrectAnswers: FBE/UEC/LFT and blood cultures;;Encourage regular fluids and admit for 6/24 weighs;;Insert NGT and give 100ml via NGT;;Reassure parents and advise to follow up with GP

Text:
A 14-year-old boy is referred to the paediatric neurology clinic. He has experienced 4 tonic-clonic seizures in the past month. His EEG shows no abnormality. He is otherwise neurodevelopmentally normal on history and examination. 

What is your next step in management?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Most children who present with a second unprovoked seizure are started on antiseizure drug therapy, since seizure recurrence indicates that the patient has a substantially increased risk for additional seizures (ie, epilepsy). (UpToDate: Seizures and epilepsy in children: Initial treatment and monitoring). 

The most appropriate drug of those included in the answers is Sodium Valproate, as Carbamazepine is indicated for treatment of focal seizures. 

NOTE: This was a question on the 2017 AND 2018 Deakin MCQs. The answer is correct based on the best information I can find, however I'm happy to be corrected.
IncorrectAnswers: Reassure his parents;;Repeat EEG;;MRI;;Commence carbamazepine

Text: Nasal turbinates play an important role in respiration. Which of the following is NOT a function of nasal turbinates?
CorrectAnswer: Warming inspired air to improve the solubility of oxygen
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Warming inspired air reduces the solubility of oxygen
IncorrectAnswers: Humidifying air to protect respiratory tract tissues;;Trapping particulate matter in inspired air;;Encouraging turbulent air flow;;Warming inspired air to prevent air embolus

Text: From which tissue in the embryo does the respiratory system develop?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The respiratory diverticulum arises from the ventral wall of the foregut.
IncorrectAnswers: Midgut;;Respiratory crescent;;Cardiac crescent;;Hindgut

Text:
Bobby is a 2-year-old child brought to the GP by his worried mother. Since yesterday he has been crying, distressed, and tugging his left ear. He slept poorly last night and is increasingly clingy today. 

On examination Bobby is crying loudly. He has a temperature of 37.5. Observations are otherwise unremarkable. With difficulty you perform an ENT examination, which reveals a healthy appearance of the external auditory meatus and a bulging tympanic membrane. 

How should Bobby be managed?
CorrectAnswer: Reassurance, simple analgesia and review in 24 hours
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
eTG: Treatment of Acute Otitis Media.

Avoid the routine use of antibiotic therapy for acute otitis media.

For most children, initial antibiotic therapy is not indicated. A number of studies support an approach where initially patients are observed and antibiotic therapy is only started if symptoms do not improve or worsen; however, if this approach is used, a mechanism must be in place to ensure the patient is followed up.

Amoxicillin would be suitable if Bobby had systemic symptoms such as high fever, vomiting or lethargy (37.5 is not a high fever). Amoxicillin/Clavulanate would be suitable if Bobby had been treated with Amoxicillin with no response. Topical antibiotic drops are used in management of Otitis Externa, not Otitis Media. Simple Otitis Media does not require emergency management.
IncorrectAnswers: Commence Amoxicillin and Clavulanic Acid;;Commence topical antibiotic drops;;Commence Amoxicillin and review in 24 hours;;Send Bobby to the nearest Emergency Department for evaluation

Text: How many times is the diphtheria/tetanus/pertussis vaccination given prior to 15 years of age (assuming given only via schedule)?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Pertussis immunity is particularly difficult to maintain and regular boosters are required. Immunisations to DTP are given at 2, 4, 6 and 18 months, 4 years, and in adolescence (that's every visit except the 12 month visit).

This is an annoying question and yes, it's redundant to try and rote learn the vaccination schedule but questions have come up in the past. Hopefully this question will serve as a prompt for a brief revision of the schedule. 

https://beta.health.gov.au/health-topics/immunisation/immunisation-throughout-life/national-immunisation-program-schedule

Text: Which of the following is FALSE of Sugammadex?
CorrectAnswer: Is used in combination with Glycopyrulate
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Sugammadex is a true reversal agent for neuromuscular blockade with certain agents. Although it's action is most rapid with Rocuronium, it can be used to reverse Vecuronium and Pancuronium as well. 

Reversal of Rocuronium with Sugammadex is faster than reversal of suxamethonium by approximately 2 minutes, hence Rocuronium can be used safely in rapid sequence intubation. 

Cholinergic side effects are observed with Neostigmine which is used as a reversal agent for other neuromuscular blocking agents. This is combated through use of Atropine or Glycopyrulate. This is not an issue with Sugammadex.
IncorrectAnswers: Mechanism of action is binding free drug;;Reversal of Rocuronium with Sugammadex is faster than spontaneous suxamethonium reversal;;Renally eliminated;;Is used to reverse Vecuronium

Text: Which of the following is NOT true of gonorrhoea?
CorrectAnswer: Most men who have a positive first pass urine test are asymptomatic
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Only 10-15% of men whose FPU is positive are asymptomatic. 

However, throat and rectal sites are frequently asymptomatic so these sites should be tested in asymptomatic individuals who are at risk, particularly men who have sex with men.

Urethral swab should only be used when discharge is present - asymptomatic men can be tested using first pass urine. 

http://www.sti.guidelines.org.au/sexually-transmissible-infections/gonorrhoea#management
IncorrectAnswers: Can cause pelvic inflammatory disease;;Managed with IM Ceftriaxone AND oral Azithromycin;;Diagnosis can be made using a first pass urine or urethral swab;;Most commonly diagnosed in men who have sex with men (MSM), among young (heterosexual) Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people living in remote and very remote areas and travellers returning from high prevalence areas overseas

Text: Which of the following is a reassuring sign when evaluating a patient with vertigo?
Topics: General Medicine(Year 3);;Emergency Medicine(Year 4);;Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Vertigo may have peripheral or central causes. Central causes are the most worrisome, as they  may indicate an underlying stroke or CNS tumour. 

In peripheral vertigo, the nystagmus can be suppressed by visual fixation

The rest of the options are suggestive of a central cause. 

NOTE: The Head Impulse test is part of the HINTS exam which aims to determine if vertigo is due to central or peripheral cause. A positive Head Impulse test is an expected finding in BPPV and reassuring that vertigo is due to a peripheral cause. Therefore a negative test in a patient with nystagmus and vertigo is worrying. 

See "Vestibular Rehabilitation" lecture on the ARP Cloud site.
IncorrectAnswers: Nystagmus changes direction with eccentric eye movement;;Purely vertical nystagmus;;Negative Head Impulse test;;Persistent regardless of head position or movement

Text:
Mrs Litchfield is a 77-year-old woman with advanced metastatic ovarian cancer. She is known to the palliative care team. She lives independently with her husband. She presents to the Emergency Department with increasing pain secondary to her abdominal metastases. 

After a thorough evaluation and treatment with intravenous morphine, Mrs Litchfield is stable and comfortable. She is keen to go home. 

Mrs Litchfield takes 40mg slow-release Oxycodone twice daily. 

What dose of PRN quick-release oxycodone is suitable for discharge?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4);;General Practice(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
PRN dose = 1/10 to 1/6 of basal opioid dose. 

1/10 = 8mg. 1/6 = 13.3mg. Available strength = 5mg tablets. 

Therefore 10mg PRN is the most practical dose. The other suggested doses are either excessive or inadequate. 

There is no suggestion of malabsorption or intolerance of oral medications, and as Mrs Litchfield lives independently a syringe driver is unnecessary.
IncorrectAnswers: 20mg;;Mrs Litchfield should be commenced on a syringe driver.;;2.5mg;;5mg

Text: Which of the following is CORRECT regarding local anaesthetic systemic toxicity?
CorrectAnswer: Neurological signs typically precede cardiovascular signs
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The initial signs of LAST are neurological in nature: perioral tingling, tinnitus and restlessness are typical. However, these are often masked by general anaesthesia. Hypotension, bradycardia and shock-refractory arrhythmias typically follow. Onset is rapid after administration of local anaesthetic
IncorrectAnswers: Can be detected early in patients under general anaesthetic;;Dantrolene is used in management;;Typically occurs hours after local anaesthetic administration;;Arrhythmias typically respond well to defibrillation

Text:
Gerry is a 24-year-old male who is receiving electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) for schizophrenia for the first time. Anaesthesia is induced with Propofol and suxamethonium is administered for muscle relaxation. 

Upon completion of his therapy Gerry fails to recommence spontaneous breathing. After 15 minutes, Gerry still requires bag-valve ventilation and is making no spontaneous breathing efforts. A BIS monitor is applied and reads at 75. 

What is the mechanism of his condition?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The above situation describes "Sux Apnoea", which is caused by a hereditary deficiency of cholinesterase. As the suxamethonium molecule is composed of Acetylcholine, in patients with cholinesterase deficiency fail to metabolise it via the normal pathways, leading to prolonged muscle relaxant effects. True homozygotes will take up to 6 hours to metabolise the suxamethonium via alternative pathways. 

If you were not familiar with the mechanism of sux apnoea, you could still reason this question out to two remaining answers. The patient is being ventilated via bag and mask, therefore laryngeal spasm is ruled out. BIS monitoring is a measure of hypnosis and this level excludes excessive hypnosis via propofol. An abnormal ryanodine receptor is responsible for malignant hyperthermia.
IncorrectAnswers: Laryngeal spasm;;Excessive Propofol administration;;Abnormal nicotinic receptor;;Abnormal ryanodine receptor

Text: In the respiratory tract of a baby in the canalicular phase of development, you would expect to see:
CorrectAnswerExplanation: http://www.embryology.ch/anglais/rrespiratory/phasen04.html
IncorrectAnswers: Active Type 2 pneumocytes;;Respiratory bronchioles with terminal sacs;;Tertiary bronchial buds with few or no terminal bronchioles;;Mature alveoli

Text:
You are an intern in a busy Emergency department. 

Jenny, a nurse on the floor, presents you with an ECG of a patient presenting with chest pain and dizziness. She doesn't see any obvious ST elevation, but noted some T wave inversion on the chest leads. The ECG is shown below. 

As you review the ECG, Jenny tells you she has taken another ECG just now and the T waves are no longer inverted. 

How should this patient be managed?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This ECG is typical of Wellen's Syndrome: 

Deeply inverted of biphasic T waves in V2-3. 
Isoelectric/<1mm elevated ST, absent Q waves, normal R wave progression. 

Persists when painfree. 

Highly specific for critical stenosis of LAD. If T waves switch from biphasic/inverted to upright and prominent, this signifies reocclusion of the LAD - hyperacute STEMI. 

This is a difficult question, and possible beyond what we need to know, but a good concept to understand nonetheless.
IncorrectAnswers: Perform serial troponins and observe;;Request an outpatient Holter Monitor;;Refer to outpatient Cardiology;;Request a chest xray

Text:
Mr Blatchford is a 77 year old gentleman currently undergoing radiotherapy for oral SCC. He has been referred to inpatient palliative care due to painful stomatitis and dysphagia, leaving him unable to swallow his normal oral oxycodone, and it has been determined he will need a syringe driver for pain management while his oral mucosa recovers. He usually takes 20mg BD Oxycontin and 4x 5mg Endone throughout the day. 

What daily dose of SC morphine will Mr Blatchford require, based on his existing oral oxycodone use?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This question requires knowledge of the conversion calculations for oral oxycodone to oral morphine, and then oral morphine to parenteral morphine. 
Always convert opioids to oral morphine equivalent (OME) prior to converting to another form of opiate.

Oral oxycodone to oral morphine: 1.5x oxycodone dose. 
ie 1.5 x (20+20+[4x5]) = 90mg oral morphine equivalent (OME)

Oral morphine to parenteral morphine (SC/IMI/IV): oral morphine dose / 3
ie 90/3 = 30mg/day SC morphine.
IncorrectAnswers: 120mg/day;;60mg/day;;90mg/day;;20mg/day

Text: Once implantation occurs, the endometrium becomes the decidua, what controls this process?
IncorrectAnswers: Syncitiotrophoblast invasion;;Growth factors from maternal circulation through the lacunae;;Hyaluronic acid

Text: Splitting of the embryo during development results in monozygotic twinning. Splitting at the 2-cell stage of blastocyst formation will result in:
IncorrectAnswers: Conjoined twins;;1 chorion, 1 amnion and 1 placenta;;1 chorion, 2 amnion and 1 placenta

Text: What is the purpose of the cortical reaction?
IncorrectAnswers:
Begin meiosis II within the Oocyte 
;;Release hydrolytic enzymes within the egg cytosol
;;Raise intracellular [Ca2+]

Text: What is the purpose of the cortical reaction?
IncorrectAnswers: Decrease intracellular [Ca2+];;Release hydrolytic enzymes within the egg cytosol;;Begin meiosis II within the Oocyte

Text: Which of the following correctly describes Lichen sclerosus?
CorrectAnswer: Thinning of the vulva with dermal fibrosis
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Red scaley plaques may indicate SCC
Thickening of the vulva and scaling is seen in lichen simplex
Flat brown lesions may indicate HPV or melanoma
Shiny, flat-topped, firm papules are seen in lichen planus
IncorrectAnswers:
Red, scaly plaque caused by proliferation of malignant epithelial cells 
;;Thickening of vulva with scaling
;;Flat, brown lesions on the vulva
;;Shiny, flat-topped, firm papules

Text: Which of the following is the best estimate of mean arterial pressure?
CorrectAnswer: 1/3 x Systolic Pressure + 2/3 x Diastolic Pressure
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The formula of MAP = 1/3 SBP + 2/3 DBP is the best estimate of mean arterial pressure.
IncorrectAnswers: 1/2 x Systolic Pressure + 1/2 x Diastolic Pressure;;Systolic Pressure + 1/3 x Pulse Pressure;;1/2 x Pulse pressure;;2/3 x Systolic Pressure + 1/3 x Diastolic Pressure

Text: In which part of the brain are Lewy bodies found in Lewy body dementia?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Lewy bodies are found diffusely throughout the brain in Lewy body dementia. In contrast to in Parkinson's disease where they are seen in the basal ganglia.

Reference: BB Lecture 1.3 - Dementia
IncorrectAnswers: Broca's Area;;Lateral Geniculate Nucleus;;Basal Ganglia;;Supramarginal Gyrus

Text:
A 53 year old man presents with a 48 hour history of central chest pain alleviated by leaning forwards. On physical examination a pericardial friction rub is auscultated in the four valve areas. 12-lead ECG shows global ST segment elevation. 

Which of the following is NOT a common cause of pericarditis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Congestive cardiac failure can arise as a complication from existing pericarditis but is not a common cause of pericarditis.
IncorrectAnswers: Chronic renal failure;;Myocardial infarction;;Viral infection;;Systemic lupus erythematosus

Text: Cardiac output can be increased by all of the following, EXCEPT?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: By decreasing ejection fraction, less blood is exiting through the aorta. All others increase the amount of blood going through the aorta.
IncorrectAnswers: Increasing ejection fraction ;;Increasing stroke volume;;Decreasing end systolic volume;;Increasing heart rate

Text: Which of the following is NOT a form of hypoxia in encephalopathy?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: All but carbonic hypoxia are hypoxia's related to encephalopathy
IncorrectAnswers: Histotoxic Hypoxia;;Anaemic Hypoxia;;Ischaemic Hypoxia;;Hypoxaemic Hypoxia

Text: What is a defining feature of the entire period of systole of the heart?
CorrectAnswer: The mitral and tricuspid valves are closed
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Cardiac systole (usually referring to ventricular systole) is defined as the period in which the ventricles contract, causing the intraventricular pressure to increase and thus close the atrioventricular valves (mitral and tricuspid). This allows blood to be ejected into the aorta and pulmonary trunk. Systole ends when the ventricles relax, allowing filling of blood via the atria through the open AV valves.
IncorrectAnswers: Atrial pressure is constantly decreasing;;Aortic pressure exceeds that of ventricular pressure;;Blood has a chance to enter the coronary arteries;;The aortic and pulmonary valves are open

Text: Which of the following structures are pacemaker sites in the heart that CANNOT generate a rhythm to sustain cardiac output?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The SA node has the fastest rhythm (60-100 action potentials per min) followed by the AV node (40-60 action potentials per minute), which is normally overriden by the SA node pacemaker potential. The Purkinjie fibres (which are also normally paced by the SA node, with an underlying rhythm of 20-30 action potentials per minute) are unlike the AV node in that they are insufficient to sustain a rhythm that generates adequate cardiac output. The ductus arteriosus and sarcoplasmic reticulum are not pacemaker cells.
IncorrectAnswers: Sacroplasmic reticulum ;;AV node;;Ductus arteriosum;;SA node

Text: The Frank-Starling law relates ventricular volume and pressure to stroke volume. How does increasing end-diastolic volume result in a higher stroke volume under physiological conditions?
CorrectAnswer: Increasing stretch results in an increased force of contraction due to optimal actin-myosin cross-bridge length being reached
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The architecture of sarcomere units in cardiac muscle largely determines the action of the Frank-Starling mechanism. By stretching the myocardium further, more actin-myosin cross-bndges form, allowing more forceful contractions to eject more volume with each cardiac cycle. This mechanism is exhausted when there is too much stretch of the myocardium.
IncorrectAnswers: Calcium influx into the contractile myocardium is increased which decreases inotropy;;The oxygen delivery is increased with increasing volumes of blood returning to the heart, resulting in a greater capacity for work;;The higher pressure results in increased stretch of cardiomyocytes which stimulates the SNS to increase HR;;The Ca2+ sensitisation of the microfilaments is decreased resulting in a greater effect of Ca2+

Text: Which atypical (second generation) antipsychotic should be avoided in breast feeding due to accumulation in the breast milk?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Clozapine accumulates to high concentrations in breast milk. The other drugs are tolerated, but generally quetiapine is best at the lowest possible dose for maternal efficacy.
IncorrectAnswers: Ziprasidone;;Aripiprazole;;Quetiapine;;Olanzapine

Text: Which of the following is not a direct determinant of EDV (end diastolic volume)?
IncorrectAnswers: Compliance of the ventricles;;Venous return due to skeletal muscle contractions;;A healthy pulmonary circulation providing a respiratory pump;;Filling time (i.e. diastole time)

Text: A new mother presents with pain in her wrist and thumb which is worsened when the thumb is moved. Which of these clinical syndromes do these symptoms relate to?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Chronic overuse of the wrist which strains the abductor pollicus longus and extensor pollicus longus tendons (such as holding a new baby constantly) causes inflammation and pain of these tendons sometimes accompanied by swelling. 

Lateral and medial epicondylitis are inflammation of the common extensor and flexor tendons which attach at the lateral and medial epicondyles of the humerus respectively causing pain in the elbow region. 

Scaphoid fracture would present very similar to tenosynovitis except a history of FOOSH would be more indicative of this pathology. 
Radial nerve palsy would result in paralysis of the wrist extensors and numbness on the dorsal aspect of the hand.
IncorrectAnswers: Lateral epicondylitis;;Radial nerve palsy;;Scaphoid fracture;;Medial epicondylitis

Text: Which of the following best describes the release and action of thyroid hormone?
CorrectAnswer: T4 is the predominant hormone released by the thyroid, although T3 binds the thyroid hormone receptor with much higher affinity
CorrectAnswerExplanation: T4 (thyroid hormone with 4 iodine molecules attached) is released in much greater quantities than T3 from the thyroid gland. However, T3 has a much greater affinity and potency at the thyroid hormone receptor at target cells. T4 is converted to T3 peripherally, largely by the liver.
IncorrectAnswers: T3 is converted to T4 by iodothyronine in cells to activate the hormone and promote metabolism;;Thyroid hormone is secreted in response to a TRH release by the anterior pituitary gland, and causes metabolism and heat generation;;T3 travels around the body bound to TBG while T4 predominantly travels freely unbound;;T3 and T4 are released in approximately equal amounts from the thyroid gland, however most is converted in tissues to T4 as this is the more potent hormone

Text: Which of the following is a primary lymphoid organ?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
It is important to understand the distinction between primary and secondary lymphoid organs. Primary lymphoid organs are where lymphocytes are formed and mature (including the bone marrow and thymus), and secondary lymphoid organs are where immune responses are initiated and the naive lymphocyte population is maintained (including the lymph nodes and spleen).

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/WmDK8pbFr2Y?ecver=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Spleen;;Tonsils;;Lymph node;;Appendix

Text:
A 56-year-old patient with a follicular thyroid carcinoma has a total thyroidectomy. Following the procedure, her blood calcium levels slowly decline until she must be given oral calcium and calcitriol.

Which of the following mechanisms is likely the most responsible for her low blood calcium?
CorrectAnswer: Removal of the parathyroid glands with the thyroid resulted in a reduced parathyroid hormone level and reduced release of blood calcium
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Surgical thyroidectomy involves a risk of damaging or inadvertent removal of one or more of the parathyroid glands. If this occurs, then the bodies calcium levels will drop after the surgery due to reduced circulating PTH (parathyroid hormone) levels.
IncorrectAnswers: Removal of the thyroid gland resulted in a reduction in calcitonin which is normally responsible for maintaining blood calcium levels;;Removal of the thyroid gland resulted in a reduction in thyroid hormone which is important in maintaining blood calcium;;The follicular thyroid carcinoma metastasised to elsewhere in the body and began secreting calcitonin, which upset the body calcium balance;;Removal of the parathyroid gland with the thyroid resulted in a reduction in calcitonin which cause calcium to be reabsorbed into the bone

Text: Which of the following correctly describes the function of Wernicke's area?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Wernicke's area is responsible for the conversion of heard sounds into understood words. Broca's area is responsible for the conversion of thought words into spoken sounds. 

Reference: BB Lecture 1.2 - Cerebral Function Development and Plasticity
IncorrectAnswers: Translation of words into objects;;Translation of words into sounds;;Translation of images into words;;Translation of objects into words

Text: Which of the following is an example of subcortical dementia?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Huntington's disease is the only example of a subcortical dementia out of the options. Alzheimer's disease and Lewy Body dementia are both examples of cortical dementias. Vascular dementia and Chronic traumatic encephalopathy are both examples of mixed variety dementias.

Reference: BB Lecture 1.3 - Dementia
IncorrectAnswers: Vascular dementia;;Chronic traumatic encephalopathy;;Alzheimer's disease;;Lewy Body dementia

Text: Calcitonin is secreted by which of the following endocrine organs or tissues?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The thyroid gland primarily secretes thyroid hormones (T3 and T4), however a secondary hormone called calcitonin is secreted from parafollicular cells in the thyroid. Calcitonin has a role in the regulation of calcium levels in the body, working in opposition to parathyroid hormone.
IncorrectAnswers: Adrenal gland;;Pituitary;;Pancreas;;Parathyroid

Text: Which papillary muscle does the septomarginal trabecula (moderator band) supply?
CorrectAnswer: Anterior papillary muscle of the right ventricle
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The moderator band is a part of the right bundle brunch of the AV bundle (conduction pathway) that extends from the right ventricle septum to the anterior papillary muscle of the right ventricle. It provides a "shortcut" and facilitates conduction time, by allowing the anterior papillary muscle to contract (and aid in tricuspid valve closure) before right ventricular systole begins, preventing tricuspid valve regurgitation.

Reference: Moore's clinical orientated anatomy; end of page 141 and first paragraph of page 142
IncorrectAnswers: Posterior papillary muscle of the right ventricle;;Septal papillary muscle of the right ventricle ;;Anterior papillary muscle of the left ventricle;;Posterior papillary muscle of the left ventricle

Text: Atrial pressure decreases slightly during the isovolumetric contraction/rapid ejection period, before increasing over the rest of systole. This is because:
CorrectAnswer: The atrial base is pulled down as rapid ejection happens which transiently increases the volume of the atrium
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The strong ventricular contraction during systole involves pulling of the atrial base, which leads to a short period of increased atrial chamber volume. When a chamber with a fixed volume of blood expands, pressure will decrease.
IncorrectAnswers: Blood returning to the atria decreases as blood is pumped out of the ventricles;;Depolarisation of the Bundle of His causes a thinning in the atrioventricular septum;;The pressure is given as a relative value to ventricular pressure which is markedly higher, thus giving the illusion that atrial pressure decreases;;Ventricular contraction creates a negative pressure that pulls further blood from the atria

Text:
A 60-year old man has presented to ED with central crushing chest pain radiating to his left shoulder and jaw. You suspect a STEMI, however his ECG is inconclusive. His troponins have come back negative.
 
To rule out an Acute Coronary Syndrome in this man, what does the TIMI score need to be?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: TIMI score is used to determine diagnostic probability of a STEMI. The criteria are as follows: - Age >65 - >2 risk factors for IHD - Stenosis - >2 episodes of angina in 24h - Aspirin use If the TIMI score is >2, and there are changes to the ECG and there is a troponin rise, the patient is deemed to be at high risk for ACS. If TIMI<3 and there are no changes to ECG and no troponin rise, the patient is deemed to be at low risk of ACS. Reference: TIMI Risk Score Calculator
IncorrectAnswers: TIMI <2;;TIMI 0;;TIMI >3;;TIMI 5

Text:
Tyson, a 4-year old boy, is brought into the GP by his mother. She explains that he seems to be very unwell and his voice has changed in the past 24 hours. She describes it as a 'hot potato' voice. He has trouble swallowing his food and seems to have a lot of salivation. His neck appears swollena and he tells you his ear hurts. He is up to date with all immunisations.

What is your most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: A hot potato voice, troubles swallowing, referred ear pain and a swollen neck are all characteristic of Quinsy. He needs to be started on Benzylpenicillin and referred to ENT for possible surgical treatment. EBV would cause fever, a protracted illnes, cervical lyphadenopathy, and variable hepato-splenomegaly. No antibiotics ar required,however analgesia and rehydration is important. It is a self-resolving illness. A retropharyngeal abscess is an important differential - this causes a muffled voice, respiratory distress/stridor if severe, painful swallowing and torticollis. They may also have a neck mass and trismus. A lateral neck xray is needed and a CT with IV contrast is the gold standard. The antibiotic of choice is Timentin, and an ENT referral for surgucal drainage is required. Reference: RCH - Sore Throat
IncorrectAnswers: Epiglottitis ;;Retropharyngeal abscess;;Infectious Mononucleosis ;;Strep throat

Text:
A 6-year old girl has short stature. She had a birth weight of 2kg at term and had a coarctation of the aorta repair in infancy. She has bilateral ptosis, a low posterior hairline, and multiple pigmented naevi. She is on the 0.4th centile for height and the 2nd centile for weight. Her mid-parental height is the 50th centile.

What single investigation is most likely to lead to a diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Turner s Syndrome
- What is it? = XO karyotype (only one X chromosome)
- Clinical Features:
      Female gender
      Short stature
      Low posterior hairline
      Low set ears
      Widely spaced nipples ( shield-like chest )
      Webbed neck
      High-arched palate
- Diagnosis = Chromosome analysis (karyotyping) 
- Always consider this in girls with short stature. 
- Girls with Turner's Syndrome are at increased risk of:
     Coarctation of the aorta = need to check femoral pulses
     Bicuspic aortic valve
     Horseshoe kidney
     Visual impairments
IncorrectAnswers: MRI scan of the brain;;Chest X-ray;;Coeliac Screen;;Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH) and Leutinising Hormone (LH)

Text:
Edith is a 78-year old woman with known Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus who presents with a 1-week history of polydipsia, feeling generally unwell and drowsy. On examination, she looks very dehydrated and is difficult to rouse. She appears confused when she does talk to you.

Admission bloods show:

Na 149 mmol/L (135-145)
K 5.2 mmol/L (3.5-5) 
Urea 22.1 mmol/L (2-7) 
Creatinine 254 micromole/L (55-120)
Blood Glucose Level (BGL) 36 mmol/L (3.9   5.5) 

What is the most important first management step?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This patient has hyperosmolar hyperglycaemic state (HHS). HHS is characterised by:
1.) Severe hyperglycaemia
2.) Dehydration and renal failure
3.) Mild/absent ketonuria

Complications include: rhabdomyolysis, venous thromboembolism, lactic acidosis, renal failure, stroke, cerebral oedema. 

Always look for causes:
- New T2DM diagnosis/poor treatment compliance
- Infection
- High dose steroids
- MI
- Vomiting
- Stroke/VTE

Management of HHS: 
- Supportive care (patients with HHS often have a deficit of over 8 litres). 
- Caution to avoid rapid fluid replacement - rapid osmolar shifts can cause cerebral oedema.

FIRST PRIORITY = fluid resus! 
- Conflicting arguments as to when you should start insulin   often wait 1-2 hours to avoid rapid metabolic changes (prevent central pontine myelinosis). 
- Fluid alone will lower BSL
IncorrectAnswers: Start insulin sliding scale;;Give calcium gluconate due to hyperkalaemia ;;Give 10 units of Actrapid (short-acting insulin) immediately;;Replace potassium

Text: In which of the following scenarios is it indicated to commence vasopressors and/or inotropes?
CorrectAnswer: When systolic BP falls by 30mmHg, or when the MAP is <60
CorrectAnswerExplanation: See Cloud Deakin Module
IncorrectAnswers: When systolic BP is <30mmHg, or when the MAP is <60;;When the diastolic BP falls by 50mmHg, and the MAP falls by 20;;When systolic BP falls by 10mmHg, or when the MAP is <40;;When systolic BP is <60mmHg, or when the MAP is <60

Text:
Rosa, a 30-year old female, presents to her GP with acute abdominal pain. She tells of a 2-week history of feeling lethargic with occasional nausea. She has also lost her appetite, and has noticed she has lost a few kilos over the past 3 weeks. On examination, you note the following when inspecting her mouth: 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Addison s disease ( Primary Adrenal Insufficiency ) 

- Adrenal gland doesn t produce enough cortisol/aldosterone
- Fatigue, anorexia, N&V, muscle weakness, diarrhoea, abdominal pain àð non-specific 
- Hypoglycaemia
- Hyperpigmentation

Blood results
!K, !Na, !glucose, metabolic acidosis

Dagnostic: ACTH stimulation test (Short Synacthen test) 

Management
- Hydrocortisone +- fludrocortisone 
- Consider a MedicAlert bracelet
- When sick, doses need to be doubled.
IncorrectAnswers:
Conn s Syndrome 
;;Measles
;;Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome 
;;Crohn s Disease

Text:
A 50-year old man, Alex, is brought to the GP by his carer. Alex is currently on Clozapine, and his carer reports that he is more tired than usual and feels generally unwell. He has a temperature, and seems to have put on weight over the last month.

What is the most important test to perform?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Clozapine is a last-line for schizophrenia, and has the important risks of neutropaenia and agranulocytosis. In someone who presents unwell whilst on Clozapine, you must check the FBE for low WCC and/or neutrophils, as they can be severely immunocompromised, and what may seem like a common cold can soon become a dangerous illness.
IncorrectAnswers: UEC;;ECG;;Urinalysis;;Troponins

Text:
A 5-year old boy is brought in to the GP with a 3-day history of a painful right knee. The child has also had abdominal pain and vomiting over the past week, which his mother attributes to  gastro.  
On examination you note a palpable non-blanching rash on his buttocks and thighs. You perform a urine dipstick which shows erythrocytes + and protein ++. 
What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Henoch-Schonlein Purpura (HSP)
- IgA-mediated small vessel vasculitis (some overlap with IgA nephropathy).
- Usually seen in kids following a viral infection. 
- Features:
       Palpable purpuric rash -  buttocks & extensor surfaces of arms and legs.
       Abdo pain
       Polyarthritis
       Features of IgA nephropathy - haematuria, renal failure. 
- Investigations:
       Urinalysis - macroscopic haematuria, proteinuria
       Bloods - UEC, albumin
- Treatment:
       Analgesia for arthralgia
       Supportive measures for nephropathy 
- Prognosis:
       Excellent - self-limiting condition (especially if no renal involvement) 


Haemolytic Uraemic Syndrome (HUS)
- Triad: ARF, macroangiopathic haemolytic anaemia, thrombocytopaenia
- Causes:
      Post-dysentry (E.coli 0157:H7)
      SLE
- Investigations:
     FBE - anaemia, thrombocytopaenia
     Blood film - fragmented 
     UEC - ARF
     Stool culture
IncorrectAnswers: Reactive Arthritis ;;Rheumatic Fever;;Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE);;Haemolytic Uraemic Syndrome

Text:
Stephanie has just undergone an emergency procedure under the ENT surgeons. All has gone well, and she is for recovery on the ward. The anaesthetic gases and ventilator has been turned off. Stephanie's HR and BP begin to rise, and she begins to sweat profusely. The anaesthetist also notes that her pupils are markedly dilated.

What is the likely cause of this presentation?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Sux is a non-competitive, depolarising muscle relaxant, and is typically used in emergency cases and RSIs due to its fast onset. It is non-reversible, and is degrades in the blood by pseudocholinesterase. A deficiency of pseudocholinesterase causes a slow degradation of Sux, and therefore the effects last longer. 
Sux apnoea is rare, and can be inherited or acquired. Acquired sux apnoea can occur in pregnancy, hypothyroidism, liver and kidney disease, and many more (see reference). 
It is managed by re-anaesthetising the patient and ventilating them. A nerve stimulator can be used to look for the return of twitch (train of 4) with no fade. If a stimulator is not available, then the patient should be kept ventilated until they are completely awake and able to follow commands. 

http://www.e-safe-anaesthesia.org/e_library/13/Suxamethonium_apnoea_Update_2003.pdf
IncorrectAnswers: Occlusion of the airway as a result of unsuccessful ENT surgery ;;Malignant hyperthermia (MH);;Laryngospasm ;;Allergic reaction to the anaesthetic

Text:
A woman with BMI 31 and waist circumference 99cm has been seeing her GP about weight loss strategies. She has altered her diet, stopped smoking, and walking every day for 40 minutes. She is still unhappy with her progress.Her GP suggests a VLED (Very Low Energy Diet). 

Which of the following statements about VLEDs is correct?
CorrectAnswer: Meals are replicated with a specific meal replacement formula of no more than 800kcal/day
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
They are meal replacement formulas of <800 kcal/day or <3350 kJ/day - replacing all meals. It involves fat burning and mild ketosis which suppresses hunger and promotes satiety.

"They can be prescribed as long-term management of obesity, provided it is producing weight loss results" - Incorrect - they are prescribed for 8-12 weeks only.

"They are helpful for weight loss, but not for glycaemic control" - Incorrect - they are useful for glycaemic control, BP control and cholesterol reduction (as well as weight loss).

"They are safe in pregnant and lactating women" - Incorrect - they are contraindicated in pregnant and lactating women, infants, children <18, elderly >65, and those with unstable angina or a recent MI. 

"They can be offered to those with BMI >26.1" - Incorrect - they can be prescribed to those with BMI >30, or BMI>27 with obesity-related comorbidities
IncorrectAnswers: They can be offered to those with BMI >26.1;;They can be prescribed as long-term management of obesity, provided it is producing weight loss results;;They are safe in pregnant and lactating women;;They are helpful for weight loss, but not for glycaemic control

Text: Select the correct statement regarding management of dementia:
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswer: Lewy Body Dementia responds well to acetylcholinesterase inhibitors.
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Lewy Body Dementia has evidence to show improvement in cognition when acetylcholinesterase inhibitors are used.

FTD does not respond to AChE inhibitors and they are not typically used for management of symptoms. There is no evidence than FTD responds well to Haloperidol. Haloperidol makes the visual hallucinations of LBD worse, and may precipitate Parkinsonism. Drugs such as Oxybutinin are not used in LBD as they can worsen cognition (AChE inhibitors are GOOD, so anticholinergics are BAD).
IncorrectAnswers: Lewy Body Dementia responds well to Haloperidol ;;Frontotemporal Dementia responds well to acetylcholinesterase inhibitors.;;Frontotemporal Dementia responds well to Haloperidol ;;Anticholinergic medications, such as Oxybutinin, improves cognition in those with Lewy Body Dementia.

Text:
A 26-year old woman presents to her GP complaining of 2 weeks of loss of appetite, loss of weight, and generalised joint pain. 
On examination, the GP notes oral ulcers and the following facial appearance.

What is the single most appropriate test to order to confirm the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Rheumatoid factor = positive in many! 
ANA = Sensitive for SLE, but not specific (also + in Sjogren s, Scleroderma)
Anti-dsDNA = SPECIFIC for SLE
Anti-Ro and Anti-La = Sjogren s Syndrome 
Anti-centromere Antibodies = CREST Syndrome (Scleroderma)

SLE
- Multisystem autoimmune disorder
- Higher risk = African American women of child-bearing age.
- Presentation:
       Non-specific   LOA, LOW, fever, anorexia, symmetric joint pain
       + 4 of DOPAMINE RASH
- Ix:
       Sensitive   ANA
       Specific   Anti-dsDNA, Anti-SmDNA
- Mx:
       Mild joint pain   NSAIDs
       Acute exacerbations   corticosteroids 
       Can use hydrochloroquine, cyclophosphamide, azathioprine 
       Bisphosphonates + VitD + Calcium to reduce osteoporosis if using DMARDs
IncorrectAnswers: Rheumatoid factor;;Anti-centromere antibodies ;;Anti-Ro;;ANA

Text:
A 6-year old boy finds it difficult to take turns and to focus on tasks at school. He is easily distracted and his father says he has no sense of danger, often running across the main road without any care. He has difficulty following a series of simple instructions and is one year behind his peers in numeracy and literacy skills. 

What is the single most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
ADHD
- Part of a spectrum of hyperactive disorder
- Characterised by: 
     Inattention and distractability 
     Hyperactivity 
     Impulsivity 
- Intrinsic to person at all times, withiin all environments 
- More common in children with learning difficulties 

AUTISM
- Also part of a spectrum
- Characterised by impaired social interaction, impaired imagination, repetition and restricted interests.

ASPERGER'S SYNDROME
- Now called ' high functioning autism'
- Often diagnosed later in primary school when social difficulties become evident.

OPPOSITIONAL DEFIANT DISORDER
- Pattern of defiant, disobedient and hostile behaviour.
IncorrectAnswers: Oppositional Defiant Disorder ;;Asperger's Syndrome ;;Global Developmental Delay;;Autism

Text:
A 21-year old man presents to ED complaining of a painful left eye. He has noticed this get gradually worse over the past 3 days. He reports no history of trauma or foreign body, and he does not wear contact lenses. He is otherwise well despite occasional back pain he notices when he first wakes up. 

On examination you notice that the left eye is red and injected, and the pupil appears slightly constricted compared to the right, and is slow to respond to light. There is no exudate present.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: This is a classical description of anterior uveitis/iritis. It is commonly associated with autoimmune disorder, such as ankylosing spondylosis (HLA-B27), which was hinted at here with the early morning back pain. Other common associations are Crohn's disease and Ulcerative colitis. They need to be referred to an ophthalmologist. Acute angle-closure glaucoma is highly unlikely in this age group, and would present with severe pain and sudden loss of vision. Keratitis would be more likely if he wore contact leneses of described 'grittiness.' Bacterial conjunctivitis and gonorrhoea would both produce a purulent discharge, which was absent here. Reference: Wikipedia - Uveitis
IncorrectAnswers: Gonorrhoea ;;Acute angle-closure glaucoma ;;Bacterial Conjunctivitis;;Keratitis

Text:
A 60-year old man with known lung carcinoma presents to ED with chest pain. His ECG shows electrical alternans.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Malignant diseases are the most common cause of pericardial tamponade. It is often associated with malignant infiltration associated with a large effusion. Reference: LITFL - Electrical Alternans
IncorrectAnswers:
Rapid AF;;Pneumothorax;;Pleural effusion
;;Constrictive pericarditis

Text:
The Cushing's reflex is the combination bradycardia and hypertension as a result of raised intra-cranial pressure.

Which type of herniation is the most likely cause of the Cushing's reflex?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Downward cerebellar herniation causes pressure on the brainstem, leading to autonomic problems, causing the Cushing's reflex. References: Wikipedia - Brain Herniation and Lecture on Cloud Deakin - Coma
IncorrectAnswers: Uncal herniation;;Cingulate herniation;;Transcalvarial herniation ;;Transtentorial herniation

Text:
A 21-year old man presents to his GP complaining of back pain. He has been struggling with intense tiredness over the past week, and as a result he has been fired from his job as a bartender. He complains that this pain is worse in the morning, and after watching TV for a long time. 
On examination, he has reduced flexion of the lumbar spine, and you note a loss of lumbar lordosis.

Given the most likely diagnosis, which of the following will most likely be positive?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Seronegative Spondylarthropathies 

**Ankylosing Spondylitis 
     Young males +/- FHx
     Intermittent hip pain & LBP àð worsens with inactivity and first thing in morning. 
     Reduced lumbar lordosis, reduced flexion, reduced chest expansion.
     Bloods = HLA-B27, !CRP, !ESR
     Mx = NSAIDs, physio/swimming, TNF inhibitors or Sulfasalazine (refractory)
     Buzzwords = bamboo spine, syndesmophytes, squaring of lumbar vertebrae 

**Psoriatic Arthritis
     Asymmetrical, associated with dactylitis
     Xray = pencil-in-cup deformity 

**Reactive Arthritis (Reiter's)
     'Can't see, can't pee, can't climb up a tree' = conjunctivitis, urethritis, arthritis = classic triad!
     Young men, usually following a GIT infection (campylobacter, shigella, salmonella)
     Joint effusion aspirate = often a negative culture
     Buzzwords = sacroileitis, keratoderma blenorrhagica, plantar fasciitis 

**Enteropathic Arthritis
     Asymmetric sacroileitis associated with IBD
IncorrectAnswers: ANA;;Anti-dsDNA;;Anti-CCP;;Rheumatoid factor

Text:
Ben has been started on a medication to manage his schizophrenia, which has been having a marked impact on his life. He presents to his GP with excessive drooling, complaining that he is even having to change is pyjama shirt during the night due to it becoming so wet. He has also noticed a rapid weight gain despite no changes to his diet or exercise habits.

What is the most likely drug that Ben has been started on?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Clozapine is for treatment-resistant schiophrenia. Its side effect profile can be broken down as follows:
- Metabolic: weight gain, hyperllipidaemia, hypercholesterolaemia, diabetes, metabolic syndrome, excess drooling (muscariinic [M4] effect)
- Haematologic: agranulocytosis, neuropaenia, 
- Cardiac: myocarditis (short-term), cardiomyopathy (longer term)
IncorrectAnswers: Flupenthixol;;Olanzapine ;;Droperidol;;Quetiapine

Text:
Brad, a 20-year old surfer, comes to see his GP as he is concerned about a mole he has noticed on his chest. He is worried it might be a melanoma. 
In terms of melanomas, what is the single most important prognostic factor?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Measures in millimetres the ditance between the upper layer of the epidermis and the deepest point of tumour penetration. Thin = <1mm Moderate = 1-4mm Thick = >4mm Clark level describes the level of anatomical invasion of the melanoma in the skin (1-5). Reference
IncorrectAnswers: Bleeding ;;Clark level;;Number of different colours within the single lesion;;Irregular shape

Text:
A 56-year old man presents with an 8-month history of generalised weakness. On examination he has fasciculations and weakness in both arms with absent reflexes. Examination of the lower limbs demonstrates increased tone and exaggerated reflexes. Sensation was normal throughout both upper and lower limbs, and there were no cerebellar signs. 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Topics: Transition to Clinical Practice(Year 2);;General Medicine(Year 3);;Brain and Behaviour(Year 2)
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Motor Neuron Disease (MND) - Unknown aetiology  both upper AND lower motor neuron signs. - Other clues: Fasciculation Absence of sensory signs & symptoms Mixture of UMN and LMN signs & symptoms Wasting of the small hand muscles/tibialis anterior - Other features: Doesn t affect external ocular muscles No cerebellar signs - Clinical diagnosis  BUT nerve conduction studies show normal motor conduction and will help exclude a neuropathy. Multiple Sclerosis (MS) - Usually non-specific presentation (lethargy is common) - Sensory: pins & needles, trigeminal neuralgia, Lhermitte's syndrome. - Motor: spastic weakness (usually legs) - Visual: OPTIC NEURITIS, Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO), Uthoff's phenomenon. - Other: urinary incontinence, sexual dysfunction. Vitamin B Deficiency - Causes subacute combined degeneration of the cord (degeneration of posterior & lateral columns). - Weakness of legs, arms, trunk, and numbness/tingling. - May develop bilateral spastic paresis. - Diagnosed with Schilling Test. Parkinson's Disease - Progressive degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in substantia nigra. - Classic triad: bradykinesia, tremor, rigidity. - Often first present with anosmia and poor sleep. - Classically asymmetrical symptoms. - Buzzwords: cogwheel rigidity, mask-like facies, small steps, micrographia, flexed posture. - Depression is very common. Syringomyelia: - Development of a fluid-filled cavity (syrinx) within spinal cord. - Slowly progressive symptoms. - Motor: wasting & weakness of arms. - Sensory: spinothalamic sensory loss (pain & temperature) - Other: loss of reflexes, bilateral upgoing plantars. >
IncorrectAnswers:
Parkinson s Disease
;;Syringomyelia 
;;Multiple Sclerosis
;;Vitamin B12 deficiency

Text:
A 64-year old woman who is known to have rheumatoid arthritis presents with pain in her ring finger when she flexes it. On one occasion she reports it became  stuck.  Clinical examination is unremarkable other than a palpable nodule and the base of the finger.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Trigger finger
- Disparity between size of tendon & pulleys through which they pass.
- Idiopathic
- Stiffness, snapping when extending +/- nodule at base of finger
- Mx = steroid injection +/- finger splint

Mallet finger:
- 'baseball finger' - unable to straighten DIP actively (but can be passively straightened) 
- Extensor tendon rupture (avulsion injury)
- Mx = non-surgical splinting 

Swan neck deformity
- Hyperextension of PIP + hyperflexion of DIP
- Associated with RA

Boutonniere's deformity
- Hyperflexion of PIP + hyperextention of DIP
- Associated with RA
- Mx = splint (PIP extended for 4-6 weeks)

Dupuytren's contracture
- Thickening and shortening of palmar fascia
- Unknown cause
- Mx = corticosteroid injections, surgical release
IncorrectAnswers: Mallet finger;;Bouttonniere deformity;;Dupuytren's contracture;;Swan neck deformity

Text:
A 3-year old boy presents for his second visit to see you, his GP. Two days ago he was seen with a 4-day history of intermittent fevers, spiking at 40 degrees, and irritability. His examination at that time was remarkable for bilateral conjunctivitis and dry, cracked lips. He was sent home with instructions for symptomatic care.

Today he returns with persistent fevers and irritability. Examination findings noted previously are still present, but now he is noted to have a maculopapular truncal rash and a large right anterior cervical lymph node.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Kawasaki s Disease = MyHEART
- Mucosal involvement   strawberry tongue, dry red lips
- Hands & Feet   oedema and desquamation 
- Eyes   non-purulent bilateral conjunctivitis 
- Adenopathy   unilateral cervical 
- Rash   trunk, pleomorphic 
- Temperature   persistent >7/7 

- Risk of coronary artery aneurysms - needs echo
- Admission for IVIG and Aspirin
IncorrectAnswers: Scarlett fever;;Stevens-Johnson Syndrome;;Systemic Juvenile Idiopathic arthritis;;Acute rheumatic fever

Text:
