Withdrawal from opiates (such as heroin) involves symptoms and signs that generally are the opposite of what the opiate causes. For example, opiate ingestion leads to pupillary constriction, so withdrawal involves pupillary dilation.

Opiate intake results in a pleasant, drowsy euphoria. Withdrawal therefore would lead to significant agitation in mind and movement, therefore making psychomotor retardation unlikely. 

Guidelines for the management of heroin withdrawal (http://www.health.gov.au/internet/drugstrategy/publishing.nsf/Content/9011C92D2F6E1FC5CA2575B4001353B6/$File/bupren4.pdf)
IncorrectAnswers: Nausea and vomiting;;Pupillary dilation;;Raised blood pressure;;Increased sweating and lacrimation

Text:
Jeff is a 76-year-old male who presents with increasing confusion, loss of concentration and agitation. He is currently under the palliative care team for management of stage 4 squamous cell lung carcinoma, with confirmed metastases to bone. He has a past history of ischemic heart disease and benign prostate hypertrophy.

Which of the following would NOT be appropriate initial investigations to diagnose the cause of delirium in Jeff?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswer: CT Brain looking for new metastases
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The initial workup of delirium in this patient should exclude the commonest causes of delirium, such as infection and electrolyte impairment (especially calcium given bone metastases), before seeking further complex investigations and imaging such as CT scanning.

BMJ Best Practice - Assessment of Delirium
IncorrectAnswers: Urea and electrolytes (including calcium) looking for electrolyte disturbances;;Chest X-Ray looking for lower respiratory tract infection;;Urinalysis looking for urinary tract infection;;ECG looking for arrhythmia and ischemic changes

Text: Which of the following muscle relaxants is a non-competitive, depolarising agent?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Suxamethonium is a depolarising agent that causes prolonged depolarisation of the muscle membrane so that nerve impulses and acetylcholine release are unable to initiate muscle contraction. All the other agents listed are non-depolarising agents, which exhibit competitive antagonism of acetylcholine at nicotinic receptors at the neuro-muscular junction (NMJ). Reference: Anaesthetic Module 6 Drugs in Anaesthesia (Cloud Deakin - Year 4 AIC), Wikipedia - Suxamethonium.
IncorrectAnswers: Atracurium;;Mivacurium;;Vecuronium;;Rocuronium

Text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic symptom of conjunctivitis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Photophobia is suggestive of a more serious infection such as meningitis, especially if accompanied by headache and nausea. Conjunctivitis often presents with a red, itchy eye with either a purulent discharge (bacterial cause) or watery discharge (viral cause).
IncorrectAnswers: Red conjunctiva;;Itchy eye;;Purulent exudate;;Watery discharge

Text: Which of the following is incorrect?
CorrectAnswer: Active transport goes along its concentration gradient
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Active transport requires the use of ATP, and works to pump molecules against their concentration gradient. These transporters are vitally important in maintaining homeostasis in the body. 

Simple diffusion allows passive diffusion along the concentration gradient. Channel mediated transport and carrier mediated transport are also both passive, and do not require energy to work.
IncorrectAnswers: Carrier mediated transport along its concentration gradient does not require energy;;Channel-mediated transport does not require energy;;Simple diffusion goes along its concentration gradient;;Simple diffusion does not require energy

Text: The product of transcription from DNA is?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Transcription is the process of copying information from the DNA into messenger RNA (mRNA) which conveys this to the ribosomes to undergo translation and production of proteins. Reference: Khan Academy
IncorrectAnswers: rRNA;;Codons;;DNA;;tRNA

Text: Which of the following does not pre-dispose a person to Deep Vein Thrombosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Aspirin is a anti-platelet agent which would reduce the likelihood of clot formation, hence would not predispose you to a DVT. All the other listed answers increase clotting risk. 

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/mMEdNCdUeAE" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Oral Contraceptive Pill;;Smoking;;Family history of DVT;;Prolonged post-operative bed-rest

Text: How many pairs of autosomal chromosomes does a normal human genome contain?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: A normal human genome contains 46 chromosomes made up of 44 autosomal chromosomes in 22 pairs, and 2 sex chromosomes (XY for males and XX for females).

Text: Which of the following is INCORRECT about the clinical progression of tuberculosis?
CorrectAnswer: A positive tuberculin (Mantoux) test result 2-4 weeks after exposure is indicative of TB infection
CorrectAnswerExplanation: A positive tuberculin test result signifies cell-mediated hypersensitivity to tubercular antigens, it does not differentiate between previous exposure to infection and active disease.
IncorrectAnswers: Spread is via person-to-person airborne droplets;;Secondary pulmonary TB is classically localised to the apex of the upper lobes of one or both lungs;;Primary tuberculosis is usually asymptomatic;;Primary tuberculosis develops in a previously unexposed, therefore unsensitised person

Text: Down syndrome is caused by which of the following genetic abnormalities?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Down syndrome is due to trisomy 21, that is 3 copies of the chromosome 21. This extra genetic information causes birth defects, intellectual disability, characteristic facial features, heart defects, amongst other issues. The genetic abnormality arises during meiosis when either the sperm or egg that is produced doesn't divide properly, and retains and extra chromosome 21. This results in 3 chromosomes being present in the zygote, instead of the usual pair. Reference: Down syndrome
IncorrectAnswers: Monosomy 21;; Trisomy 18;;XXX;;Trisomy 13

Text: What is the most common tachyarrhythmia in childhood?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) is the commonest. This condition can cause symptoms such as weakness, fatigue, dizziness, fainting, or palpitations if the heart rate becomes too fast. This isn't a life-threatening problem for most children and adolescents and treatment is only considered if episodes are prolonged or frequent. References: Heart Foundation and Stanford Childrens
IncorrectAnswers: Ventricular tachycardia;;Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome;;Atrial fibrillation ;;Atrial flutter

Text:
John is a 74-year-old male who sustained a massive sub-arachnoid haemorrhage 5 days ago, and is now in ICU on a ventilator. The ICU team believe John has no capacity to regain CNS function, and decide to carry out formal testing for brain and brainstem death.

Which of the following criteria are NOT required to proceed with assessment of brain death?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: There are a number of criteria that must be satisfied before tests of brain and brain stem can be carried out to certify brain death. These are: 1. Cause for coma consistent with brain death 2. At least 4 hours of observation during which preconditions must be met (GCS 3, pupil non-reactive, no cough, apnoea) 3. Neuro-imaging consistent with acute brain pathology that could cause brain death 4. Normothermia (T>35C) 5. Normotension (SBP>90 or MAP>60mmHg in an adult) 6. No sedation or analgesia (dependent on types of drugs used, renal and hepatic function; use antagonists if concerned) 7. Absence of severe electrolyte, metabolic and endocrine disturbances (glucose, Na+, PO43-, Mg2+, renal and hepatic function) 8. No paralysis (use NMJ monitor or electromyography if concerned) 9. Ability to assess brain stem reflexes (at least one eye and ear) 10. Ability to perform apnoea test (doesn t have severe hypoxic respiratory failure or have a high cervical spine injury) The patient does not have to be in sinus rhythm for brain death assessment to be carried out. References: ANZICS Statement on Death and Organ Donation and Life in the Fast Lane.
IncorrectAnswers: Absence of severe electrolyte, metabolic and endocrine disturbances;;Normotension (SBP>90 or MAP>60mmHg in an adult);;No sedation or analgesia currently in the person's system;;Normothermia (temperature greater than 35.0)

Text:
Dave is suffering from metastatic bowel cancer, and has recently been found to have a malignant bowel obstruction. In addition to anti-emetics and analgesia, his doctors want to give him something to reduce GI secretions. 

What is the most suitable agent to prescribe?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Hyoscine and octreotide are the 2 to pick between here   hyoscine is an anti-secretory agent and also helps with colicky pain, whereas octreotide is helpful for reducing upper GI secretions. According to guidelines, Octerotide is first-line for a complete bowel obstruction.
IncorrectAnswers: Glycopyrrolate ;;Hyoscine;;Lactulose;;Metoclopramide

Text: What is the most useful pain medication for musculoskeletal pain in the terminal phase?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
NSAIDs are the most useful for musculoskeletal pain in the terminal phase   ketorolac being the best as it is the only NSAID that can be given SC. 
Methadone is effective for neuropathic pain (such as spinal cord or nerve root compression), as is lignocaine and ketamine.
IncorrectAnswers: Morphine;;Oxycodone;;Fentanyl;;Methadone

Text: Which of the following describes a process whereby a joint is secured in place to allow no further movement, and is only done when all other options have been exhausted?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Arthrodesis is the process of fusion of a joint, restricting it from any further movement. This is usually a last resort after other medical and surgical management has failed, and is typically indicated in patients with severe arthritis, instability or deformity. It should be avoided in younger patients where possible as their continued growth may cause additional abnormalities. 

Arthrotomy is the surgical opening or exploration of a joint. Osteotomy is the surgical cutting of a bone to help realignment. Arthroscopy is a minimally invasive surgical exploration of a joint using a arthroscope (camera). Arthroplasty is the surgical reconstruction or replacement of a joint.
IncorrectAnswers: Arthroscopy;;Arthroplasty;;Arthrotomy;;Osteotomy

Text: Which of the following is NOT a risk factor for ischaemic heart disease?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The OCP does not increase the risk of IHD, rather it can slightly increase the risk of venous thrombotic disease (i.e. DVT and stroke). All the other answers listed do indeed increase the risk of IHD.
IncorrectAnswers: Hypertension ;;Male and post menopausal women;;Smoking;;Family history of cardiac disease

Text: Which of the following patients would NOT be a candidate for non-invasive ventilation?
CorrectAnswer: A 24-year-old male with hypoxia due to trauma-related pneumothorax
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Non-invasive ventilation cannot be used in patients with untreated pneumothorax, as the positive pressure ventilation may worsen the severity of pneumothorax and lead to haemodynamic instability.

COPD, pulmonary oedema, cystic fibrosis and OSA are all indications for the use of non-invasive ventilation.
IncorrectAnswers: A 64-year-old male with an infective exacerbation of COPD;;A 58-year-old female with symptomatic obstructive sleep apnoea ;;A 78-year-old female with hypoxia secondary to cardiogenic pulmonary oedema;;A 42-year-old male with end-stage cystic fibrosis, awaiting lung transplant

Text: Which of the following is NOT a risk factor for post operative nausea and vomiting (PONV)?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Being a non-smoker is in fact a major risk factor for post operative nausea and vomiting (PONV). All the other options are validated risk factors for PONV, as well as younger age and duration of anaesthetic. Reference: Guidelines for Mx of PONV and PONV Prophylaxis Guidelines
IncorrectAnswers: Postoperative opioids ;;Female;;History of PONV/motion sickness;;Use of volatile anaesthetic agents

Text: A 26-year old man presents to his GP complaining of 6 months of lower back pain and stiffness, which is worse in the morning. After a lumbar spina xray the doctor believes this to be Ankylosing Spondylitis. What serum marker is generally associated with this disease?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Ankylosing spondylitis is a sero-negative arthropathy, meaning it is negative for rheumatoid factor, hence B is incorrect. HLA-B27 is typically positive in those with Ank Spond, however is of little use in diagnosis because it is positive in around 10% of normal people. 

ANA is positive in several rheumatoilogical diseases: SLE, Sjogren's syndrome, scleroderma. Hence, it is sensitive but not specific. 

Similarly, Rheumatoid factor is sensitive for many rheumatological diseases (notably RA), but not specific. Furthermore, ankylosing spondylitis is one of the 'seronegative' diseases, which means it is rheumatoid factor negative.

Anti-centromere antibodies = scleroderma (CREST syndrome/limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis).

Anti-dsDNA antibodies = Specific for SLE.
IncorrectAnswers: Anti-centromere antibodies;;Rheumatoid factor;;ANA;;Anti-dsDNA antibodies

Text: Which statement concerning the principles of the use of antibiotics is false?
CorrectAnswer: Use of the original antibiotic should be continued until script has been completed, with a more specific antibiotic started once completed
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Antibiotics are often started as broad spectrums and once the microbe is identified it is immediately narrowed down to prevent resistance. Its also better for your flora. Flora are friends, not food.
IncorrectAnswers: Use a dose that is high enough to ensure efficacy and minimise the risk of resistance selection and low enough to minimise the risk of dose related toxicity;;Use single drugs unless proven that combination therapy is required to ensure efficacy or reduce the selection of clinically significant resistance;;Use where it will benefits are scientifically demonstrable;;Use narrowest spectrum antibiotics to treat the known or likely pathogens

Text: From medial to lateral, what are the contents of the femoral triangle?
CorrectAnswer: Femoral vein; Femoral artery; Femoral nerve
CorrectAnswerExplanation: From medial to lateral, the order is femoral vein, femoral artery, femoral nerve. The mnemonic usually remembered by medical students is NAVY (nerve, artery, vein, Y of the midline legs) which is from lateral to medial, so one must be sure to read the stem carefully and understand which direction the question is asking for. Another mnemonic to remember the structures in order from medial to lateral is VAN (vein, artery, nerve) which is simply a reverse of the other mnemonic. References: Radiopaedia and Teach Me Anatomy
IncorrectAnswers: Femoral vein; Femoral nerve; Femoral artery;;Femoral artery; Femoral nerve; Femoral vein;;Femoral artery; Femoral vein; Femoral nerve;;Femoral nerve; Femoral artery; Femoral vein

Text: Widespread oedema, vascular shock, difficulty breathing and loss of consciousness are characteristic of which like-threatening condition? What is the immediate treatment required?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This is a classic description of an anaphylaxis episode. This is treated primarily with IM adrenaline, usually to the outer thigh (0.5mg every 5 minutes until improvement). 

Due to the multi organ involvement, this is a clearly a systemic condition. Whilst adrenaline is the drug needed, IV adrenaline is inappropriate to use in this situation.
IncorrectAnswers: Local anaphylaxis; IV adrenaline;;Type I hypersensitivity; antihistamine;;Severe allergic reaction; IV adrenaline;;Arthus reaction; corticosteroids

Text: Paul has just had his second round of chemotherapy for metastatic melanoma. He is recovering at home but feels extremely nauseous and has vomited twice in the past hour. His wife calls you, his doctor, to ask for a script for an anti-emetic. What should you prescribe?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Ondansetron is the most effective drug for nausea associated with radio and chemotherapy. It is also used commonly post-surgically, as it is less sedating than Cyclizine and Droperidol.
IncorrectAnswers: Metoclopramide;;Cyclizine;;Droperidol;;Nothing   this is normal and will pass soon

Text:
Mary is a 75 year old female who recently suffered a low trauma vertebral fracture. Upon further investigation, it was discovered that her bone mineral density T score was -3.1. 

Which of the following drugs used in the management of osteoporosis acts as a RANKL inhibitor?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Denosumab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically targets RANKL. Through inhibition of RANKL, denosumab prevents osteoclast formation resulting in decreased bone resorption and increased bone mass. Alendronate is a bisphosphonate that inhibits osteoclastic bone resorption through a number of different mechanisms, including impairing their ability to form the ruffled border to adhere to the bony surface and produce the protons needed to continue bone resorption. Teriparatide is a sythetic form of human parathyroid hormone which stimulates osteoblast activity. Raloxifene is a selective oestrogen receptor modulator (SERM) which exerts the positive oestrogen effects on bone including reducing resorption of bone and increasing bone mineral density. Strontium ranelate increases osteoblast precursor replication and collagen synthesis, and reduces bone resorption through altering the ultrastructure of osteoclasts. References: RACGP Osteoporosis Pharmacological Management and Denosumab Mechanism of Action.
IncorrectAnswers: Raloxifene;;Alendronate;;Strontium ranelate ;;Teriparatide

Text: Which of these diseases are not associated with their corresponding immunological hypersensitivity?
CorrectAnswer: Type III & Haemolytic disease of the newborn
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Haemolytic disease of the newborn is a type II hypersensitivity reaction, not type III. 

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/kLaUz58CBMc" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
IncorrectAnswers: Type IV & Leprosy;;Type II (V) & Myasthenia Gravis;;Type II & Blood transfusion reactions;;Type I & Allergic Rhinitis

Text: Which of the following does NOT increase coronary artery blood supply?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Coronary arteries fill passively during diastole, hence shortening this time would decrease blood supply to the coronary arteries, not increase it. All the other options result in vasodilation of the coronary vessels, reducing the resistance and increase blood supply. This is detailed further in the reference below. Reference: Coronary blood flow
IncorrectAnswers: Vagal nerve activation;;Increased cardiac activity;;Locally released nitric oxide;;Locally released adenosine

Text:
Donald is a 74 year old man who has been experiencing worsening vision over the past few years. Initially he noticed loss to the sides of his visual field, however it has now starting to affect his central vision. This is concerning to Donald as he is a keen birdwatcher. 

On examination, Donald is systemically well. Fundoscopy shows an increased cup-to-disc ratio, and tonometry demonstrates increased ocular pressures. 

Given the likely diagnosis, which of the following is NOT a risk factor for development of this condition?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: The clinical scenario here represents glaucoma, most likely of the chronic open angle type. Given the insidious nature of chronic glaucoma, it can lead to complete blindness if not recognised and treated. Risk factors for glaucoma include increased pressure in the eyes, family history, migraines, hypertension, diabetes, age over 40-60, African/Hispanic/Asian heritage and previous eye injuries/surgery. Vitamin A deficiency is not a risk factor for developing glaucoma. Whilst it does play an important role in vision through the production of rhodopsin which is necessary for sensing low light situations, it does not have any relation to glaucoma. It instead can cause nyctalopia (night blindness), and is a leading cause of blindness in developing countries. References: Mayo Clinic American Academy of Ophthalmologists Vitamin A Deficiency - Wikipedia
IncorrectAnswers: Family History;;Hypertension;;Diabetes;;Age over 60

Text:
Ben is a 32 year old accountant who fails to attend court on charges of embezzlement due to a severe headache. This is the third time this has occurred, and each time he presents to the ED on the day of court with complaints of severe headaches. On examination and imaging there are no abnormalities found, despite his complaints of severe pain. 

This presentation is an example of which of the following diagnoses?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Malingering is the conscious production of signs and symptoms of medical illness with a conscious motivation. Usually this is to avoid something, gain an advantage or revenge. There is a tendency to fake common disorders with symptoms that are hard to refute e.g. headaches, anxiety, low back pain etc. In this question, the fact that these 'severe headaches' only occur when he is to present to court should lead you to consider this diagnosis, although a proper assessment of the patient would be needed to ensure no serious condition is missed. 

Conversion disorder is sensory (or motor) dysfunction in the absence of physical pathology. Usually occurs in females, appears suddenly and remits spontaneously. It can also occur in epidemics. This does not typically present with headaches in this nature. 

Hypochondriasis is the fear or belief that they have a specific disease. Present for 6 months, their preoccupation is there despite reassurance by doctors, and it affects their level of functioning. This is not a delusional disorder. 

Factitious disorder is the conscious production of signs and symptoms of medical illness with unconscious motivation. The objective is to assume the sick role. If the tests come back negative, they tend to become angry and accuse the doctors, threatening litigation. This is a reasonable differential for this question, however there is clear motivation to avoid the court case in this scenario. 

Subarachnoid haemorrhage would have to be considered in a patient with a severe headache. However, given the repeated episodes and no findings on examination and imaging, this is less likely. 

Reference: Deakin Lecture 'Somatoform Disorders' by Richard Harvey - Cloud Deakin Year 3 Mental Health
IncorrectAnswers: Subarachnoid haemorrhage;;Conversion disorder;;Factitious disorder;;Hypochondriasis

Text:
A 32-year-old farm worker sustains a head injury when falling from a motorbike at high speed with no head protection. When ambulance services arrive at the scene of the accident 2 hours later, the patient opened his eyes to pain only, was engaging in disoriented conversation and was localising to pain. Witnesses to the injury note that the patient lost consciousness for roughly 90 minutes after the accident. During the first several hours in hospital, the patient shows signs of post-traumatic amnesia, with disorientation to time, person and place, as well as no recollection of the accident. The post-traumatic amnesia resolves spontaneously 6 hours after the initial accident.

Based on the clinical scenario, what is the severity of the patient's traumatic brain injury (TBI)?
Topics: Aged Care, Rehabilitation and Palliative Care(Year 4)
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Severity of traumatic brain injury (TBI) is determined by initial GCS after resuscitation and length of post-traumatic amnesia (PTA). Some sources cite period of unconsciousness as another determinant of severity.

Mild TBI correlates to an initial GCS of 13-15 and PTA less than 30 minutes. Moderate TBI correlates to an initial GCS of 9-12 and PTA between 30 minutes and 24 hours. Severe TBI correlates to an initial GCS of 3-8 and PTA lasting more than 24 hours. 

https://lifeinthefastlane.com/ccc/traumatic-brain-injury/
IncorrectAnswers: No TBI;;Mild TBI;;Severe TBI;;Very severe TBI

Text: Which of the following are NOT common causes of traveller s diarrhoea?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: C. Diff is typically acquired after use of antibiotics. All the other organisms listed are common causative agents for diarrhoea in travellers, particularly to foreign countries.
IncorrectAnswers: E. Coli;;Giardia;;Shigella;;Rotavirus

Text: The median nerve supplies all of the following anterior forearm muscles EXCEPT?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Flexor carpi ulnaris is supplied by the ulnar nerve. All of the other muscles listed are supplied directly by the median nerve. Teach Me Anatomy - Muscles of Anterior Forearm
IncorrectAnswers: Pronator teres;;Palmaris longus;;Flexor carpi radialis;;Flexor digitorum superficialis

Text: Which category of drugs, listed by the Therapeutic Goods Administration, has been deemed safe for pregnant women and will not cause harm to the fetus?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Category A drugs have been used by many pregnant women without evidence of fetal malformation or harm. Category B3 causes in utero malformation in animal studies (not enough evidence to guarantee safety), category D drugs have not been tested but do cause irreversible malformation in the limited women who have taken them during pregnancy, and Category X drugs have a known high risk of causing harm to the fetus. Category S does not exist.
IncorrectAnswers: Category X;;Category D;;Category B3;;Category S

Text:
You are the surgical intern at a busy metropolitan hospital. You go to see Mrs Davis, a 54 year old female who is 4 hours post right hemithyroidectomy, as the nurse is concerned about her breathing. As you begin to assess her, you notice that she has marked respiratory distress with an increased respiratory rate (28 breaths/min), reduced oxygen saturation (95% on RA) and some stridor. The right side of her neck also appears to be swollen. 

You believe there could be haematoma developing at the surgical site obstructing her airway. As the nurse calls a MET call and begins to manage the airway, what is the most important next step?
CorrectAnswer: Remove skin staples/sutures from the wound
CorrectAnswerExplanation: A haematoma obstructing the airway following any neck surgery is rare but life threatening emergency. Removal of sutures should be done on the ward, and be performed by the first doctor at the scene of a patient with signs of upper respiratory tract obstruction post neck surgery. This should help release the pressure and reduce the obstruction. Put on a Hudson mask at 6L O2 = While giving O2 is an important consideration, the most critical issue is maintaining the airway which involves releasing the pressure of the haematoma through removal of sutures. Call your surgical registrar and await for their advice = This is a surgical emergency that needs to be recognised and treated by interns on the ward. Any delay could result in airway compromise and potential respiratory arrest. Arrange for an urgent CT scan of neck = the cause of the airway compromise should be determined clinically and treated as such Put on a 5mcg salbutamol nebuliser and watch the patient for improvement = this would be involved in the management of an asthma attack, but play no role in a physical obstruction of the upper airway as in this case Reference
IncorrectAnswers: Arrange for an urgent CT scan of the neck;;Put on a Hudson mask at 6L O2;;Put on a 5mcg salbutamol nebuliser and watch the patient for improvement;;Call your surgical registrar and await for their advice

Text:
A 38-year old woman presents to the ED complaining of chest pain for the past several hours. She describes it as sharp, centrally located, and non-radiating. The pain worsens somewhat with inspiration and movement. The patient denies having fevers, chills, dyspnoea, sweating or difficulty breathing at night. 

She says she first noticed the pain while exercising 3 weeks ago, but has experienced it at rest as well. She says she has been exercising heavily in order to lose weight, as her BMI is 34. She smokes half a pack of cigarettes a day. On physical exam her BP is 112/69, and HR is 72/min. Cardiac exam reveals regular S1 and S2 without extra sounds or murmurs. There is tenderness to palpation over the sternum. 

What is the most likely cause of her chest pain?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: This is a classic presentation of costochondritis - chest pain associated with exercise, worsening when pressure is applied. The fact that her pain is localised and sharp, worsens with inspiration and movement = all suggests musculoskeletal aetiology.
IncorrectAnswers: Pericarditis;;Pulmonary embolism;;Stable angina;;GORD

Text:
A 67-year-old man is receiving a blood transfusion to treat significant anaemia that has developed secondary to bowel cancer. 3 hours after the transfusion was commenced, the man complains of fever, chills and shortness of breath. The nurse takes a set of vital signs, which indicate increased respiratory rate and heart rate, as well as hypotension and hypoxia. The nurse notes that the man's urine in his catheter bag appears normal in colour.

What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the best course of management?
CorrectAnswer: Transfusion-related acute lung injury, cease transfusion
CorrectAnswerExplanation: This scenario is describing TRALI (transfusion related acute lung injury), a type of transfusion reaction that leads to a clinical picture that essentially mimics ARDS (bilateral chest infiltrates and hypoxia). TRALI tends to develop after the transfusion has been running for several hours, while acute haemolytic transfusion reactions tend to occur immediately once the transfusion begins. If TRALI is suspected, the transfusion should be ceased immediately, and intensive supportive care should be instituted. Red Cross - Adverse transfusion reactions
IncorrectAnswers: Transfusion-related acute lung injury, temporarily cease transfusion and re-commence after 30 minutes of monitoring of vital signs;;Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction, cease transfusion immediately;;Febrile transfusion reaction, continue transfusion and give paracetamol;;Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction, give paracetamol and extra crystalloid fluids

Text: What is the preferred staining method of Mycobacterium?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Mycobacterium are acid-fast bacilli, and require a special staining technique known as Ziehl-Neelsen stain to be visualised. Reference: Ziehl-Neeslen Staining
IncorrectAnswers: Haematoxylin and Eosin;;Silver Stain;;Gram Stain;;Mycobacterium are not able to be stained

Text: What is a granuloma composed of?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: A granuloma is a focal collection of epithelioid macrophages which follows a chronic inflammatory reaction. Reference: Granuloma
IncorrectAnswers: T-cells;;B-cells;;Dendritic cells;;Neutrophils

Text: What is the inheritance pattern of cystic fibrosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Cystic fibrosis is a classic example of an autosomal recessive condition.
IncorrectAnswers: Autosomal dominant;;X-linked dominant;;X-linked recessive;;Mitochondrial

Text:
A 60-year old man arrives at ED shocked with sudden onset, severe chest pain at rest. He complains that the pain is radiating to his back and down his arms. He has a past medical history of hypertension, angina, and had a DVT 4 years ago. His regular medications include ramipril, GTN spray and simvastatin. He has never smoked and doesn't drink alcohol. On examination, it is noted that he has uneven blood pressures on either arm. A chest x-ray reveals a widened mediastinum, and ECG shows sinus tachycardia.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Aortic dissection presents similar to a STEMI, however the pain classically radiated to the back, and is often described as 'tearing.' In this case, the ECG did not report any St elevation, ruling out C as the answer.
The other giveaway is the widened mediastinum on CXR and the uneven bilateral blood pressures. In an MCQ, this is classic of an aortic dissection.
IncorrectAnswers: Pulmonary embolus (PE);;ST elevation myocardial infarction;;Unstable angina;;Coarctation of the aorta

Text: Which of the following is NOT a criteria for an Assessment Order under the Mental Health Act 2014?
CorrectAnswer: The person must not be under the influence of any drugs and/or alcohol
CorrectAnswerExplanation: An Assessment Order under the Mental Health Act 2014 must satisfy all of the following criteria: the person appears to have mental illness (mental illness is a medical condition that is characterised by a significant disturbance of thought, mood, perception or memory); and b. because the person appears to have mental illness, the person appears to need immediate treatment to prevent: i. serious deterioration in the person s mental or physical health; or ii. serious harm to the person or to another person; and c. if the person is made subject to an Assessment Order, the person can be assessed; and d. there is no less restrictive means reasonably available to enable the person to be assessed The presence of alcohol and/or drug intoxication does not preclude early assessment, although it may indicate the need for further assessment when the person is no longer intoxicated. The coexistence of intoxication does not prevent assessment by Crisis Assessment and Treatment services. References: Compulsory Treatment, Assessment Order Form, Assessment of Intoxicated Persons
IncorrectAnswers:
There is no less restrictive means reasonably available to enable the person to be assessed;;If the person is made subject to an Assessment Order, the person can be assessed;;The person appears to have a mental illness;;Because the person appears to have mental illness, the person appears to need immediate treatment to
prevent serious deterioration in the person s mental or physical health or serious harm to the person or to another person

Text:
A 77-year-old man is admitted to ICU after repair of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. Intraoperatively, he received 8 units of packed RBCs, and was transferred to ICU on a ventilator with an ETT in situ, initially with minimal oxygen requirements. Twenty-four hours later, his requirement for O2 has begun to increase. A CXR shows new bi-basal opacities. An echocardiogram demonstrates good right and left ventricular function with an ejection fraction of 55%. 

The most likely diagnosis is:
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
ARDS occurs in situations of severe illness and/or lung injury. It can be diagnosed using the Berlin definition of:
1. Acute   onset over 1 week or less
2. Bilateral opacities consistent with pulmonary oedema on CXR or CT
3. PaO/FiO <300mmHg (40kPa) with a minimum PEEP of 5cm H2O
4. Not fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload

Acute lung injury is an outdated term analogous to ARDS. Ventilator-associated pneumonia occurs in situations such as these (patients on ventilators with opacity on CXR), however the illness takes longer to develop than the scenario above. While TRALI presents similarly to the above patient (especially given his high volume of blood products received), by definition it must present within 6 hours of transfusion. Given the normal echocardiography result, cardiogenic pulmonary oedema can be effectively ruled out.

Acute respiratory distress syndrome: the Berlin Definition, ardsnet.org
IncorrectAnswers: Acute lung injury (ALI);;Ventilator-associated pneumonia;;Transfusion-related acute lung injury;;Cardiogenic pulmonary oedema

Text: Which of the following describes a Jefferson fracture?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: A Jefferson fracture is the eponymous name given to a burst fracture of C1 otherwise known as the atlas. This fracture results from excessive axial load during hyperextension of the neck, usually seen from injuries involving diving into swallow water, impact against the roof of vehicles or falls from heights. If the transverse atlantal ligament remains intact, it is considered stable and will usually be managed conservatively with hard collar immobilisation. If disrupted it is unstable and will require more extensive management. Reference: Jefferson Fracture Radiopedia
IncorrectAnswers: Fracture of the fibula;;Fracture of the dens of C2;;Fracture of the pedacles of C2;;Fracture of the humerus

Text:
Karen is a first time mother. She brings her son Billy to the maternal and child nurse for a routine visit. During the visit, Billy sits on the ground without support, crawls around the room and is able to stand whilst holding on to something. He is playful and babbles, but does not make any specific words. He is also able to take blocks and pass them to his mother. 

Assuming the developmental milestones exhibited by Billy are normal, what is his approximate age?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Sits without support = 5-8 months Crawling = 6-9 months Stand holding on = 6-9 months Babbling = 6-9 months Passing blocks = 5-8 months Given the average age of the above milestones, 7 months is the only answer that fits within these timeframes. At 10 months he would be expected to be achieving more milestones such as walking holding on, saying mama/dada, waving goodbye etc. References: RACGP and Developmental Milestones.
IncorrectAnswers: 4 months;;18 months;;10 months;;1 year

Text: Which one of these processes does NOT occur in meiosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Genetically distinct haploid cells are produced in meiosis, hence the production of identical daughter cells does not occur. The production of haploid gametes ensures the correct number of chromosomes when fertilization occurs. Crossing over results in recombination that aids in genetic diversity. There are 2 cycles of cellular division in meiosis, 1 in mitosis and therefore metaphase 2 only appears in meiotic division. This is similar to anaphase 2, in which the sister chromatids separate and are pulled towards opposite poles of the cell. Reference: Khan Academy Meiosis
IncorrectAnswers: 1st anaphase;;Production of Haploid gametes;;2nd metaphase;;Recombination

Text: Which of the following people would NOT be required to undergo faecal occult blood testing at this point in time?
CorrectAnswer: A 46-year-old female whose father was diagnosed with bowel cancer aged 62
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Family history for a single instance of bowel cancer becomes significant if a first degree relative is diagnosed before age 55. As such, the person in option B does not require FOBT testing until they turn 50, as they fall into the "Average or Slightly Increased Risk" category. If the first degree relative is diagnosed prior to age 55, then screening is recommended to commence 10 years younger than the age of first diagnosis of the relative (e.g. if the relative was 51, then screening should begin at age 41). Screening can be colonoscopy, +/- FOBT in this moderately increased risk demographic.

RACGP Guidelines for preventive activities in general practice - Colorectal Cancer
IncorrectAnswers: A 54-year-old female with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS);;A 72-year-old male with no past heath issues;;All the above require FOBT screening currently;;A healthy 52-year-old male with no family history of bowel cancer

Text: A 20-year old man wakes up on Sunday morning unable to extend his right wrist. He had been drinking heavily the night before. What is the likely cause of his weakness?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: This is a classic presentation of 'Saturday night palsy' - caused by compression of the radial nerve against the humeral shaft, possibly due to sleeping on a hard chair with the hand draped over the back. The radial nerve supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm, wrist, fingers and thumb, and so a palsy classically results in wrist drop. The anatomy of the radial nerve can be revisedhere.
IncorrectAnswers: Fractured ulna;;Ulnar nerve palsy;;Fractured radius;;Median nerve palsy

Text: Karen, a 17 year old type 1 diabetic presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, and confusion. An arterial blood gas shows a high anion gap metabolic acidosis and she is diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis. Which of the following is not a cause of high anion gap metabolic acidosis?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
The causes of high anion gap metabolic acidosis can be remembered by the mnemonic LTKR or Left Total Knee Replacement

Lactic acidosis
Toxins
Ketoacidosis
Renal failure (leading to uraemia)

The anion gap is calculated by Na - (Cl + HCO3), in Addison's disease the hyponatraemia will lead to a normal anion gap.

For more reading see: https://lifeinthefastlane.com/ccc/anion-gap/
IncorrectAnswers: Ketoacidosis;;Renal failure;;Ethylene Glycol;;Lactic acidosis

Text:
An 85 year old man is in pre-admission clinic for a total hip replacement. Today, he reports having mild shortness of breath and chest pain on exertion. On examination, the patient has an ejection systolic murmur in the upper right sternal edge associated with a slow rising pulse and  narrow pulse pressure

What underlying valve pathology does this patient have?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Aortic stenosis is a narrowing of the aorta that is most commonly caused by age-related calcinosis. Other causes include congenital, a bicuspid aortic valve (as seen in Turner's syndrome) and rheumatic heart disease.

Hypertrophy of the left ventricle is required to increase blood pressure to  push blood through the aortic valve which can result in an ejection click. Furthermore, stenosis of the valve results in turbulent flow leading to an ejection systolic murmur.
IncorrectAnswers: Mitral Stenosis;;Mitral valve prolapse ;;Aortic Regurgitation;;Mitral Regurgitation

Text:
A 62 year old male presents to the GP for a regular check-up. On examination, you notice an ejection systolic murmur in the upper right sternal edge The murmur does not radiate to the carotids and has a normal pulse and normal apex beat.

What is the underlying valve pathology?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Aortic sclerosis occurs when the aortic valves thicken, resulting in turbulent flow. This is not to be confused with aortic stenosis, which is stiffening of the aortic valve causing a narrowing of the opening through which blood passes through. 

It can be differentiated from aortic stenosis by its non-radiating nature, normal pulse and apex beat.
IncorrectAnswers: Aortic Stenosis ;;Mitral Regurgitation;;Mitral Stenosis ;;Mitral Valve Prolapse

Text: Which of the following would be most appropriate in a patient with a very low level of fibrinogen?
IncorrectAnswers: Apheresis platelets;;Pooled platelets;;Fresh frozen plasma;;Irradiated red blood cells

Text: Which statement is false?
CorrectAnswer: Acetylcholine Nicotinic receptors are G-coupled protein receptors
IncorrectAnswers: GABA is typically in inhibitory neuron as its receptor is typically a Cl- ion channel;;Saltatory transmission along a neuron is faster than continuous transmission;;There are two common types of receptors for Acetylcholine, nicotinic receptors and muscarinic receptors;;Acetylcholine esterase inhibitors increase the amount and or duration of neurotransmitter in the synaptic cleft

Text: Leukocyte extravasation involves:
CorrectAnswer: PECAM-PECAM interaction on white blood cells and endothelial cells
IncorrectAnswers: ICAM/VCAM interaction with alpha/beta integrins during transmigration;;De novo synthesis of P-selectin;;Sialyl Lewis X interaction with P-selectin to facilitate pavementing;;Vasoconstriction

Text: Sodium potassium pumps (Na+/K+ ATPase) involve which type of transport:
CorrectAnswerExplanation: These pumps are used to maintain low intracellular concentrations of sodium. They work by pumping sodium out of the cell using ATP (making them active, so it can t be B), then bringing potassium back into the cell. As the molecules are moving in different directions this makes this system antiport transport. If the molecules were moving in the same direction, it would be symport. If there was only one molcule, it would be uniport. Transporters that use the energy from the Na+ gradient that this pump creates (ie transports molecules in or out of the cell by bringing Na+ in down its concentration gradient) is dais to be undergoing secondary active transport.
IncorrectAnswers: Uniport transport;;Active diffusion;;Passive diffusion;;Symport transport

Text: Which statement is correct?
CorrectAnswer: Spinal nerves consist of mixed fibres both sensory and motor
IncorrectAnswers: The parasympathetic preganglionic neuron is shorter than the sympathetic preganglionic neuron;;There are 32 spinal nerves;;The dorsal root is responsible for the conducting of efferent transmission;;In the spinal cord the white matter is in the central region surrounded by grey matter

Text: Which of the following is FALSE regarding the action potential?
IncorrectAnswers: It is the transmitted form one axon to another;;Hyperpolarisation of the membrane is due to K+ moving out of the cell;;The Na+/K+ pump restores the membrane to resting potential;;Depolarisation occurs due to entry of Na+ into the cell

Text: Which of the following is NOT an enabler of cancer?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Enabling replicating immorality is a hallmark of cancer
IncorrectAnswers: Genome instability and mutation ;;Activating invasion and metastasis ;;Inducing angiogenesis ;;Tumour-promoting inflammation

Text: How does thiamin deficiency affect fuel metabolism in the tricarboxylic acid (Krebs) cycle?
CorrectAnswer: The conversion of alpha-ketoglutarate to succinyl CoA is impaired
IncorrectAnswers: The synthesis of fatty acids from citrate is diminished;;The replenishing of intermediates from glutamate is blocked;;The release of succinate from succinyl CoA is slowed;;The synthesis of oxaloacetate from pyruvate is disrupted

Text: Which of these statements is incorrect?
CorrectAnswer: The Brunner s glands are located in the duodenum secrete acidic mucous.
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Brunner's glands are submucosal glands of the duodenum and secrete ALKALINE mucous to protect the duodenum from stomach acid.

Text:
A patient presents to you with two days of fever, sore throat and enlarged tonsils. They deny the presence of a cough. On examination, there are palpable cervical chain lymph nodes and obvious tonsilar exudate. 

What infectious organism is most likely to be responsible?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
This patient has streptococcal pharyngitis. 

Centor criteria: 
- Fever
- Tonsilar inflammation and exudate
- Cervical lymphadenopathy
- Absence of a cough. 

RSV and parainfluenzae are common causative agents of upper respiratory tract infections and typically cause rhinorrhoea, croup and bronchiolitis. Mycoplasma pneumoniae may cause community acquired pneumonia. Haemophilus influenza type B is a vaccine-preventable infection that may cause epiglottitis.
IncorrectAnswers: Haemophilus influenza type B;;Respiratory Syncytial virus;;Mycoplasma pneumoniae;;Parainfluenzae

Text: A 3-month-old boy has had recurrent infections of the respiratory, gastrointestinal, and urinary tracts since birth. The infectious agents have included Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jiroveci, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, rotavirus, and cytomegalovirus. Despite intensive treatment with antibiotics and antifungal drugs, he dies at age 5 months. At autopsy, lymph nodes are small with very few lymphocytes and no germinal centres. The thymus, Peyer patches, and tonsils are hypoplastic. There is a family history of other males with similar findings. Which of the following immunologic alterations best describes the abnormality that caused this patient s illness?
CorrectAnswer: Mutation in the common ³ chain of cytokine receptors
IncorrectAnswers: Mutation in the Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene;;Deletion involving chromosome 22q11;;Deficiency of CD4 cells due to congenital HIV infection;;Mutation in CD40 ligand

Text: What is the structure that prevents the bowstringing of tendons where they cross joints?

Text: A patient has developed fever, hypotension, nausea and pain in their back and test after undergoing a blood transfusion. This is likely to be due to which type of hypersensitivity?
CorrectAnswerExplanation:
Type I - Allergy. IgE mediated. Eg Allergic rhinitis, anaphylaxis. 
Type II - Cytotoxic. Antibody + complement mediated cellular destruction. IgG or IgM antibodies react with cellular/surface autoantigens, causing cellular lysis. Eg ABO mismatch transfusion reaction, haemolytic disease of the newborn (maternal IgG binds to foetal RBCs)
Type II(V) - Stimulatory. Antibody mediated cellular dysfunction (as distinct from Type II, where cells are destroyed). Eg Myasthenia Gravis, Graves Disease.
Type III - Immune complex mediated. Ab + Ag = soluble immune complexes which deposit and cause local inflammatory response. Eg Arthus reaction, Serum sickness. 
Type IV - Delayed. T-cell mediated. Eg Granulomatous hypersensitivity as seen in TB.
IncorrectAnswers: Type II (V);;Type III;;Type IV;;Type I

Text: Bill has come to see his GP with a fever, headache, and productive cough. Upon questioning you find out that bill has returned from an overseas working trip last week. You prescribe Bill some paracetamol and tell him to return if his symptoms get worse. A week later Bill returns complaining of delirious spells & increasingly worse fevers. Upon examination you notice that Bill is bradycardic and has pink papules, that look like rose spots on his chest. What is the most likely cause of Bill s symptoms?
CorrectAnswerExplanation: Typhoid. Typically lasts 4 weeks. Week 1 expect to see fever, headaches, malaise, constipation and productive cough. Week 2 high spiking fevers, splenomegaly, delirium, bradycardia and (30% chance) rose spots. Week 3 confusion states, watery diarrhoea (pea soup). Week 4 fever, confusion states   begin to resolve. Most common cause of fever in travellers.
IncorrectAnswers: Influenza ;;Hepatitis B;;Malaria ;;Dengue
